column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This module introduces the core themes of the central IMARC theme: ‘Border crossing, Security and Social Justice’. Students learn in-depth about various aspects of border crossing, security and social justice and their socio-political and criminological relevance, the value of critical and cultural criminological approaches, and the important national and international actors involved. Students are encouraged to view the core themes from different perspectives, specifically those perspectives which are related to the three IMARC tracks offered by the three partner universities:

column2: • Global flows, local dilemma’s and glocal solutions
• European Union criminal policy and justice in context
• Border crossing – theory, culture, power, and the global.

column1: In addition, the module builds on the module Globalisation and crime to further examine comparative and cross-cultural criminological research and research in an international setting more generally: either on an international topic, by working with internationally focused actors or by doing (internationally) comparative research. The aim is to engage students with the core themes of the IMARC programme and to stimulate them to formulate a direction for their research project. The classes will help students to select research themes, formulate appropriate research questions and in broad lines design research approaches, preparing students for choosing their final research topic and writing their research proposal in semester 2.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Upon completion of the module, the student will be able:

column2: • Discuss relevant criminological themes related to border crossing, security and social justice in relation to (global) current socio-political and legal developments,
• Discuss and compare the roles of important national and international actors involved in issues of border crossing, security and social justice,
• Describe and reflect on the added value of doing research in an international setting,
• Describe and reflect on various strategies of doing research in an international setting,
• Reflect on the particular practical, political and ethical challenges of doing
• Write a basic proposal for a research project including a first research question and broad outline of a research approach.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89837,2019,Brain & Behaviour,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. A Mora Cortes'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is an introduction to the structure and function of the brain. The different processes in the brain that shape our behaviour will be discussed in the context of psychology and neuroscience. The general aim of the course is to provide a basic understanding of how our brain processes information, how the environment affect this processing, and how our brain guides our behaviour accordingly. The theories and models that describe the brain and its relation with human behaviour will be presented at various levels and from different perspectives. Understanding complex processes such as memory, movements and consciousness, requires knowledge about the underlying neurobiological systems, including the structure of -and cellular communication within- the brain.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The learning objectives of the course are that you:

column2: • are able to describe the role of the eye and the brain in visual perception;
• understand the concepts of memory and attention;
• understand the role of the brain in generating voluntary and reflexive movements
• understand how behaviour can be changed by experiences;
• can describe the concepts of problem solving and intelligence;
• understand the general structure and functioning of the brain.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85701,2019,Brain and Cognition: Perception,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. R Zeelenberg'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: <div>

column6: In dit blok zal je veel leren over visuele en auditieve perceptie en over de werking van onze evenwichtsorganen. Theorieën over, bijvoorbeeld, de perceptie van contrast, kleur en objecten zullen aan bod komen. Verder zul je kennis maken met experimentele methodes die worden gebruikt in wetenschappelijk onderzoek naar perceptie en aandacht.

column5: <div>

column6: Er wordt zeer veel onderzoek gedaan naar perceptie. Het zal je daarom niet verbazen dat we in dit blok keuzes hebben moeten maken uit de brede waaier aan mogelijke onderwerpen. Daarbij is er ten eerste voor gezorgd dat de onderwerpen op elkaar aansluiten. Ten tweede is er voor gezorgd dat binnen deze onderwerpen een zekere diepgang kan worden bereikt. Keuzes maken betekent dat we sommige interessante onderwerpen hebben moeten laten liggen. Zo wordt de nadruk gelegd op visuele waarneming en in mindere mate auditieve waarneming en ruimtelijke oriëntatie. Andere zintuigen – reuk, smaak, en tast – zijn al kort aan bod gekomen bij blok 1.4 en komen hier slechts zeer zijdelings aan bod.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: In dit blok zul je kennis verwerven over visuele en auditieve waarneming, twee gerela-teerde onderwerpen die in de biologische en cognitieve psychologie veel aandacht krijgen. Daarnaast besteden we aandacht aan de evenwichtsorganen en ruimtelijke oriëntatie. Aan het einde van het blok wordt van je verwacht dat je in staat bent:

column5: De anatomie en functionaliteit van het oog en het oor te beschrijven alsmede de structuren en processen in de hersenen die een rol spelen bij de waarneming van visuele en auditieve stimuli.
Uit te leggen op grond waarvan mensen beslissingen nemen over de aan/afwezigheid van een stimulus.
Uit te leggen hoe mensen verschillen in stimulusintensiteit waarnemen.

De wetenschappelijke hoofdstromingen te beschrijven die iets zeggen over hoe het cognitieve systeem visuele en auditieve elementen groepeert en interpreteert en hoe objecten en auditieve patronen herkend worden.
Uit te leggen hoe het visuele systeem omgaat met diepte-informatie.
Uit te leggen hoe en wanneer beweging wordt waargenomen.
Uit te leggen hoe kleuren worden waargenomen en welke deficiënties hierbij kunnen optreden.
De anatomie en functionaliteit van de evenwichtsorganen te beschrijven alsmede de structuren en processen in de hersenen die een rol spelen bij ruimtelijke oriëntatie.
Een aantal belangrijke experimentele paradigma’s op het gebied van perceptie en aandacht te beschrijven.
Correcte statistische analyses uit te voeren op de resultaten van onderzoek met deze paradigma’s.
In staat te zijn de uitkomsten van deze analyses te interpreteren.
De uitkomsten van de statistische analyses op een correcte wijze te rapporteren (i.e., volgens de richtlijnen van de APA).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87460,2019,Brand Development,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. J Boegershausen', 'dr. QPC Andre']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Think about the brands that inspire you, those that trigger your embarrassment, and about those that don’t mean much to you. Where do these differences in your attitudes come from? How are great brands made and managed? The goal of this course is to train you to be able to do just that – know how to create and manage brands which bond deeply with consumers and provide them with value.

Brand management is primarily skill, a skill of integrating coherently knowledge from a broad set of marketing domains such as strategic analysis, marketing research, consumer behavior, marketing communication, etc. The core of the course is a practical assignment called Brand Audit. The background knowledge necessary to complete the Brand Audit is introduced during lectures and case discussions. Lectures cover relevant theories while case discussions provide an illustration of how those theories can be applied in practice.

The course is suitable for students of marketing seeking to integrate their marketing knowledge and develop skills in applying it in the field of brand management. It is also suitable for students of other domains of management who seek to gain broad, practically oriented, and comprehensive insight into the field of marketing.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: Make managerial decisions in a structured way

column3: Organize information obtained from various sources, in various format
Coherently integrate multiple insights into a managerial decision

column2: Communicate your decisions in a coherent and convincing way

column3: Prioritize issues and focus on the key ones
Communicate efficiently in the written form using combination of text and graphics

column2: Develop substantive links between theories, frameworks, business cases
Share your thoughts in a public setting

column1: Ability to direct and execute work on:

column2: Identifying and prioritizing challenges facing a brand
Design a marketing plan aimed at achieving specific branding goals
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: A brand is often considered to be the company’s most valuable asset, although the origin of this value resides in the mind of the consumer. This Branding course takes a strong consumer‐based view on branding, so we will discuss the foundation of branding in consumer behavior and consumer psychology. The course provides insight into how consumers perceive brands and the roles these brands play in their everyday lives.

We will look at product and service brands and we will look at consumer markets and industrial markets. We will focus on the value of brands, brand associations, consumer‐brand relationships, brand building strategies, the leverage of brand value, brand architecture, and brand image measurement. Although the basis for our approach is the consumer, we will translate these consumer insights into marketing practice and strategic brand management, very much including a business brand environment as well. We will build a strong theoretical foundation by studying journal articles, but we will immediately translate this theory to practice by means of short articles from the business press, discussions on company's branding strategies (including several guest presentations, e.g. a brand designer and a brand manager) and practical team assignments. Apart from instructive and interesting, this course bridges the gap between theory and practice and is both interesting and fun! Do realize that all of us are confronted with brands every single day, and it is challenging to explore the processes by which they are built and communicated to you.
During the lessons the following topics will be discussed:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students understand the consumer psychology of brands (brand decision making) and its application in marketing and advertising.
• Students review and criticize academic publications on topics related to branding, advertising, and consumer psychology.
• Students analyze how companies apply branding theory in their marketing strategies and the methods they use to measure advertising effectiveness.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87184,2019,Brands, Media and Identity",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. M Scalvini'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Brands and branding have become central to contemporary businesses practice, with successes and failures inherently connected to their connections with consumers. With the development of truly global brands that have mediated connections to people worldwide, the relationship between differing ‘brands’ and the construction of personal identity through consumption has become increasingly important. This class will explore the intersections of brands with the use of (social) media, and how this becomes connected to expressions of personal consumption. Students will develop research that addresses differing aspects of these intersections. Specifically, the focus will be on interactive use of social media, such as is found within brand communities, Pinterest, Facebook pages, Twitter followers and more. In this process students will design a small research study, and collect and analyze their own data to examine the interactions between ‘brands’ and their customers. Pertinent issues that arise in this process are brands as assemblage, the mediation of brands, the use of social media for both cultural production and tracking consumers, user generated content, corporate resources in digital practices, and more.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The development of brands and branding and the connection to (social) media.
• Focused and practical research designs and methods to examine social media brand practices.
•  report on their findings in oral and written form.
•  reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on thriving at work in terms of the development of human strength and personal growth; and fostering resilience in employees within an organizational culture that makes healing, restoration, and reconciliation possible, and that cultivates extraordinary individual and organizational performance.

The course offers more in-depth knowledge into the recent insights from positive psychological/ organisational behavioural scholarship and how it can help answer the current needs and demands of organisations in general, and with regard to Human Resource management specifically.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:
1. Use a strength approach to encourage greater employee engagement.
2. Explain and understand theories in the area of positive organisational psychology and behaviour, with specific focus on assessment, personal development, team working and leadership.
3. Have a deeper personal insight into your own strengths and personal values.
4. Apply an inclusive HRM approach to long-term organisational performance</body>

column1: Het burgerlijk procesrecht is als het ware het sluitstuk van het materiële privaatrecht. Hier komen civielrechtelijke vakken als goederen- en verbintenissenrecht, arbeidsrecht en ondernemingsrecht samen bij het bestuderen van de wijze waarop een partij haar geschil aan de overheidsrechter kan voorleggen en hoe zij een uitspraak van de rechter ten uitvoer kan leggen. Het materiële recht dient dus als basis voor de bestudering van het burgerlijk procesrecht. Het wordt dan ook in grote lijnen bekend verondersteld.

Wanneer partijen een tussen hen bestaand civiel geschil niet in onderling overleg kunnen oplossen, hebben zij recht op toegang tot de rechter. Zij kunnen hun geschil voorleggen aan de overheidsrechter. Het burgerlijk procesrecht geeft de spelregels hoe partijen hun recht kunnen verwezenlijken. In dit vak krijg je een voorproefje van de rechtspraktijk: is het verstandig om te gaan procederen, hoe kan je het nodige bewijs leveren, welke procedure kies je, hoe begin je een procedure, hoe verloopt een procedure, welke ruimte heb je als rechter om over een zaak te beslissen, hoe kan een rechterlijke uitspraak ten uitvoer worden gelegd, kan tegen de uitspraak een rechtsmiddel worden ingesteld, hoe loopt de procedure daarna verder? Je gaat ook reflecteren op de botsende belangen in een procedure. Denk aan de wens van de politiek om procedures sneller te laten verlopen enerzijds en het belang van partijen om een gedegen beslissing in hun zaak te krijgen anderzijds.

Onderdeel van het vak maakt uit het concipiëren van eenvoudige processtukken. In dit vak is er aandacht voor de procesrechtelijke eisen waaraan een processtuk moet voldoen. Deze vaardigheid zal in de quizzes worden geoefend.
Omdat geschillen zich niet tot de landsgrenzen beperken, zal er aandacht zijn voor het grensoverschrijdend procederen.

De procedure voor de overheidsrechter is niet altijd de meest geschikte weg om het geschil op te lossen. In het vak burgerlijk procesrecht komen daarom ook alternatieve wijzen van geschiloplossing aan de orde, zoals arbitrage, bindend advies en mediation.

Ter illustratie wordt op Canvas een procesdossier geplaatst waaraan tijdens de colleges, de onderwijsgroepen en in de practicumopdrachten zal worden gerefereerd. Naast het procesdossier staan er ook voorbeelden van processtukken op Canvas, zoals een memorie van grieven en een beslagrekest, zodat je nog beter kan zien ‘hoe het er werkelijk aan toe gaat’. Het bekijken van informatie op rechtspraak.nl kan daarbij ook helpen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Uitleggen welke invloed de beginselen van procesrecht hebben op de beslechting of oplossing van geschillen en beoordelen of de beginselen in de procedureregels voldoende zijn gewaarborgd.
• De procedureregels in vorderings- en verzoekzaken in eerste aanleg omschrijven en in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De procesrechtelijke regels toepassen bij het opstellen van eenvoudige processtukken.
• De regels rond de feitenvaststelling, de bewijslevering en bewijslastverdeling omschrijven, uitleggen en in concrete gevallen toepassen.

• De mogelijkheden om een uitspraak aan te tasten, beschrijven en in concrete gevallen toepassen en de procedureregels van de procedure in verzet en hoger beroep uitleggen en in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De maatregelen tot bewaring van rechten en executie van uitspraken omschrijven en de specifieke regels in concrete gevallen toepassen.
• De procedureregels van de voornaamste vormen van alternatieve geschilbeslechting (arbitrage, bindend advies, mediation) uitleggen en in eenvoudige zaken toepassen.
• De bronnen van de regels voor de beslechting van grensoverschrijdende geschillen omschrijven en in eenvoudige zaken toepassen.
• Het materiële recht (verbintenissenrecht en goederen- en faillissementsrecht) toepassen bij het oplossen van procesrechtelijke vraagstukken, waaronder het opstellen van processtukken.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Stakeholders such as managers, shareholders, bankers and analysts rely on accounting information to understand, compare and forecast financial performance. The course ‘Business Analysis

and Valuation’ provides the knowledge and skills to understand the key concepts of financial accounting as well as to derive, interpret and forecast key metrics that matter for analysing, comparing and estimating financial performance. The course takes the perspective of the user of financial statements (investment analyst, portfolio manager, financial manager) as she interprets financial reports, prepares forecasts and applies valuation techniques to derive equity value.

The first sessions of the course will cover the key concepts and building blocks of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Then we will move to the focus of the course. Using financial statements, students learn to analyse various aspects of a business, including the efficiency of operating, investment, financing and dividend decisions as well as forecast key value drivers such as earnings, cash flows and returns. Students also learn how to critically evaluate the quality of financial reports and undo distortions to financial statements to improve financial reports for use in financial analysis and valuation. We will discuss the key approaches to equity valuation and cover the intricacies of major valuation methodologies (DCF Models, Residual Income- or Profit- Based Models, and Valuation Multiples) as well as the concept of equity and enterprise value. The course will have a strong practical emphasis and we will use topical case studies from different industries and regions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column3: • To understand the environment in which financial reporting by companies takes place
• To become acquainted with financial reporting requirements and practices applied by global firms
• To understand the limitations of International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as a global accounting language
• To appreciate the differences / similarities in the various valuation methodologies (Discounted Cash Flow Model, Profit-Based Models, and Valuation Multiples)
• To determine the quality of the accounting in financial reports and undo accounting distortions
• To analyse a firm's operating and investment performance through ratio and cash flow analysis
• To forecast future financial statements, determine the cost of capital, and apply fundamentals-based valuation techniques
• To obtain exposure to, and familiarity with, the fianncial statements of real companies
• To interpret the communication between company and financial markets on financial performance, forecasts and valuation
• To critically review a firm's key performance metrics within an industry context
• To question financial reporting requirements and firms reporting practices
• To appreciate the role of judgment in financial accounting and analysis

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course presents an overview of basic quantitative research methods and techniques that are frequently used in management and provides a context for developing skills in the practical application of these methods. Quantitative methods deal with the formulation of research hypotheses, setting up causal relationships schemes, quantitative data collection, and statistical methods to perform univariate (hypothesis testing and estimation), bivariate (ANOVA, t-test, correlation and contingency tables) and multivariate (regression) analyses.

Quantitative research covers the collection and analyses of quantitative data. The lectures will address the theoretical background of measurement and analysis techniques, but also aid hands-on experience with development of surveys and application of statistical techniques to process data and support inference. The various topics are presented: models, hypotheses and measurement theory; (univariate) estimation and hypothesis testing; bivariate analysis; and multivariate (regression) analysis. The distinction into univariate, bivariate and multivariate methods refers to the number of quantities involved in the analyses. Univariate methods are methods to analyse and represent the outcomes of individual variables. Bivariate methods consist of methods to analyse and represent the systematic pattern of joint outcomes of two variables, such as contingency tables, t-tests, correlation coefficients and analysis of variance. In this context, attention will be paid to phenomena, like spurious correlation, common causes and intervening variables, which can lead to highly misleading inferences if not appropriately handled. Multivariate methods are used to examine the dependencies between more than two variables at the same time. In this course, only regression analysis will be discussed.

Throughout the course, attention is paid to methodological topics, such as implications of the measurement scales of available variables, the difference between statistical dependence and (assumed) causality, the possibly disturbing influence of neglected intervening variables or common causes on previously observed associations, and the difference between simple and multivariate explanatory models. Practical research skills are developed within the context of a research project related to a topic in sustainability that comprises most elements of the empirical cycle, from hypothesis generation to data collection, analysis and reflection. Throughout the course, we make use of the software package R. Thanks to social media and other digitization efforts, textual sources are increasingly available on the Internet and providing a rich information source. This last part of the course will touch upon elementary analytics notions in this domain.
Students are required to successfully complete a prep course by the second week of September 2019.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The objectives of this course are to have knowledge about the background and application of commonly used quantitative methods and techniques, and to have skills to apply these methods in research practice.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89062,2019,Business Architecture and Transformation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. DK Zegners', 'prof.dr. M Weinmann -', 'prof.dr. T Li', 'Y Kuper, MSc', 'Z Yang, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In Business Architecture & Transformation we aim to explain the role of digital and leadership capabilities within organizations and how to assess these capabilities. We will present you with the concept of operating models and demonstrate on real life examples which operating model fits which kind of company. We will explain the difference between digital operations and digital strategy. Further, we will look into how investments in IT can be assessed.   We will point out the importance of IT governance to achieve strategic alignment between IT and business. Finally, we will talk about what really makes a true management leader in IT.

While you have looked into how to strategically use information and how to design business applications in the first block of your core courses we try to give you a perspective on how you can manage IT projects on a higher level. We look into the business and management perspective of transformation processes and how strategic decisions on a CIO-level should be made.
This course is a combination of lectures, guest lecturers, in class case analysis, and discussions.

Specific course guidelines will be made available via Canvas prior to the beginning of the course and need to be read and understood by each participant. Further, the textbook for the course needs to be purchased prior to the start of the course.
The assessment of the course can be divided into 2 main parts: (1) Individual: Final Exam, and (2) Group Assignments.

Group assignments focus on transformation projects for which students will face challenges in which they need to practically apply the tools and methods that they have theoretically studied for the course. Through specific grading criteria and feedback we help students to be able to recap their work and learn from its positive as well as negative aspects.

In the final exam students are assessed based on their understanding of the complete course both from a theoretical as well as practical perspective. The exam covers all themes presented in the lectures and guest lectures as well as the complete reading material.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course Business Architecture & Transformation focuses on managing activities of information resources within firms that are crucial for firm success. Although, understanding information technologies and their role in transforming businesses is important this offers only one part of the picture. Success of firms depends on both digital and leadership capabilities.
At the end of Business Architecture & Transformation a student is able to:

column2: • Evaluate the Digital and Leadership Capabilities within an organization
• Create a Digital Strategy for an organization
• Apply the main concepts of a Digital Transformation to an organizational context
• Determine the appropriate Digital Governance Structure for an organization
• Analyze the IT Funding Guidelines of an organization

column1: The course is divided into weekly themes containing several topics per theme.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87084,2019,Business History of Fashion,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AG Janssens, MSc', 'prof.dr. B Wubs']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Fashion has often been studied from a cultural or costume history perspective. This course aims to highlight other important aspects of fashion and focuses on the fashion industry. The main objective of this minor is to gain insight into the business historical dimensions of the fashion industry and the importance of fashion for the global and local economy. It delves into the history of fashion companies and intermediaries, the economic characteristics of the fashion products and its markets. Students will thus study past and recent developments in the fashion industry. They will gain a historical, business, economic perspective of the fashion industry through a mix of lectures, seminars, guest lecturers and field trips.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective is to look into the history of the fashion industry and the world behind the glamorous catwalks and shiny magazines. It aims to analyse fashion from a business history perspective, to look for similarities and differences with other industries. After completing the minor, students should have a wide-range knowledge and critical understanding of the historical, business, economic dimensions of fashion and of the particularities of fashion products, businesses, and intermediaries.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: During the past decades, advances in information technology (IT) have fundamentally altered essential aspects of our society, our economy, and our individual lives. The Internet and digital technologies in general have radically impacted our personal and professional routines and challenged our perception of physical and social boundaries, of distance and speed, of how we want to live, work, learn, communicate, compete, collaborate, and socialize. The verdict is still out on whether digital technologies isolate us or brings us closer together, whether they provide a voice to the marginalized or help to suppress them, whether they bring about prosperity for the many or only for the few. Business plays a critical role in answering these questions since it is both, fundamentally affected by digital change and a main driver of the same. Traditional industries often struggle to adapt to this changing environment, with their business models being disrupted by new, agile competitors. Evidence can be found in the multitude of startups transforming a variety of sectors, such as energy, mobility, health, and finance. At the same time, the past decade has brought about a new set of platform-based business giants, including Google, Apple, Uber, Airbnb, and Amazon, which dominate the public discourse surrounding digitalization and raise new questions related to power and regulation in a digital world.

This course, Business Information Management acquaints students with the role of information technology in today’s economy and society. On the one hand, it provides a varied perspective on central discourses related to digitalization, such as the power of digital platforms, the boost digital technologies provide for the exchange of knowledge and ideas, but also the threat that a lack of regulation may pose. On the other hand, the course equips students with an understanding of digital technologies and with basic skills in algorithmic thinking, database management, and modelling required to thrive in today’s workplaces and academic programs. The course is offered by the Business Information Management group of RSM’s Department of Technology and Operations Management.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Discuss the evolution of digital technologies and current technological trends.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today’s volatile, uncertain, complex and ambiguous (VUCA) business environment the challenges of strategy development and implementation are greater than ever before. This course teaches you a new approach to strategic decision making to motivate and mobilize stakeholders to achieve the business’s overarching goals, such as making a profit and delivering on people- and planet-related objectives.

The course consists of 6 sessions. Articles, book chapters, case studies and (short) videos help you prepare for the sessions. In the sessions you work on real-world cases and exchange insights. Your skills are tested by means of an individual exam based on a case.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completing this course, students should be able to:
1.    Analyze present strategic problems and opportunities at the business level
2.    Create, evaluate and make decisions about strategic options for addressing these present issues
3.    Create an implementation plan for a business strategy
4.    Appraise foresighted strategic problems and opportunities at the business level
5.    Create, evaluate and make decisions about strategic options for anticipating these foresighted issues
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89037,2019,Business ethics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['MA de Kiewit, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The financial crisis has raised public discussion about ethical conduct in the corporate world. Ethics and compliance are now terms often used in the financial sector. The pressure for organizations to comply with laws and regulations and implement compliance measures to live up to ethical standards is ever-increasing. This course will provide knowledge on what business ethics means in practice for organizations, why it is important for financial professionals to know about ethics and compliance concepts and how behavior can be influenced towards both ethical and unethical behavior. Active participation in the course will help you preparing for the exam.

We discuss what is understood by the term “ethics” in the context of a business organization. In the lecture we take a behavioral (as opposed to a philosophical) approach in order to understand what factors influence human behavior in the daily operations of an organization. What influences people towards morally good or bad decisions? We discuss different examples of misconduct. We will look at important concepts that influence ethical behavior.

We will discuss several examples of ethical issues and compliance violations from the financial sector. We will use this to apply and deepen our knowledge gained in the first lecture on ethical concepts.
We will discuss examples on how to manage behavior. We will discuss the following questions:
»      How can we make employees comply with laws, regulations and guidelines?
»      What are the pitfalls of all these rules and controls?
»      How does an organization make the best use of governance instruments like a Code of Conduct and a whistleblowing procedure?

The articles as well as the slides and the discussions from the two lectures are part of the literature. The assessment will be a written multiple choice exam. The exam will be graded by either a “Pass” or a “Fail”.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After having followed this course students are able to understand important concepts of ethical behavior and how this knowledge can be used for managing conduct in an organization. After following this course students are better equipped to recognize the ethical pitfalls of dilemma situations within a working environment.</body>

column1: Het betreft een verdiepend vak, dat met name Europeesrechtelijk van aard is. Naast een aantal principes uit de Europese verdragen en richtlijnen komt de jurisprudentie over de BTW van het Hof van Justitie aan de orde, alsmede de ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de BTW en andere indirecte belastingen in Europa. Het vak vormt een aanvulling op het vak Omzetbelasting dat in de bachelorfase wordt aangeboden.
Voor elk college dienen de studenten twee stellingen te formuleren en daarover hun mening te vormen. Iedere stelling moet gemotiveerd worden met een tekst van circa 1 A4 (450 woorden).

Tijdens de colleges gaan de docenten nader in op de stellingen en de daarover gevormde meningen van de studenten. Het gemiddelde van de stellingen vormt 50 procent van het eindcijfer. Het schriftelijk tentamen vormt de overige 50 procent van het eindcijfer.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Beter en verdiepend inzicht verwerven in het Europese BTW-systeem in het bijzonder met betrekking tot specifieke en verdiepende deelonderwerpen.

• De vaardigheid ontwikkelen om dwarsverbanden te leggen en zelf met een deelonderwerp aan de slag te gaan, bijvoorbeeld voor het schrijven van een masterscriptie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Tijdens het vak Capita Aansprakelijkheidsrecht vergaart u kennis van diverse onderwerpen op het gebied van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht. Bij dit vak wordt voornamelijk gebruik gemaakt van gastdocenten; specialisten op het gebied van de te behandelen onderwerpen. Naast de colleges, waarin een actieve werkvorm centraal staat, zijn er ook masterclasses. Tijdens deze masterclasses bezoekt u steeds een organisatie (advocatuur/verzekeringsbranche) waar een van de onderwerpen uit het vak wordt uitgediept waardoor direct de uitwerking daarvan in de praktijk zichtbaar is.

De belangrijkste capita zijn structuur van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht, verjarings- en vervaltermijnen, beroepsaansprakelijkheid, werkgeversaansprakelijkheid, verkeersaansprakelijkheid, productaansprakelijkheid en overheidsaansprakelijkheid.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren en uiteen zetten.
• U kunt de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht toepassen op een feitencomplex.
• U kunt ten aanzien van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht een kritische houding aannemen, een standpunt innemen en in discussie gaan.
• U kunt op het gebied van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht ontwikkelingen signaleren, analyseren en (actualiteiten) bijhouden.
• U kunt verschillende leerstukken op het terrein van het civiele aansprakelijkheidsrecht analyseren, vergelijken, verbanden leggen en bepalen welke op een casus toegepast kunnen worden.
• U kunt de opgedane kennis van de belangrijkste capita op het terrein van het aansprakelijkheidsrecht omzetten in praktische kennis en u kunt daarbij de trends en ontwikkelingen signaleren.

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in verschillende specialisaties. Hieronder volgt een korte beschrijving van de Capita Selecta Transfer Pricing:

Tijdens de colleges staat het Transfer Pricing vakgebied centraal. Zo zullen wij tijdens de colleges uitgebreid stil staan bij de internationaalrechtelijke aspecten van Transfer Pricing, alsmede de Nederlandse implementatie van de Transfer Pricing regels, inclusief bijbehorende jurisprudentie. De Transfer Pricing discipline is volop in beweging. Tijdens de colleges zullen daarom ook de recente ontwikkelingen op het terrein van de Transfer Pricing aan bod komen.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. Iedere student moet in tweetallen een verhandeling schrijven en de essentie ervan presenteren gedurende maximaal 15 minuten. Daarnaast wordt elke student eenmaal aangewezen om een verslag van een van de bijeenkomsten te maken. Voor een nadere omschrijving wordt verwezen naar de brochures die per Capita Selecta beschikbaar zijn op Canvas.</body>

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in verschillende specialisaties. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de capita selecta Caribisch fiscaal recht:

Tijdens de colleges wordt ingegaan op het fiscale stelsel van de BES eilanden (Bonaire, Sint Eustatius en Saba) en ACS (Aruba, Curaçao en Sint Maarten). Aan de orde komen de staatkundige vernieuwing van het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden, de directe en indirecte belastingen, formeel belastingrecht, belastingrechtspraak in het Caribisch gebied, tax incentives (tax holiday, e-zone), internationale aspecten (verdragen, BRN, BRK, verhouding met EU), misbruik van offshore vennootschappen (Panama leaks, 'Ultimate Beneficial Owner'), tax haven en ethiek. Daarnaast wordt een uitstap gemaakt naar het fiscale stelsel van Suriname.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

column1: De Capita Selecta Fiscaal Recht valt uiteen in vijf specialisaties. Hieronder een korte beschrijving van de capita selecta Van eenmanszaak tot internationaal concern:

De cyclus van 16 colleges wordt begonnen met verschillende aspecten die van belang zijn voor familievennootschappen behandeld. Daarbij gaat het om zowel civielrechtelijke als fiscaalrechtelijke aspecten. Onderwerpen die daarbij aan de orde komen zijn: bedrijfsopvolging in de inkomstenbelasting en vennootschapsbelasting, de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteit voor de schenk- en erfbelasting, het creëren van holdingstructuren, horizontaal toezicht en tax assurance, ethiek en renteaftrekbeperkingen.

Met betrekking tot het internationale deel van deze capita zullen de volgende onderwerpen behandeld worden: Inbound en outbound investeringen, het begrip vaste inrichting, winstallocatie, ethiek, doorstromers, immigratie en emigratie aanmerkelijkbelanghouder, transfer pricing, misbruik van belastingverdragen, fiscale aspecten van grensoverschrijdende werknemers en hybride entiteiten, belastingconcurrentie, staatssteun, BEPS/ATAD en belastingheffing in de digitale economie. De focus bij deze onderwerpen ligt op het internationale concern.
De hoorcolleges worden verzorgd door gastdocenten uit het bedrijfsleven, de belastingadviespraktijk, de rechterlijke macht, de belastingdienst, ministeries, etc.

Voor de Capita Selecta geldt dat de deelnemers maximaal tweemaal afwezig mogen zijn. Tevens wordt actieve participatie verlangd. column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Het verzekeringsrecht staat niet op zichzelf. Er wordt altijd ""iets"" verzekerd en dat ""iets"" kan met vele juridische deelgebieden verweven zijn. Verzekering vervult in onze moderne samenleving met alle daaraan verbonden kansen en risico's ook een onmisbare rol in het veilig stellen van de sociale zekerheid voor het individu. Dat maakt het verzekeringsrecht tot een boeiend onderdeel van het recht. Het betekent ook dat kennis van het verzekeringsrecht niet alleen onmisbaar is voor juristen die in de verzekeringsbranche zelf werkzaam (willen) zijn of bijvoorbeeld in de advocatuur de belangen van verzekeraars vertegenwoordigen. In feite loopt iedereen die in een juridische functie (rechterlijke macht, bedrijfsleven, overheid) werkzaam is, de kans met verzekeringsrechtelijke vraagstukken te worden geconfronteerd; zoals dat ook privé het geval is. Ook maken meerdere Masterclasses deel uit van het vak. In het kader van deze Masterclasses zullen meerdere advocatenkantoren, verzekeraars en/of assurantiemakelaars worden bezocht. Tijdens deze Masterclasses staan onderwerpen centraal die in het onderwijs aan de orde zijn.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: In this series of lectures we introduce three debates of Inequality: (A) inequality within nations; (B) inequality between nations and (C) the justification of inequality. The international gap of wealth between rich and poor nations, as well as the domestic gap in wealth within nations is among the most important issues of contemporary political debates. When did those gaps emerge? What was their historical cause? How did historians, economists and sociologists in the past (Marx, Weber, Adam Smith) debate these issues? And what about contemporary historians and economists, like Piketty, Sen and Hajoon Chang? What is the role and importance of institutions, states, culture, colonialism and capitalism in explaining differences of inequality?

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Students learn how economic inequality is labelled by sociologists, historians and economist in the past as well as in contemporary times. They recognize various research methods, assumptions and theories of capitalism. They learn to reflect on academic debates on the origin of capitalism and inequality. At the end of the course the students are able to write an independent written essay and reflect in an academic way on the origins of capitalism and inequality in a particular well defined historical case.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Causal identification is critical to the testing of theoretical relationships in organizational science. This course is designed to provide an understanding of methodological concepts as well as skill in apply various analytical techniques for causal identification. As such, the main objective of this course is for students to develop the research skills related to causal inference and identification.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90453,2019,Causal Inference,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,[],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Building on the foundations of causal inference, we will review 4-5 major research designs in the quantitative social sciences.  We will cover regression discontinuity, differences-in-differences, instrumental variables and synthetic control. Time permitting, we will also cover matching.  As much as possible, I will take the audience to the frontier knowledge through lecture and empirical exercises.
(The lecturer of this course is Dr Scott Cunningham from Hankamer School of Business, Baylor University.)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The field of causal inference has come into its own and continues to expand at a rapid pace.  It is a field which aims to identify the causal effect of environmental factors, such as policies or education, on events occurring in a person’s life, such as violence, educational attainment, or income. The purpose of this workshop is to bring the audience up to the frontier of this field through lectures and hands-on empirical exercises.

The foundation of contemporary causal inference methods is the counterfactual tradition which dates back to philosophical work by John Mill and David Lewis, statistical work by Jerzy Neyman, behavioral work by Don Rubin, computer science work by Judea Pearl, and numerous applied researchers such as Josh Angrist, David Card and Alan Krueger.  I break down the counterfactual tradition into two distinct lectures: a lecture on the potential outcomes framework, and a lecture on causal models and directed acyclical graphical models.

This is an applied course and most of the mathematics required is nonparametric and/or regression based.  A basic understanding of OLS regression is helpful. Empirical exercises will be in Stata as that is my comfort level, but as much as I can, I will provide the audience with R code if that is their preference. My hope is that the workshop will provide guidance, skill and confidence to use these methods in one’s own research.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In addition to formulating a competitive strategy that leverages a firm`s competencies, it is also important to update the strategy in response to technological developments. The fast pace of innovation require firms to constantly upgrade their product and service offerings to remain competitive and be ambidextrous: firms should not only focus on exploiting their existing capabilities, but also on developing new and complementary competencies. Two important skills to strategically change a business is to deploy existing competencies in innovative ways, and to locate and benefit from external knowledge that will facilitate new innovations. This course allows students to acquire relevant knowledge about navigating an increasingly complex innovation landscape and to practice it through case discussions and group exercises.

Each session consists of a lecture based on selected journal articles related to the theme of the session, and a discussion of a real-life case to allow the application of research insights to actual business situations. Your contributions in the form of questions, arguments, and examples are essential to create a rich and interactive learning environment. Students are expected to prepare the assigned material prior to each class to be able to be able to contribute to the interactive classroom discussions as well as being able to complete in-class group exercises.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: •    To identify new business models to leverage the core competencies of a firm in innovative ways;
•    To appraise the value of external knowledge for innovation and identify appropriate sources for valuable external knowledge;
•    To define a firm`s innovation ecosystem and describe the role of complementary external parties in developing innovative products and services;
•    To distinguish between exploration and exploitation and evaluate the role of each in enhancing competitiveness through innovation.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88492,2019,Charter Parties & Bills of Lading,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. FL Stevens', 'dr. J Constantino Chagas Lessa']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Merchant vessels are meant to make money for their owners. Very often, ship owners do that by renting out their ships (with or without a crew) to other parties that have a use for that ship. A general term for such contracts is 'contract of affreightment'. Within that general category, there are two main types of contracts: charter parties on the one hand, bills of lading on the other hand.

This course first looks at charter parties, which exist in different varieties (mainly bareboat, time and voyage charter parties). The rights and obligations of the charterer and of the ship owner are studied.

In the second part of the course, Bills of Lading are studied. A Bill of Lading can be issued under a charter party, but can also be (evidence of) a contract of carriage on its own. Bills of Lading are very important in international trade and for the financing of such trade. The course will look at the nature and characteristics of the Bill of Lading as a document of title, and will look at the rights and obligations of the parties to a contract of carriage under a Bill of Lading.

Carriage of goods by sea is often governed by international conventions such as the Hague (Visby) Rules, the Hamburg Rules and the Rotterdam Rules, which have a major impact on those rights and obligations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Over the past 30 years, psychologists and economists have gained deeper insight into consumer choice, including the non-economic features of the environment that can influence people’s choices (e.g., whether a policy component is the default). Many of these insights have challenged the traditional assumption that people make choices primarily in a rational, self-interested manner. This research program, often called behavioural economics, has provided novel insight into how people deviate from “optimal” choices and the consequences of these “sub-optimal” choices.

Because these “irrational” or “sub-optimal” decision strategies often generate choices that have a negative impact on society, business, government policy, the environment, and consumer welfare, it is important that you as (future) business leader a) understand the basic principles of consumer choice and b) have the best tools in your toolbox to implement strategies that will guide consumers toward preferable, sustainable, and healthy choices (dubbed nudging). Doing so will not only help you obtain and retain satisfied customers, it will also help you ensure your company runs smoothly, as you and the other members of your team will be better decision makers.

Although there may be some overlap with contents typically seen in marketing courses on communication and advertising, the Choice Architecture course provides a substantially different approach to understanding and changing consumer choice. Specifically, the current course will draw primarily from behavioural economics research, will be geared towards making sustainable choices at the individual, business, and societal levels, and will be aimed at developing choice-intervention strategies that can be implemented in a wide variety of contexts: one-on-one negotiations, team organization, risk management, policy design, among others, as well as more classic communication arenas such as social marketing.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: Enable you (as a future business leader) to design and implement effective choice interventions that benefit the company, consumer, and/or society in a wide variety of arenas including social marketing, policy design, risk management, negotiation, organization of teams, among others. This will be accomplished by building on the toolbox that standard economics provides for influencing behaviour with insights from state of the art behavioural science research, particularly behavioural economics. You will design several consumer-choice interventions based on insight from this course.

Improve the quality of your own judgments and decisions. We will study some important individual and group decision errors that are particularly important for real world problems and have easy-to-implement solutions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

An industry, a media and an art, cinema is mostly enjoyed as a form of entertainment. Studying movies, unlike literature or painting, is often seen as a waste of time and an anomaly in higher education. Yet, the power of cinema to convince, to move audiences, and to provide influential stories should be carefully studied. This course will use several movies to understand their social significance, and how societies have replaced ancient mythologies with modern images.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 60. This course has mandatory lectures.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Using a combination of case studies and film history, Cinema and Society intends to help students appreciate cinema and its effects on societies. Movies from different eras and societies will be used to provide students with a better understanding of cinema.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87137,2019,Cinemas in Context,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EF Augé'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Each week in “Cinemas in Context”, a different movie will be analyzed to understand its roots, context, place in pop culture, and future in high culture. Focus will be on movies able to create their own universe, hence the subtitle “Deep universes”. Using a combination of students’ research, lecturing and tutoring, the seminar aims to contribute to a better understanding of cinema from an academic and artistic point of view. At the end of the seminar, students will be able to understand several movies’ universes provided in the curriculum, along with some they will choose themselves.
Note: The minimum number of participants is 6, the maximum number is 25

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>""Cinemas in Context: Deep Universes"" intends to contribute to the understanding of film studies by exposing students to in-depth research in cinema as an art and an expression of culture.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87450,2019,Circular Economy,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['DMPE den Held, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
With the Circular Economy elective, you are taking the next step in sustainability strategies.
Where most sustainability strategies today still focus on reducing a company’s negative footprint, in this course we will also look at making a pósitive footprint.

Academically, this can be referred to as ‘regenerative sustainable development’. For business it means: instead of adding a burden to doing business as usual, we’re implementing a positive agenda to company strategies, business partnerships and customer relationships.

An exiting and existing example is paint that cleans the air (produced by AkzoNobel), and during this course, we will look at several other examples in the market today and discuss concepts for the future. We will look into the business benefits ánd obstacles of implementing these alternative project and/or company strategies.

Would you prefer to make a great business out of contributing to society and the environment, rather than just postponing the damage a company has on the environment or people? Then you are welcome to step into the Triple Top Line paradigm; the core of our theories and practice.
You are happily invited to step forward with a daring proposal for your roadmap assignment, fiery debates in the lectures and bold ideas during the exercises.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: Work with the Triple Top Line. You will not only learn and discuss the theoretic fundaments, but also actively practice it.
Implement the Triple Top Line in a company and/or project with a TTL ambitions text, TTL goals, transitional goals and a (strategic) roadmap.
You will go through this in exercises and work out an example in your individual assignment.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: More and more people are on the move, leaving their home due to economic, environmental, political or safety considerations, in search of a better life prospect. Leaving their place of origin can be voluntary or forced; caused by a variety of push and/or pull factors. Many of those affected move to cities, either staying within their country of origin or crossing the border(s) to another country.

The number of people affected is staggering and on the rise: according to UNHCR (2018), worldwide there are 68.5 million people forcibly displaced, of whom 40 million are Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), 25.4 million are refugees, and 3.1 are asylum seekers; more than fifteen million people a year are estimated to be displaced due to development (Cernea, 2008), and a growing number of people are displaced due to rural expulsions caused by land grabbing and climate change (Sassen 2014).

All these people on the move have an impact on the place of departure but more importantly on the places of arrival, being mostly the major and secondary cities. Whereas some cities have shrinking populations, many cities’ population is growing rapidly; all these movements are influencing urbanization patterns. This creates frictions as well as opportunities, which in this course will be looked at from social, economic, spatial and gender perspectives. Different responses on how to capture the gains and address the negative aspects of urban residential mobility dynamics exist and will be assessed during the course.

column2: • Processes of change and issues of integration and inclusion
• Spatial implications for departing and arrival cities

column1: 3. Guiding urban mobility dynamics (using case studies)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After the module, participants should be able to:

column2: • Describe current migration dynamics, at a global, regional and local level
• Critically reflect on implications of migration on sustainable & inclusive urban development
• Assess different governance responses and their relevance in a specific context
• Argue and debate a position statement (debate skills)

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87498,2019,Clean Tech Business Study (Intellectual Property),Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. HM Gubby, barrister']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This module deals with intellectual property (IP). It introduces students to the various forms of IP and then focuses on patents, as acquiring patent protection is the most expensive form of IP protection. A patent is often a substantial investment for start-ups and small companies.

In this master elective, RSM students work together with technical students from the University of Delft. Their aim is to develop a business plan for a sustainable invention. For many students, this is the first time they have had to consider the IP implications of an actual product or process. This module combines IP theory with practice. It raises awareness of IP issues and is immediately relevant for students regarding the invention they are working on.

column2: • This course is linked to the TU Delft course Clean Tech Business Study (MOT9515) ) offered by Delft Centre for Entrepreneurship. More details on this course will be published on:
• No previous knowledge is required for this course. However, students are recommended to read the overview of IP basics provided on Canvas before the lectures.

column3: • An overview of all the different forms of IP – patent, copyright, design rights, trademarks and secrecy;
• A review of patent law basics to assess the patentability of an invention and how patent claims work and are interpreted;
• A review of 10 classic IP mistakes commonly made by entrepreneurs.

column2: • The workload consists of 2 lectures of 3 hours each, reading the designated articles and producing a group assignment.
• Course structure:  2 lectures of 3 hours each. Delft and RSM students may also consult with the lecturer on IP matters that arise in the course of their business plan.
• Attendance at the lectures is compulsory. The lectures combine theory and several practical exercises.
• There is a group assignment based on a case. This assignment must be uploaded before the end of the RSM block 3.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
More details on this course will be published on:
·         To identify all forms of IP that might be relevant to their invention.
·         To be aware of and understand the legal issues that can arise when seeking to protect an own invention or when using the IP of others.
·         To have a basic understanding of patent law, thereby knowing when patenting is an option and when not.
·         To recognize and avoid the typical and common mistakes entrepreneurs make with respect to IP.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87574,2019,Climate change strategy roleplay,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SP Kennedy'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Climate change is one of today’s most pressing issues, receiving international attention from political leaders, corporations, the media, advocacy groups, and the general public. In the future, it is likely to become even more pressing as the effects of climate change intensify resource competition, natural disasters, disease vectors, water and food scarcity, and refugee migration.

According to Sir Nicholas Stern, former chief economist of the World Bank, the impact of climate change is likely to change the international business environment dramatically. However, the business relevance of climate change is insufficiently understood by future decision makers in international management and society.

We believe that tomorrow’s business leaders should be educated on the key elements of climate change – the science, the evolving policy, and role of business. They can become an essential part of the solution, but only if equipped with a sound understanding of the challenges at hand and the processes by which new policies are constructed.

The Climate Change Strategy course and its Model United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) form an innovative educational approach to closing this knowledge gap. Our goal is to broaden students' understanding of climate change, climate policy, and their impacts on the future of business.

The course modules deal with the core issues of climate change and include a wide range of effective didactic tools and exercises.  Students are given a deeper understanding of the background and consequences of climate change for business, and of corporate responses to it. Special emphasis is laid on international and national regulatory frameworks, and on emerging resource challenges and market opportunities.  Furthermore the course will provide students with an opportunity to develop a broad set of personal skills such as negotiation, forming strategy, research, public speaking and debating.

The 2019 edition of the course will be simultaneously offered at eight leading CEMS universities and culminates in a two-day UNFCCC simulation event at one of the business schools (TBC – host will not be RSM). Students will be using the recent Paris Agreement created at COP21 and be simulating the upcoming COP23 to be held in Asia.  Negotiations will seek to enhance the current Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) of countries and work out details of how the new mechanisms and funds will function.  The big challenge is how to improve the current commitments to be in line with the universally agreed target of limiting global temperature rise to ‘well-below 2 degrees’.

Students will negotiate on issues such as mitigation of greenhouse gases (new voluntary targets, financing and compliance), adaptation to climate change (financing, climate change refugees, technology transfer), and market mechanisms (sustainable development mechanism, REDD+, aviation and shipping).
Example blog of the Role Play in 2016, written by the fictitious media team: https://unfcccnegotiations2016.wordpress.com
UN Principles of Responsible Management Education (PRME) LEADERS+20 Competition Top 10 Placing for the course:
News articles about the 2016 Model UNFCCC at RSM:
This course assumes no prior knowledge of climate change or of climate change policy.  The course is divided into four modules:

column2: • Module 1 gives an extensive introduction to the topic of climate change and climate policy and will include a guest lecture from a notable climatologist.
• Module 2 will highlight the role of business in climate change and will include guest speakers from industry, management consultancy and the non-profit sector.

• Module 3 prepares students for the role-play including negotiation skills training.  Students gain insights in negotiation theory and acquire skills of looking beyond positions to the underlying interest of a party.
• Module 4 consists of the two-day simulation at one of the business schools with all participating universities.

column1: Midterm, roles for the negotiation simulation will be assigned to all students. In line with the innovative three-sector approach of this course, each student will either represent a government delegate, a non-governmental organization or a lobbyist from industry. This approach aims to provide experience not only in inter-governmental debate of climate change issues, but also in the way civil society and business interests can influence these discussions.
Fisher, R., Ury, W., and Patton B. (1991) Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreement Without Giving In, Boston: Houghton Mifflin.
Hoffman, A.  and Woody J. (2008) Climate Change: What’s Your Business Strategy? (Memo to the CEO), Harvard Business School Publishing.
Stern, N. et al (2006) Stern Review: The Economics of Climate Change, London, HM Treasury.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The participant is able to understand the negotiation process under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC).
• The participant is able to explain the roles and interests of the private sector, government and civil society in tackling climate change.
• At the end of this module the participant is able to evaluate business strategies for climate change.
• The participant is able to construct a progressive business strategy for climate change.
• At the end of this module the participant is able to distinguish strategies for bilateral and multilateral negotiations.
• The participant is able to formulate a negotiation strategy for climate change negotiations.
• The participant is able to apply negotiation skills in an international negotiations setting.

column1: <body>The ability to communicate effectively is very important for many professional practitioners. Professional communication differs from normal communication in a number of ways, for example by using professional interviews. Professional interviews have a clear purpose and how the interview is led and carried out should be geared towards achieving that goal. Good problem clarification, for example, is a condition of a good professional therapy or advice session. Furthermore, the client can expect that a professional takes the greatest care in dealing with his or her personal problems, which can be very sensitive issues. A number of basic communication skills and a good basic attitude are needed in order to achieve this goal. So, the aim of this course is to improve the knowledge and skills required for effective communication. Theory and research on communication is reviewed and basic attitudes and basic interviewing skills are practised in role-plays. Note. This course is not about the clinical interview as a tool for diagnosing clients.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: The Clinical Communication Skills course will:

column5: Help you gain insight into the processes in counselling a person with a request for help.
Help you gain insight into and knowledge of the Van der Molen, Lang, Trower & Look (2014) interview model and how to use this model
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the concrete skills needed to help a person with a problem
Increase your knowledge and understanding of the adequate use of these interviewing skills

Deepen your knowledge in cultural differences that exist between (counsellors and) clients in perceptions of mental illnesses and help you gain insight into the multicultural counseling competencies needed to help clients from different cultures.
