<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The WHO (Geneva, 2001) estimated that 450 million people will suffer from a mental or neurological illness at some point in their lives. That’s about 1 in every 4 people. Due to this 1 in 4 prevalence of mental illness, it is very likely that most of us know or have met someone who has been diagnosed with a mental illness. In this course, we’ll cover some of the main and more commonly occurring and diagnosed mental disorders as they appear in the DSM5. We’ll take a look at how these disorders are viewed from the traditional psychiatric perspective as well as how mental illness is viewed from other perspectives in the field of psychology, not only in terms of their causes, but also in terms of how they are described, understood and applied by practitioners in the field. By the end of the course, students will have gained an understanding of the scope of the field of clinical psychology, including how working in the field is not always as black and white as it may first appear.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: On completion of this course, students need to be able to:

column5: Have a basic understanding of the role of clinical assessment in the field of mental health

Know the basic documented history of mental illness and the field of clinical psychology, including the different models of understanding of mental illness and the causes of mental illness. Identify the diagnostic criteria for the specific disorders covered in the course (lectures and PBL activities)
Have and understanding of the DSM-5: it’s history, it’s organization and the main changes to the current edition, including the dimensional approach to mental illness diagnosis
Understand the diagnostic process and the concept of co-morbidity
Understand the role of culture in understanding and interpreting mental illness and mental health
Have a grasp of the overlap and differences between psychology and psychiatry

Develop a critical perspective on the field of clinical psychology, including having developed their own opinions (based on the course material) of what mental illness and mental health are, as well as what might distinguish abnormality from normality and how the field may or may nog contribute to stigma and discrimination

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85706,2019,Clinical Psychology: Anxiety and Stress,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. MJ Wieser'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Angststoornissen behoren tot de meest voorkomende psychiatrische stoornissen en kennen vele verschijningsvormen: zo zijn er de specifieke fobie, sociale fobie, paniekstoornis, agorafobie, gegeneraliseerde angststoornis, obsessief-compulsieve stoornis en de posttraumatische stress stoornis. De studenten zullen de verschillende angststoornissen van elkaar moeten kunnen onderscheiden. Daarnaast is het de bedoeling dat studenten het ontstaan van deze stoornissen kunnen verklaren: daartoe dienen ze niet alleen te beschikken over grondige kennis van algemene conditioneringprincipes, maar ook oog te hebben voor meer specifieke processen die bij iedere stoornis apart een rol spelen.

Stress is een belangrijk thema binnen de gezondheidspsychologie. In dit blok zal vooral worden stilgestaan bij de relatie tussen stress enerzijds en lichamelijke en geestelijke gezondheidsproblemen. Denk daarbij aan hart- en vaatziekten, kanker, en maagzweren, maar ook aan depressie en angststoornissen zoals de paniek- en de post-traumatische stress stoornis.

Studenten maken in dit blok kennis met persoonlijkheidsdiagnostiek. In dit blok oefenen de studenten met de Eysenck Personality Profiler (EPP). Verwacht wordt dat studenten zelf de EPP invullen, scoren, en hun profiel in verband brengen met normgegevens en een persoonsbeschrijving door een naaste. Tot slot dienen studenten hier op correcte wijze verslag van te leggen, waarbij er ook aandacht is voor zelfreflectie.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: De algemene doelstelling van dit blok is de aanwezige kennis van angststoornissen en stress te verdiepen en uit te breiden.
Specifiek kunnen de volgende doelen voor dit blok worden geformuleerd:

column5: Kennis hebben van biologische en psychologische processen die betrokken zijn bij stress en de ervaring er van.
Kennis hebben van de fenomenologie, de symptomatologie en de DSM-classificatie van de angststoornissen.
Kennis hebben van de etiologie van deze stoornissen.
Kennis hebben van de psychologische en farmacologische behandeling van angststoornissen.
In staat zijn om wetenschappelijke artikelen over psychische stoornissen kritisch te lezen en samen te vatten.
Kennis hebben van het interpreteren van een persoonlijkheidsvragenlijst aan de hand van normgegevens.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: De klinische psychologie richt zich op afwijkend, slecht aangepast of abnormaal gedrag dat door individuen zelf of hun omgeving als ongewenst wordt gezien. Men spreekt in dit verband ook wel van psychische, psychiatrische of psychopathologische stoornissen, of kortweg van psychopathologie. Deze stoornissen zijn veelal het resultaat van een samenspel van biologische, psychologische en sociale factoren. In aansluiting hierop houdt de klinische psychologie zich bezig met vraagstukken als 'Hoe ontstaan psychische stoornissen?', 'Hoe komt het dat ze blijven voortbestaan?', 'Welke verschillende stoornissen zijn er te onderscheiden?' en 'Op welke manieren kunnen psychopathologische stoornissen worden verholpen of voorkomen?'. Binnen dit blok gaan we in op de uiteenlopende verschijningsvormen van psychische stoornissen, op de theorieën over het ontstaan en voortduren van deze stoornissen en op de verschillende behandelingen en hun effectiviteit.
De kernvragen die gedurende het blok steeds weer aan de orde zullen komen zijn: waar ligt de grens tussen normaal en abnormaal, hoe ontstaat een stoornis en wat is er aan te doen?
Het blok is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het blok "Normaal of abnormaal?" gaat over afwijkend gedrag van mensen en     geeft     een     inleiding     in     het     vakgebied     van     de     klinische     psychologie.     Aan     de     hand     van     voorbeelden     uit     de     praktijk     worden     belangrijke     psychische     stoornissen     bestudeerd,     waaronder     angststoornissen,     eetstoornissen,     stemmingsstoornissen     en     psychotische     stoornissen.     Na     afloop     van     het     blok     kent     de     student     van     de     meest     voorkomende     stoornissen     het     klinisch     beeld     en     de     diagnostische     criteria,     de     theorieën     over     etiologie     alsmede     de     empirische     bevindingen     die     de     theorie     steunen     dan     wel     tegenspreken,     de     gangbare     therapieën     en     de     effectiviteit     daarvan.

column1: <body>In this course, which will be taught in Dutch, you will acquire the basic skills required to establish and lead a consultation as a physician. The course consists of two types of sessions that overlap Quads 1, 2, 3 and 4 of year 3: (1) Clinical reasoning (Klinisch redeneren, KR) and (2) Consultation (Consultvoering, CV). During the clinical reasoning sessions, you will learn how to make a diagnosis, after examining and analysing a patient’s complaints. You will learn what the importance is of knowing what kind of questions the physician should ask to obtain crucial and relevant information. In addition, you will learn which diseases can be the cause of a specific complaint, and how to make an accurate diagnosis by physical examinations and diagnostic tests. In the Consultation sessions, you will be able to practice the aforementioned skills. You will learn how to approach and interview patients, how to perform a physical examination, and how to interpret your findings. Due to the practical nature of the course, the assessment will be based mainly on practical exams performed in Quad 4.</body>

column1: This course spans the entire academic year – starting in quad 1 and ending in quad 4. During the course we come together for seven (7) sessions in a seminar setting (mixing ‘close reading sessions’ and ‘discussion’) and throughout the year you will read - from cover to cover - one of the major works by one of the pivotal thinkers in continental philosophy: Friedrich Nietzsche. You may have heard about him – and if you haven’t, you probably heard about one of his famous philosophical concepts (such as nihilism, God is Dead, the Last Man, the ‘Übermensch’, The Eternal Return of the Same, etc.). This year we read Nietzsche’s classic The Gay Science (org. 1882). Your final assignment will be a review essay.

column1: <body>Cognitive neuroscience studies the cognitive and neural basis for such diverse mental functions as perception, action, language, attention and memory. This relatively young discipline seeks to unravel the workings of the brain. What happens in our brains when we do what we do? How is this fascinating, unbelievably complex 'microcosmos' inside our skulls organised? How do those billions of nerve cells collaborate in an organ no bigger than half a football? Thanks to advanced brain-imaging techniques available today, scientists are able to observe the human brain in action, while animal studies provide an unsurpassed understanding of underlying mechanisms. As many already know, cognitive neuroscience is the discipline of the future.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: After completing this course, the student can

column5: apply knowledge about basic neuroscience anatomy and physiology;
relate cognitive phenomena to biological processes;
distinguish the different forms of memory and their biological basis;
describe the neurological processes involved in sleep/waking transition
describe the hierarchy in decision making and its biological basis;
describe the mechanisms behind overt and covert attention;
describe the neural mechanisms behind emotions;
relate evolutionarily primitive neural reward mechanisms to human sexual behaviour
conduct behavioural experiments in a cognitive neuroscience context;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: We have nearly 8 billion people on earth, and all of us think. But why do we think? How do we think? And what happens if we stop thinking?

This course explores the answers to these profound questions. It will go further than the course ‘Brain & Behaviour’ as it will introduce concepts like schemas, mental imagery, categorisation and language, to understand how the content of thoughts are established. Furthermore, this course delves into memory and attention. In addition, it will introduce the study of complex thinking abilities, such as problem solving, reasoning and decision making, and looks at the deterioration of cognitive processes: What happens if we are unable to think properly?

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85697,2019,Cognitive Psychology: Thinking and Remembering,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['G Korkmaz, MSc', 'prof.dr. RA Zwaan']",,"Inhoud

Menselijke cognitie kan beschouwd worden als een snelle weg waarlangs wij ons aan veranderende omstandigheden in onze omgeving aanpassen, naast de tragere methoden van genetische mutatie en (operant) leren. Hoe helpt aandacht ons efficiënt met de informatie uit onze externe en interne omgeving om te gaan, en wat gebeurt er als aandacht faalt? Kennis en kennisrepresentatie vormen een tweede thema. Relevante vragen daarbij zijn: op welke wijze beelden wij informatie uit onze omgeving innerlijk af en hoe gebruiken we de kennis bij het interpreteren van de wereld om ons heen? De structuur en het functioneren van onze geheugens is een derde onderwerp. Hoe wordt informatie onthouden voor de korte en lange termijn? Wat gebeurt er als we herinneringen ophalen? Het laatste thema betreft redeneren en denken. Zijn er wetmatigheden te onderkennen in ons redeneren? Hoe denkt de expert en hoe de beginner in een bepaald domein?

Het blok biedt een introductie in de centrale onderwerpen van de     cognitieve     psychologie.     Hierbij     spelen     cognitieve     processen     als     begrijpen,     kennisverwerving     en     kennisrepresentatie,     aandacht,     herinneren,     denken,     en     probleemoplossen     een     centrale     rol.     Studenten     maken     kennis     met     het     klassieke     model     van     het     informatieverwerkende     systeem     dat     aan     deze     processen     ten     grondslag     ligt.

column5: In dit blok komen de meest recente neurowetenschappelijke theorieën en bevindingen op het gebied van aandacht, executieve functies, emoties, en motoriek aan bod. De lokalisatie, lateralisatie en organisatie van de verschillende hersenfuncties zullen worden behandeld. Ook wordt aandacht besteed aan de gehanteerde technieken, variërend van diermodellen tot humaan beeldvormend onderzoek zoals bijvoorbeeld met functionele MRI. Tevens zal worden ingegaan op de praktische toepassing van deze neurowetenschappelijke methoden en bevindingen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus beoogt studenten dieper kennis te laten maken met de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie: modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit. Studenten maken kennis met verschillende hedendaagse toonaangevende discussies binnen deze vier thema’s, en leren reflecteren op diverse prominente onderzoeksproblemen.

Aan de hand van deze verdieping in de centrale thema’s van de sociologie, wordt aandacht besteed aan de vertaalslag van sociologische theorie naar empirie. De student leert hoe puzzels binnen de thema’s modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit kunnen worden onderzocht met behulp van empirisch onderzoek. Naast het behandelen van voorbeelden van empirisch onderzoek binnen deze vier thema’s, leren studenten hoe ze zelf theoretische begrippen kunnen aanwenden voor de formulering van empirisch toetsbare vragen of verwachtingen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • De student maakt zich prominente sociologische theorieën rondom de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie eigen: modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit.
• De student is in staat om centrale begrippen binnen de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie te beschrijven en toe te passen op hedendaagse maatschappelijke vraagstukken.
• De student maakt kennis met voorbeelden van empirisch onderzoek binnen de vier hoofdthema’s en leert onderzoeksartikelen kritisch te bestuderen.
• De student beschikt over het vermogen om zelf sociologische theorieën te gebruiken om empirische verschijnselen te duiden.
• De student is in staat om empirisch toetsbare vragen en verwachtingen te formuleren op basis van sociologische theorieën over modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit.
• Bachelor-3 studenten maken een additionele schrijfopdracht (ter grootte van 1,5 ECTS).

column1: <body>Combinatorial optimisation deals with finding an optimal solution from a finite set of feasible solutions. Since enumerating this set is practically infeasible in general, one tries to exploit the problem structure to find an optimal solution in a computationally efficient way. In this course, we develop techniques for combinatorial optimisation problems. These techniques include:

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To recognise and model combinatorial optimisation problems as integer programming problems.
• To understand the basic theory and techniques to solve combinatorial optimisation problems.
• To master the basic techniques to solve combinatorial optimisation problems.
• To be able to implement the basic solution techniques in a software package.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85874,2019,Combinatorisch optimaliseren,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. W van den Heuvel', 'MA van Zon, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: De combinatorische optimalisering houdt zich bezig met het vinden van een optimale oplossing uit een eindige verzameling van toegelaten oplossingen. Omdat volledige enumeratie van deze verzameling vaak onpraktisch is door het zeer grote aantal toegelaten oplossingen, probeert men gericht te zoeken naar een optimale oplossing door gebruik te maken van de aanwezige structuur. In dit college worden oplossingsmethoden voor combinatorische optimaliseringsproblemen behandeld. Technieken die worden behandeld zijn:

column5: Branch-and-bound
Lagrange relaxatie
Maximum stroom algoritme
Hongaarse methode
Dynamisch programmeren

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: Het herkennen en modelleren van combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen als discrete optimaliseringsproblemen.
Het begrijpen van de basistheorieën en -technieken om combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen op te lossen.
Het beheersen van de basistechnieken om combinatorisch optimaliseringsproblemen op te lossen.
In staat zijn de basisoplossingstechnieken toe te passen in een softwarepakket.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87878,2019,Commercial Contracts,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr.dr. JLE Vannerom', 'prof.mr. FGM Smeele', 'prof.mr.dr. HN Schelhaas']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course unravels the multiplicity of commercial contracts underlying international trade. It offers students an insight in the fundamentals of a commercial contract. Despite the differences between these contracts in the contract chain, each commercial contract contains - to a large extent - similar clauses or types of clauses (e.g. on hardship and frustration, on the exclusion of liability, on damages, on confidentiality and arbitration & dispute resolution, etc). A first part will thus focus on:

column2: • precontractual information duties (including NDA and confidentiality clauses) and the principle of good faith;
• contract formation (validity of the contract, mistake and fraud);
• contractual obligations: limitation of liability and contractual remedies;
• multi-party transactions: the relativity of contract and the techniques of assignment, novation and (contractual) subrogation;
• typical clauses in long-term agreements such as the right to set-off, hardship and frustration; and

column1: In the course’s second part we turn our eye to some specific contracts. The focus lies with the sale of goods contract; agency, distribution and franchise agreements.
As it is vital to learn the basics of contract drafting, this course also offers students a workshop and an assignment dedicated to helping them develop the legal skills of contract drafting.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with the different types of contracts and contractual clauses that underlie international trade.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87507,2019,Commodity Trade and Supply Networks,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['WAA Jacobs'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Commodities are critical in the global economy as they literally power the world, feed the planet and provide the essential inputs in all the devices (e.g. smartphones) and household appliances (e.g. shampoo) that make our lives easy. Commodity trading involves the transformation of commodities in time (through storage), space (through shipping) and form (through processing). Commodity trading firms (CTFs) such as Vitol, Trafigura and Cargill are for a large part responsible for the supply and delivery of commodities to their clients, often large manufacturing firms, in which they take upon (and offset) various forms of risks (e.g. price volatility, geopolitics, the weather, foreign currency exchange and operational risks such as delay in delivery) for their clients. Commodity trading thus involves highly dynamic information-intensive tasks and capabilities in the field of logistics, finance and technology.

No better place to study this than in Rotterdam: Europe’s gateway for the global trade in physical commodities. Rotterdam forms the heart of the ARA-region (Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp), a global price reference point for crude oil and used as geographical benchmark in many commodity delivery contracts and freight prices. Commodity traders make use of the port to ship the commodities to markets and many have actual logistical assets (tank storage and warehouses) and processing operations (i. c. refineries)  in the port in addition to the trade desks, supply chain support functions, head offices or holdings in the city.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is to provide a clear understanding of the important role that commodity traders play in global supply chains and to gain both hard analytical skills and soft skills required to work in dynamic, multinational commodity trading operations.
After the course, students should be able to:
1.    Understand worldwide supply and demand patterns of the most important commodity product groups (energy, metals/minerals, agriculturals)

2.    Comprehend the way commodity markets (physical and derivative) function and the role that commodity trading firms play in the worldwide physical delivery of commodities, including contracting, financing and shipping.
3.    Comprehend the various forms of risks involved in commodity trading and how these can be mitigated.
4.    Analyze specific commodity markets and synthesize these analyses into (short term) trading strategies and (long term) strategic decision-making
5.    Present analytical results to a professional audience.

The assessment consists of an individual assignment (essay), a group assignment (business case), and an individual written exam. The elective will be concluded with a College Tour-style meeting, in which students and business leaders will engage in thought provoking discussions.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90117,2019,Communicating (in)equality in the city,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. I Awad Cherit', 'Z Hammana, MSc']",,"Inhoud

According to the UN, half of the world population already lives in urban areas and by 2050 that number will be close to two-thirds. That more and more people are willing to concentrate in larger and larger cities, however, does not mean that they share similar living conditions. In cities across the world, power and (other) resources are unevenly distributed. Socio-economic divides, as well as differences linked to gender, race, and ethnicity have important consequences for people’s everyday experiences in/with the city and for their sense of belonging.

This course focuses on the key role of communication in sustaining and challenging these inequalities. The starting point is an acknowledgement that (economic) equality and (cultural) difference do not contradict each other; they go hand in hand. This means that socio-economic justice is not about everyone being the same, but about gender, ethnic, racial and other cultural differences being properly recognized and represented. Recognition and representation are communication rights: They enable social groups to have a fair say in society and in the distribution of its resources.

In the case of Rotterdam, consider, for example, how the city is drawn and labeled in tourist maps and business brochures, how “normal” Rotterdammers and/or “foreigners” look in public campaigns, how the city inhabitants and their problems are portrayed in the news. Consider as well what art deserves city funding and what is the local history taught in schools. Moreover, who gets to decide about these issues? What are the possibilities for marginalized groups to claim spaces for their ways of being Rotterdammers, their perspectives on the city and its history, their music?

In dealing with these issues—not only in relation to Rotterdam, but to cities around the world—the course strongly relies on students’ own background and experiences. It pays attention to both the local and the cross-national from an interdisciplinary and critical perspective</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: •            Communicative practices related to specific inequalities and efforts to contest them in contemporary urban spaces.
Students have developed the skills to:
•            Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.
•            Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered in the course to contemporary case studies and their own work.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87494,2019,Communicating Sustainability,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. SM Laasonen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Organizations are increasingly expected to communicate about the degree to which their operations and other activities are sustainable, in the sense of creating value for society. Communicating about sustainability involves a specialized area of activity that involves CSR-related communication and integrated reporting as well as community engagement. The overall aim of these activities for an organization is to signal and demonstrate its commitment to social and environmental issues and to build strong and lasting relationships with the local and global communities in which it resides and operates. However, in doing so, organizations often encounter obstacles, such as:

column2: an inherent skepticism toward large corporations, potentially leading to accusations of ‘greenwashing’
action groups using well-known organizations who portray themselves as ‘good citizens’ as easy targets for campaigns to highlight social issues (think of Nike and child labor)
sustainability communication getting ‘drowned out’ in a sea of other information
perceived trade-offs among stakeholder interests (e.g. an organization’s actions making customers more satisfied but employees less satisfied, or vice versa)

column1: How should companies deal with obstacles like these? The course explores the concepts of corporate citizenship, CSR and community relations, and details the nature and effectiveness of various communication strategies and tactics, ranging from integrated reports and stakeholder dialogue platforms to partnerships that address pressing community issues.

The course approaches the issue of sustainability through a corporate or organizational lens, concerned with the questions of when and how organizations should be vocal on sustainability issues in the media and in the public domain, of when and how they may best communicate about such issues to internal and external stakeholder audiences, and of how their communication may help foster strong relationships with local and global stakeholders.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of the course, students will have acquired:

column2: a detailed understanding of the role of communication in sustainability; including phenomena such as standard setting and moral entrapment, greenwashing, and integrated reporting;

practical skills in the use of communication theories and techniques, including framing, rhetoric and discourse, in communicating about sustainability and in garnering support for sustainability strategies.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87164,2019,Communication Ethics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AFM Krijnen', 'dr. AG Fokkema', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. E Huiberts', 'dr. EBR Timmermans', 'dr. M Scalvini', 'dr. WK McCarthy', 'prof.dr. MPA Bouman', 'TCTM Loudon']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will have a general understanding of 'ethics' for the media professional. They will be introduced to different perspectives in (social) philosophy with an emphasis on different modes of ethical reasoning. This understanding will enable the students to evaluate how well or how poorly standards in the field (e.g., professional ethics in journalism or public relations), are constructed and formulated. Students will not only be able to identify the ethical perspectives underlying these standards, but also to identify the different ethical argumentations implied within these. Through readings and class discussions connected to real life cases, students will be trained in ethical reasoning and form personal ethical underpinnings for their future careers.
Note: The lectures of this course are mandatory.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:

column2: • the cultural and historical diversity of ethical principles;
• ethical principles guiding professional ethical standards in the field of media and communication.
• critically examine and evaluate ethical principles guiding professional ethical standards in the field of media and communication;
• formulate and defend their own ethical principles and reflect on their own intercultural competencies.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87110,2019,Communication Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['DE Kiss, MA', 'dr. AMM Hermans', 'dr. L Zheng', 'dr. Y Wang', 'M Freire Machado, MSc', 'RS Rocha, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

T-mobile creates a YouTube viral video by capitalizing on the already viral flashmob videos online. Marc Jacobs gains a loyal following on Twitter through his personable tweets. KLM, designs a media campaign encouraging people to ‘stewardess’ themselves, gaining significant attention with well over 55,000 new fans on Facebook in just 7 days. Whether it is electronics, fashion non-profits, all companies and organizations seem challenged by new communications possibilities in the social media era. However, most are still experimenting with their communications and some are hesitant to adapt.

This course provides an overview and application of how companies and organizations are using social media. The course examines key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media marketing based on recent empirical findings, particularly in relation to social media and reputational risk, as well as social customer relationship management. In teams, students will focus on a particular theme and choose a particular company or organization. Then, applying their academic knowledge, they will conduct a practical consulting project. The course cumulates in a pitch to the company (in class) and a final written proposal using insights gained throughout the term. This workshop will be of interest to students keen on entering the private sector as consultants and communication specialists.
Note: This course is only open to IBCoM students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and an understanding of:

column2: • The management of social media communication and marketing within (international) companies and organizations
• The needs of a particular company or organization  and their concerns regarding social media
• Innovations and challenges in adopting social media strategies and campaigns
• Critically reflect upon international case studies and real-world social media management scenarios
• Develop a professional relationship with a company or organization
• Implement diverse methods of collecting and analyzing customer data
• Design and pitch a professional proposal for companies or organizations on their social media practices
• Effectively work in internationally diverse teams and identify key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media campaigns

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87098,2019,Communication Technologies and their Impacts,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AK van Eldik, MSC MA', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. EBR Timmermans', 'dr. IM Derda', 'dr. M Slot', 'dr. T De La Hera', 'IB Segers, MSc', 'RS Rocha, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The introduction and use of new communication technologies in society can never be told in just one story. It is a process of mutual shaping; society and technology influence each other, with   various outcomes, opportunities and impacts for different groups of people in various contexts. In   this course, we will look at the interplay between communication technologies and society. The course is both historical and thematic in nature and offers a critical exploration of (a selection of) cultural, social, political and economic impacts of various communication technologies on our society. Teaching methods involve a combination of lectures and tutorials. The lectures provide a guide to the subject matter and set out foundations on which students can build, while the tutorials stress active participation by the students and provide the opportunity for in-class assignments and discussion of key issues and optional topics.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The historical development of media and communication technologies in international perspective;
• Themes central to the study of new media and communication technologies;
• Social, political, cultural and economic impacts of new media and communication technologies and the forces shaping their development and use in different times and places.

column1: Students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication technologies;
• Formulate their own viewpoints and research questions, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The introduction and role of new communication technologies in society can never be told in just one story. It is a process of mutual shaping; society and technology influence each other, with various outcomes, opportunities and impacts for different groups of people in various contexts. In this course, we will critically reflect upon the interplay between communication technologies and society. The course is both historical and thematic in nature. Students will be trained to critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication technologies, and to formulate their own viewpoints, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings. Teaching methods involve a combination of lectures and tutorials.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87124,2019,Communication and International Relations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. EF Augé'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
As this is a seminar, personal input from the students is an essential part of the classes. The instructor will illustrate how mechanisms and issues related to communication in international

relations play a role in negotiations. We will put our acquired skills into practice by organizing large- scale simulations of negotiation. Students will also be required to focus on one aspect of communication in international relations that they would like to develop into a final paper.
The ultimate aim of the seminar is not theoretical, but practical: for participants to become better ‘international communicators’.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Conceptual frameworks and theories regarding communication in international relations
• Real-life issues, crisis communication strategies and conflict resolution attempts in international communication
• Critically review current research on international communication processes and practices
• Analyze and reflect on developments, issues and practices in various international communications settings

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87109,2019,Communication and Media Labour Market Orientation,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AE Mols', 'RN Mast, MA', 'RS Rocha, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Graduates of the IBCoM program can take on specialized communication jobs in a variety of fields, including marketing, management, sales, corporate communications, public relations, internal communications, government, public affairs, education, journalism, the media and entertainment industries, and the art world.

This course will help IBCoM students orient on the opportunities in these professional fields, in preparation for their internships (required in the second year of the program), and for the job market after they have graduated from the program. During the lectures, guest speakers from a variety of relevant fields will present their views on the labor market in communication and media and discuss the issues that they consider key to acquiring and fulfilling particular positions or internships in their field. In the tutorial meetings students will train and develop their skills to find and prepare for an internship or job relevant to their career goals.
Note: This course is only open to IBCoM students.
Students should have completed the course Communication and Media Practice (CM2008) before they may start with the internship (CM3040) in BA-2.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have knowledge and understanding and awareness of:

column2: • Labor market prospects and career opportunities for graduates in communication and media
• Internships opportunities for students in communication and media in the Netherlands and abroad
• Expectations and requirements of potential employers and internship providers in a variety of relevant fields
• Define their own career goals and learning objectives
• Orientate themselves on the (international) job and internship market
• Search for relevant job opportunities and internships in the Netherlands and abroad
• Develop an internship plan and otherwise prepare for their internship

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87105,2019,Communication and Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. A van Prooijen', 'dr. IM Derda', 'dr. R Mittal', 'dr. S Nguyen', 'dr. Y Wang', 'I Blum, MA', 'PH Le, MSC MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course, we will examine communication as it relates to organizations and organizing. The course will focus on the history, major theories, and contemporary issues and dilemmas of organizations in an international and globalizing environment. Topics covered are communication processes and structure, organizational culture, leadership, branding and identity, power, teamwork, and gender in organizations. Critiques of organizational communication systems, structures and theories are also presented.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The main theoretical approaches, perspectives and issues in the field of organizational communication;
• The role of communication in the functioning and performance of organizations;
• Processes of organizational communication in a multicultural and global environment.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of organizational communication
• To communicate their viewpoints clearly and constructively, both orally and in writing;
• Reflect on and improve their own competence in communicating in diverse organizational settings.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87225,2019,Communication and Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['AJ Coady, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course, we will explore communication within organisations. The course will focus on the major theories, issues and dilemmas of internal communication in an international environment. Topics covered are communication processes, effects of top-down communication, organisational culture, organizational identity, corporate ethics, internal branding, change management, conflict management and leadership. Effective communication in global organisations and critiques of organisation communication systems and structures are also presented.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of organizational communication
• Be able to apply the theory to a variety of organizational settings
• Be able to identify and distinguish between different perspectives from the field of organizational communication

A Paz Alencar', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. SMR Driessen', 'I Blum, MA', 'Q Huang']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course presents an overview of state-of-the art approaches to understanding media and communication as social forces. The first part of the course considers how media and communication feature in processes of major social change(s). It does so through the concept of mediatization, which approaches social, cultural, political and economic practices as increasingly organized around the workings and logic of the media. Case studies will illustrate how different fields and institutions are greatly affected by such media logic.

The second part of the course focuses on the different ways in which we can understand media and communication as technologies in governing the behavior of citizens in contemporary society. The course emphasizes current developments in media and communications in an international perspective to provide context and comparison. Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussions of student assignments and coursework.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The main theoretical perspectives and approaches to the study of the societal aspects and impacts of mediated communication;
• The social, political, cultural and economic impacts of media and the forces shaping their development and use in different times and places.
• Reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of mediated communication, drawing on relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings;

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87847,2019,Company Law and Restructuring,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. J Constantino Chagas Lessa', 'mr. GF Strietman', 'mr. H Koster', 'mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'prof.mr.dr. JH Even', 'prof.mr.dr. MA Verbrugh']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course has as general theme corporate restructuring in the internal market of the EU and concerns legal, economic as well as fiscal aspects. European company law has reshaped national company laws of the EU-member states. The course starts with the relevant aspects of European company law, including harmonization of company law, freedom of establishment, representation, supranational companies and the relevant aspects of European insolvency law, followed by legal, fiscal and economic aspects of national and cross border mergers & acquisitions. Further, different forms of corporate restructuring will be discussed during the lectures. Finally, aspects of European labour law, more specific, transfer of undertaking, will be dealt with.
The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases. Active participation and discussion of the students is expected and motivated.
If possible, students will be encouraged to attend a conference or a seminar on a relevant topic somewhere in The Netherlands.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Upon completion of this course the student has or is able to:
- thoroughly understand the meaning and significance of the harmonization program of company law in Europe and how national company law is influenced by it;
- independently analyze, assess and evaluate trends and developments of freedom of establishment for companies in Europe;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning representation;
- in-depth knowledge of the structure, characteristics and developments of supranational companies;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning national and cross border mergers and acquisitions;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning European insolvency law
- independently analyze and solve questions concerning relevant tax aspects of national and cross border mergers and acquisitions;
- independently analyze and solve legal questions concerning transfer of undertaking;
- work together in order to write an academic paper on a merger or acquisition;
- critically discuss the topics and literature of the course and to defend a formulated proposition in that respect.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87978,2019,Comparative Constitutional Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. NS Efthymiou', 'mr. SPM Wolf', 'prof.mr. R de Lange']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The idea underlying this course is to present constitutional law from a comparative perspective, in order to improve the knowledge of the student's national constitutional system. For that reason, not only constitutional texts will be compared and analyzed, but also specific features of constitutional systems, such as the separation of powers, judicial review (or the absence of judicial review), federalism and the protection of human rights. Special attention will be paid to the constitutional systems of the United Kingdom, Germany and France and the United States, which have served as a model for many twentieth-century constitutions.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Constitutional law has become increasingly important not only in the context of national legal systems, but also in an international context, as part of attempts to rebuild states that are in crisis or have become ‘failed states’ where stability and security are jeopardized, peaceful means of solving conflicts are under pressure and the rights of private citizens are not guaranteed. This course aims at increasing the familiarity of students with basic notions of constitutional law in various constitutional systems. Focus will be on a substantive theme – Democracy – and on method. Two recent books will be read with the students and discussed during class.
Students are expected to give a group presentation in which they link themes that are present in the books to constitutional questions that have arisen in their home country. There is an oral exam.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88773,2019,Comparative Health Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['C Carboni', 'dr. LE Oldenhof', 'dr. ME van Bochove', 'DV Ivanova, PhD', 'ES Graler', 'JFL van de Sande', 'prof.dr. HM van de Bovenkamp', 'prof.dr. I Wallenburg', 'prof.dr. RA Bal', 'TS van Dijk, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Why do countries which share many similarities, such as the USA and Canada, have such different healthcare systems? Why do healthcare policies often change incrementally, even when stakeholders in the governance of health care argue for immediate change? And why may healthcare policies that are successful in one country fail in another?

The course focuses on various actors in healthcare governance and adopts an institutional theory perspective. At the end of this course, students will be able to explain why countries have different or similar healthcare policies; why healthcare policy reform often proves to be difficult; and how, when and why institutional change takes place. Furthermore, students will be able to execute a comparative health policy analysis and to judge the possibilities for cross-country learning.
The paper assignment will determine 50% of the final course grade; the written exam makes up the other 50%. A minimum grade of 4.5 is required for the written exam.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The aim of the course Comparative Health Policy is to provide students with profound knowledge and skills in cross-national health policy analysis.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87995,2019,Comparative Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['prof.dr. FJM De Ly'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In this course some of the basic tenets of comparative law are dealt with. First, the focus is on classification and characteristics of the major legal systems in the world. Apart from the French, German and English systems, also non-European legal systems are discussed such as the United States. In addition, uniform law (including European harmonization) is analyzed (objectives, manifestations, instruments, uniform interpretation, organizations and coordination). Finally, the methodology of comparative legal research is discussed.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The objective of the course is to familiarize the participating students with the characteristics of the major legal traditions, with basic notions of uniform law (including European harmonization) and with the methodology of comparative law research.

After completion of the course, the student should have an understanding of the characteristics and structure of the major legal traditions and of uniform law. In addition, he should be capable of doing comparative legal research.
The student shall be assessed on the basis of knowledge or on the basis of the skill of writing a comparative law paper.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90475,2019,Comparative Public Policy,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. MKA Kniou'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: Comparative public policy has become an important field of study within the Policy Sciences more in general. By promoting the exchange of knowledge, expertise and ‘best practices’ across Europe it is also playing an important role in the process of Europeanization of public policies itself. Yet, comparative public policy faces many empirical, theoretical and methodological difficulties. To overcome such difficulties, this course develops a problem solving approach to the comparative study of public policies.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: At the end of the course, students:

column5: are able to discuss the difficulties as well as opportunities of comparative public policy for policy learning;
are familiar with the comparative dynamics of agenda setting;
can compare processes of policy implementation by looking at instrument choices and implementation styles;

are familiar with the design and execution of policy research from a comparative perspective and with instruments as international surveys, multi-case studies, benchmarking and best practices and use of international statistics

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Competition policy (also called ""antitrust policy"") is a term used broadly to describe intervention by public authorities to ensure competition in markets for goods and services. This course aims at making students familiar with the application of economic arguments in European competition law. Comparisons with U.S. antitrust law are included where appropriate for a better understanding of cases and the implications of legislation and court rulings on economic efficiency.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88772,2019,Competition in Health Care Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,['dr. AF Roos', 'dr. RGM Kemp', 'dr.ir. RCMH Douven', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following years of controls, rationing and expenditure caps, many countries introduce market-based health care reforms. Competitive interactions between health care providers and payers create incentives that affect market players’ behavior and the price, quality and quality of health care services. This is especially true in the United States, where the majority of total health expenditures are privately financed and prices, quantities and qualities for health care services are determined by market interactions. But competitive forces also shape strategic interactions in health care systems which are mostly publically financed and where prices are regulated (for example, the British NHS).

In this course, students are introduced to determinants of market structure, prices, quality, provider networks and competition in health insurance and provider markets. Unique attributes in health care not only affect the functioning of market-based health care systems, but also complicate competition enforcement. Therefore, competition (or: antitrust) enforcement in the health care sector is also extensively discussed.
The central aim of this course is to study:

column2: • the functioning and performance of competitive health care systems
• the use and adequacy of competition enforcement in health care
• the challenges related to competition (enforcement) in health care.

column1: To that end, the course introduces students to state-of-the-art concepts and literature in the field of industrial organization of health care markets.
The course consists of 12 meetings of 90 minutes with problem-based interactive lectures.
Some classes will be taught by guest teachers.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>The central aim of this course is to study:

column2: • the functioning and performance of competitive health care markets
• the role of EU competition law and its national counterparts in health care
• what theoretical and empirical challenges policymakers and antitrust agencies face, when introducing competition and applying competition law in health care

column1: By the end of this course the student is able to:

column2: • Evaluate the functioning and performance of competitive health care markets
<li>Assess the use and adequacy of the enforcement of main competition instruments in health care:
• Understand the theoretical & empirical challenges related to competition and the enforcement of competition policy in health care

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Most students are comfortable using commercially available software, like Excel or Adobe Photoshop. However, the power of being able to use computers expands dramatically when one learns how to think like a software engineer and how to design and even write one’s own computer programs. Programming, or “coding”, is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course is an introduction to programming simple algorithms that can be extremely useful throughout anyone’s career. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of the role computation can play in solving problems. It also aims to help students, regardless of their future direction, to feel justifiably confident of their ability to write programs that allow them to accomplish useful goals. The course uses the Matlab (M) programming language as an example, as it is easy to learn and useful in many scientific fields, and the acquired coding skills and the programmer’s mindset will be easily transferred to other programming languages.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
• Illustrate the value of computing and computer programming
• Become familiar with programming and the programming environment of MATLAB
• Apply the use of programming to a set of problems
• Learn how to continue learning how to program</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89898,2019,Computer Science P,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. CMP Müller'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Coding is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course introduces students to the programming language Python 3 (P). This language is widely used in academia, is open and free, and allows one to use a programming language used by a large worldwide community, as well as companies like Google, Facebook, Instagram, Spotify, Quora, Netflix, Dropbox & Reddit. Python 3 is well-supported and well-documented and allows for a number of things that other packages, e.g Matlab, do not. For example like picking one’s own Integrated Development Environment. The course Computer Science I (or Computer Science M) is not a prerequisite, but can be helpful because the way of thinking like a programmer is also taught in Computer Science I/M. Students will be offered lectures alongside tutorials during which they will work on exercises and assignments.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: At the end of the course, the students will acquire sufficient knowledge in order to apply techniques from informatics, computer science and programming to their own research. </body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86062,2019,Computer Science for Business Analytics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. F Frasincar'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course starts by introducing various Computer Science topics relevant for Business Analytics. After that, the phenomenon of Big Data is presented, followed by the Semantic Web as a set of technologies bringing structure to Big Data. As a large amount of Big Data resides on the Web, techniques for extracting information from online sources will also be discussed. Additionally, in order to be able to query relational databases, the SQL query language will be studied.

As means to process Big Data we will look at parallel computing models, focusing on the Map-Reduce parallel computing style. Also, with the purpose of reducing the number of computations for finding similar items (a fundamental data mining problem), we will describe Locality-Sensitive Hashing.

In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures, the students will work in teams on several assignments on the discussed topics. The students will also write a report describing the proposed solutions.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Have an overview of Computer Science topics (e.g., Machine Learning, Data Mining, Query Languages, Parallel Algorithms, etc.) relevant for Business Analytics.
• Know Computer Science techniques (e.g., Semantic Web, Locality-Sensitive Hashing, SQL, Map-Reduce, etc.) applicable for Business Analytics.
• Exploit Computer Science techniques for building Business Analytics solutions.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87984,2019,Computers and Law,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. C van Noortwijk'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course focuses upon certain concrete legal problems that are connected with the use of information technology in society. Examples are: downloading music and movies from the internet; the legal protection of computer software, databases and data; ecommerce and electronic markets; privacy protection and computer crime; legal questions of ‘Social media’ and the liability of intermediary service providers. Students will learn to analyse these problems and examine possible solutions within the context of their own national legal system. The problems of integrating technological developments in areas that have always been paper-based, and the role and use of 'electronic signatures' in these areas will also be examined. In addition to these practical aspects, the impact of technology on the development of legal principles will be dealt with.

In the digital world of the Internet, today's lawyers frequently encounter problems and questions, but also new possibilities related to information technology. Lawyers in private practice, company lawyers or lawyers in managing functions are expected to be able to deal with such issues.

Furthermore, information technology has given rise to new possibilities for legal practice as well as for performing (empirical) legal research. Several of such new possibilities will be discussed during this course. Among these are new ways to increase legal knowledge, as well as to manage this knowledge and to apply it in practice. By working on two practical assignments, students will have the opportunity to perform ‘jurimetrics research’ and to build and use so-called ‘legal knowledge based systems’.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is twofold:
•    to familiarize students with the social changes brought about by the 'Information Society', and to place these within a legal context;

•    to assess the impact of IT developments for the legal profession (sometimes referred to as ‘LegalTech’) and to gain insight in new tools and methodologies (for instance, for performing legal research) that are (or will be) available to lawyers.
After the course, students will be able to
•    understand and describe the way in which technology is developing;
•    formulate legal questions and problems relevant to our current ‘Information Society’;
•    provide solutions to these questions and problems;
•    discern the essential characteristics of the internet, as far as these are legally relevant;
•    assess the impact of IT on legal practice;
•    perform empirical research, as a group member, with respect to (data relating to) legal decision making;
•    explain the importance of proper knowledge management for legal organizations, and the role information systems can play for that.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85665,2019,Concepts and Categories,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. O Lindemann'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Categories and concepts make up the knowledge people have about things and people in the world. Being able to make a connection between our earlier experiences and new interactions with the environment ensure that we can recognise and understand new things and people. For most people this is a fairly simple process which runs largely automatically, but understanding it from a psychological viewpoint is highly complicated. Four broad topics will be covered during this course: Learning categories and the formation of prototypes and stereotypes, and the consequences for categorizing things and people. The effect of brain damage or abnormalities on categorisation and concept representations, with a special focus on deficits that result in the inability to recognize particular categories of things such as animals or human faces. Embodied cognition, which will address the question whether bodily sensations or actions are involved in the representations of categories. The grounding of concepts in the brain, addressing the question where and how conceptual knowledge is represented by the brain, and which methods can be used to investigate this question.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students learn the most important theories and empirical data on the way people represent their knowledge and the influence this has on behaviour. Attention will also be devoted to research methods both in theory and practice. At the end of the course, students should be able to understand, describe, and critically compare theories of categorization and concept representations. They should be able to understand, describe, and critically evaluate studies that test such theories.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88115,2019,Concepts and Methods of Law and Economics,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AMIB Vandenberghe'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course offers an introduction to the basic concepts and methods of law and economics. It illustrates the broad utility of these tools by way of applications to the analysis of various core areas of law. This course does not aim to develop practical skills or new insights, but rather to show the broad utility of economic analysis of law. By combining examples from various areas of law, students will learn that the economic approach to law provides a unified vision of the law, tying together diverse areas of the law into a common theoretical structure.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89203,2019,Conflict Analysis and Transformation: A Governance Perspective,Engels,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,['dr. HM Hintjens', 'dr. SMS Jayasundara - Smits', 'prof.dr. SM Murshed']",,

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In today's world, war between states has become a rarity, whereas violent conflict within national boundaries is of growing concern. The causes and dynamics of civil wars, and other types of intra-state conflicts, require a different understanding than classical wars. Conflicts are increasingly complex, featuring multiple parties, transnational dynamics, and strategies to resolve them.

The course focuses on contemporary conflicts and is structured around three parts: (I) how conflicts arise, (II) how they can be managed, and (III) how they can be transformed and resolved. Borrowing from fields such as International Relations, Political Science, Sociology, Psychology, history, anthropology, Law, this course has a distinctly interdisciplinary outlook.

A variety of violent conflicts are featured ranging from ethnic, electoral, ethnic, resource-based and secessionist. By adopting a case study-approach, we will attempt to understand the causes of conflict as well as techniques and interventions developed to end and resolve them such as peacekeeping, mediation, and transitional justice. Finally, you will gain tools to understand and analyse conflict, and gain practical experience in negotiating a resolution to a conflict by means of a simulation game.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • have basic knowledge of various types of conflict in the contemporary world;
• be familiar with different conflict models and able to apply these models, concepts and theories to a range of conflicts;
• have acquired an understanding of the main methods and tools used in conflict resolution;
• have acquired basic skills in conflict analysis, problem-solving and negotiation

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/88576,2019,Consultancy project,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,[],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: To bring business closer to your academic education and enhance your understanding of the business world in practice the consultancy project is part of the program. In the consultancy project you are challenged to analyse a real-life problem coming from a business-client and understand the specific needs in and of a client organization. In a group of approximately 6 students you will be asked to help a client solving a problem by developing new and sustainable recommendations. This process takes place in a project-like work setting in intensive contact with the client. You are expected to understand the clients’ needs, scope and narrow down the problem into a researchable question, develop and use a suitable theoretical framework, collect data and explore potential solutions and make recommendations. The projects often take place within a context with various stakeholders. Hence, dealing with a variety of different stakeholder is part of the project.

Next to problem-solving skills necessary in this project team cooperation and leadership in and of a team are relevant aspects in this project. To reflect on the team process and improve on your team behaviour various challenge and reflection moments are built into this 4 month process. The project team is invited to assess their members’ behaviour and critically reflect on possible improvements.
This course is worth 6 EC and runs from blocks 3 through 4.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Analytical skills: Dealing with a high amount of information in a short time in an (formerly) unknown domain and gain/maintain an overview
• Analytical skills: Being able to define, scope, analyse and structure an (formerly) unknown and ill-defined problem
• Problem-solving skills: Develop consistent, relevant and sustainable recommendations for the client based on high professional standards and understand that there is no right or wrong
• Managerial skills: Think independently and behave autonomously: working on problems – not following instructions
• Managerial skills: manage and satisfy the various requirements from stakeholders
• Managerial skills: Make use of the cross-cultural and disciplinary diversity in a team
• Leadership skills: experience and reflect on your impact on a team process and think about improvements
