column1: In preparation for each class, all students are expected to carefully read a set of assigned readings. There are two types of readings: “discussion papers” and “background readings”. Students are required to read all of the discussion papers (marked with an *) as we will spend the majority of the time discussing these articles and exploring promising avenues for related future research. The background readings will provide students with additional information on the topic if they are interested in learning more.

We will spend a large portion of class time focusing on the assigned discussion papers. For each topic, students will be expected to submit one discussion question to me by 9pm the night before the class discussion. The discussion question can be about a specific article, a combination of the articles, or focus on the topic area. Students should come to class prepared to share their question with their classmates.

In addition to submitting a discussion question, students will be asked to come prepared to advocate for and critique against the assigned articles. In order to advocate for a paper, students should identify some positive aspects for the work and think about why the assigned article merited publication. As a critic, students should seek to identify the weakness(es) of the work and explain why they believe the weakness(es) limit the research. Unlike the discussion question students are NOT expected to submit their thoughts on the articles’ strengths and weaknesses prior to class.

Students will be expected to prepare a thought paper for a minimum of three of the topics we cover (please feel free to do more if you would like!). The thought paper is designed to help develop skills of identifying interesting future research ideas and to practice communicating ideas in a coherent written fashion. The structure of the paper should involve identifying a specific new research question that extends, or is otherwise inspired by, the work reported in the assigned articles. Further, students will be expected to justify why the proposed idea is interesting and important to consider.

Thought papers are due by 9 pm the evening before the day we cover the topic. The papers should be submitted to me by e-mail in a Word document (2-3 pages, double spaced, Times New Roman 12-point font, 1 inch margins) for each paper. Late submissions will not be marked.
The submissions will be marked on the following scale:

Note that I will mark a thought paper as “outstanding” only if it significantly exceeds my standard for acceptable submissions. I will provide feedback on each of the submitted thought papers. In addition, students will be asked to share their thought paper idea with their classmates during the class discussion. Students will be asked to present a brief overview of their idea and then the class will discuss it. The goal is for students to have a “workable” idea from most, if not all, of the thought papers they write.

Students will be expected to submit a research proposal for a major study (or multiple studies, where appropriate) on a novel and important question or topic in the area of consumer behaviour. This proposal should include:
1. A statement of motivation for the proposed research. (Why should anybody care about the outcomes of this research?)
2. A clear statement of the purpose of the research. (What is the objective of the research).
3. A statement of the intended contribution of the proposed research. (How will it improve our understanding of the phenomenon of interest?)
4. A thorough review of the relevant bodies of literature. (What has already been done in relevant areas of research?)
5. A theoretical framework for the proposed work. (What are the relevant theories, and how is the proposed research enhancing, integrating, or applying them?)
6. A set of research hypotheses. (What are the specific predictions, in connection with the theoretical framework, that is proposed to be tested?)

7. A detailed description of the research method that is proposed to test the hypotheses. (Including experimental design, environment, tasks, stimuli, instruments for measuring responses, and specific plans for data collection and data analysis.)

This assignment is designed to result in a working draft of the front end for a paper. Students will be given an opportunity to share their research proposal idea in class on the final day. During this time, students will be expected to communicate the core idea of their work and then solicit feedback from their classmates and myself. Final papers will be due one month later.
Final marks will be based on performance in three domains. The percentages below show the importance that each of these three components.
PM:  research paper ideas and discussion of emerging research topics</body>

• Provide students with a strong foundation for critical thinking in the area of consumer behaviour.
• Provide insight into how a consumer behaviour paper is written.

column1: Consumers are confronted in their daily lives with numerous marketing actions. Companies and manufacturers use media to pursuade consumers to buy their products or to use their services. To understand the idea behind these communciation messages you will learn in this course different concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences. For example you will learn how consumers make decisions and how they learn and remember information. You will also learn how consumers are persuaded or motivated. Moreover you will learn how consumers form attitudes about products and you will get insight into how all these theories and concepts are used by companies in their media communication and marketing strategies. In this course all students make a personal portfolio of magazine advertisements. Students will analyze these advertisements in order to gain insight into important concepts that are covered throughout the course. Moreover, this assignment will help you to see how and why marketing practice may illustrate and support consumer behavior theories, as well as how practice may contradict these theories.

column2: • The lectures of this course are mandatory
• This course is not accessible for students who have already completed the CM2072 or CM2272 course.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The purpose of this course is to introduce you to the study of consumer behavior. We will examine many concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences and analyze their usefulness for developing marketing strategies. The goal is to teach you these key concepts and to develop your ability to apply them in analyzing marketing situations and developing appropriate marketing strategies.</body>

column1: The course focuses on consumer/audience behavior, more specifically people’s attitudes towards specific businesses/organizations/products/services/artists, what factors contribute to their attraction to those products, and why they continue to make the same choices. On the other hand, the course topic is also meant to research upon and give a better understanding regarding individuals’ ‘attachment’ to specific brands, and possible reasons behind their refusal to acknowledge the quality of others.

Based on a theory-practice perspective, the course will introduce students to specific persuasion tools, used in both media and advertising for business purposes, giving them an insight on what to look for when analyzing specific topics, and will also encourage them to find examples to which the theoretical concepts can be applied.

Seminars will be divided into two main parts, the understanding of theoretical concepts, and discussing them in relation to practical examples. Four assignments will be given during the 8-week seminars, and the final assessment will consist of a comment paper and the presentation of that paper. During the seminars, formats for qualitative analysis research will be introduced to students, with the expectation that their final exam hand-ins will be arranged according to those formats.</body>

column2: • develop their analytical skills, both individually (through assignments and exam) and in teams (during seminar debates);
• gain a better understanding of qualitative research methods, in the form of a critical comment paper at the end of the term;
• develop their debating skills, opinion expression, argument defense and confrontation, and also presentation abilities.

column1: Students will have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • literature reviews in accordance to specific topics;
• integration methods of reviewed information in their own comment papers;
• embodying the obtained information into their own ideas and arguments.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89092,2019,Consumer Behaviour,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. DR Schley'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Understanding consumers is the key to a successful marketing strategy. Unfortunately, however, the mind of the consumer is not always easy to understand. This course provides an overview of theories that best explain how consumers arrive at their judgments and decisions. The course will review relevant theories from economics and psychology that provide a foundation for behavioural marketing. Consumer behaviour varies greatly depending on a range of factors. For instance, consumers’ judgments and decisions are influenced by the market environment (e.g., retail vs. online), the type of consumer (e.g., older vs. younger), and the type of product (e.g., hedonic vs. utilitarian goods), just to name a few. Although it is impossible to fully grasp and predict this behaviour, consumer researchers have created a body of knowledge that allows us to achieve at least a basic understanding of consumer needs, wants, decisions and actions. This course will provide a structured overview of this body of knowledge. In the first part of the course, students will be provided with an introduction to the psychology of perception, information processing, emotions and decision-making. The second part of the course will elaborate on the influences of the social environment, culture and situational factors on consumer behaviour. Additionally, the second part of this course will apply these theories and principles to real-world marketing problems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: Provide you with a foundation in the theories, models, and other tools used by academic and industry marketers for understanding the determinants of consumer behavior.
Provide you with general ideas about how to influence consumers, and about how you as a consumer are influenced by others (including marketers).
Prepare you to write a master thesis on the topic of consumer behavior.

column1: During the lessons the following topics will be covered and discussed:
1. Historical and contemporary perspectives on consumer behaviour.
2. Decision-making, involvement, learning and memory in consumer behaviour.
3. Perceptual processes, attitude theory and behaviour change in consumer behaviour .
4. Personality, self and motivation in consumer behaviour .
5. Groups, social processes and communications in consumer behaviour.
6. Data, buyer behaviour and brand loyalty.
7. Anti-Consumption, future trends in consumer behaviour.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Understanding consumers and their needs are at the core of marketing. - This course will cover the fundamental principles and theories to understand and interpret consumer behavior. Questions that will be addressed during this course are: - How can an understanding of consumer behavior help in developing marketing strategies to influence consumer behavior? - How do consumers make purchase decisions? - And what underlying psychological processes might be involved in consumer decision making?
• Reproduce and interpret concepts in key areas of business economics: marketing and consumer behavior.
• Analyse, explain, evaluate and advise about current situations based on the history, philosophy and ethics of the field.
• Cooperate with fellow students in task-driven groups of various structures (monodisciplinary or multidisciplinary). Deal with relationships and tensions between different people in the group.
• Present information, ideas, research results and policy recommendations both in writing and in verbal form.
• Take a stand on economic developments and related research. Moreover, students should be able to defend that position.
• Take responsibility for their personal learning process.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The extensive group work is limited to 2 group assignments.
• Furthermore, the course uses a profound and structured, most recent, academic book that covers the entire consumer behaviour knowledge area.
• January-February 2019, the learning objectives have been changed and raised to the proper Master level: After this consumer behaviour course, you will be able:
• To evaluate past, current and future trends as well as consumer behaviour developments.
• To identify how behavioural insight thinking impacts on consumer behaviour.
• To identify the decision-making process stages of consumer shopping behaviour.
• To explain how behavioural, cognitive and social learning impacts on consumer behaviour.
• To explain the perceptual process, from exposure to stimuli to consumer response.
• To assess what attitude theory is and how this theory is used in consumer marketing.
• To analyse how personality, self and psychographics explain the consumer’s behaviour.
• To explain the role of group influence mechanisms on consumer behaviour.
• To appraise how buyer behaviour relates to segments, differentiation and distinctiveness.
• To assess and compare individual (age/knowledge/income) and external (socio-cultural /geographic/demographic/technological) factors that influence consumer behaviour.

• In addition, the information and instructions regarding the written (digital Remindo) exam as well as about the 2 written assignments has been improved and clarified. This means that in particular all questions of the 2 written assignments have been improved.

• Furthermore, 2 clear rubrics have been added to the 2 written assignments, clarifying to the students which issues are relevant in these assignments as well as clarifying how these issues will be marked by the lecturer.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87236,2019,Consumer Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. SJ Opree', 'prof.dr. CJM van Eijck']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The goal of this course is to provide students with a proper understanding of consumption from the academic perspectives of the homo economicus, homo sociologicus, and homo aestheticus. Using this multi-disciplinary perspective, consumption will be addressed as a socially embedded practice where aspects of freedom and individual choice are to be considered in the light of the opportunities for consumption offered by a socio-historically specific context. This implies that students develop an understanding of the causes and consequences of consumption (both material and cultural) at both the micro-level (e.g., identity, routines, meaning-making) and the macro-level (e.g., sustainability, politics, citizenship). Having been offered a solid theoretical foundation on consumption, students will apply theoretical insights to actual consumption practices by conducting interviews on informants’ consumption practices. In addition, they will carry out a literature study of a specific element of consumer culture, explicitly linking micro- and macro-levels of analysis so as to grasp the complex links between consumer behaviour on the one hand and its causes and consequences at the level of society.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The main theories and concepts, including a critical appraisal of their historical emergence, regarding consumption and consumer culture
• The consumer research traditions within economics and the social sciences
• Apply theoretical concepts regarding consumption and consumer culture to empirical observations / their own lives
• Report and reflect on their findings in oral and written form

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89093,2019,Consumer Marketing Research,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. AM Ferecatu'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
In this course, students will familiarize themselves with the main marketing research approaches for understanding consumer behaviour. Students will acquire knowledge on:
(1) how to accurately measure and analyse consumers’ preferences, attitudes and choices, and
(2) how marketing variables (such as product benefits, assortments, advertisements and retail environments) affect consumer behaviour.

The course introduces the main methods for analysing consumer behaviour (e.g. structured and unstructured observations, experiments and survey research), and focuses on the design and analysis of experiments and surveys.

column2: • knowledge of the main research methods for studying and understanding consumer behaviour
• Be able to analyse and interpret consumer research data, collected in experiments and in surveys

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87150,2019,Consumer Perceptions of Corporate Social Responsibility,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. A van Prooijen'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A growing number of companies have started to recognize the value of sustainable business practices, and have adopted a pro-active search for opportunities to improve their societal and environmental impacts. These socially responsible practices can lead to a range of shared benefits for the company and for society. Despite these mutual benefits, it can be challenging for companies to promote their CSR activities. On the one hand, it is important for companies to communicate about their CSR performance in order to acquire potential reputational benefits. Moreover, consumers increasingly demand transparency from companies about their business conduct. On the other hand, consumers do not always respond positively to CSR information of companies. Consumers can be sceptical about the credibility of corporate claims about their involvement in CSR. Thus, even though companies might have sincere motives for their sustainability initiatives, the promotion of these initiatives can backfire due to suspicions of corporate greenwashing. Topics that are discussed in this course include the drivers of consumers’ preference for socially responsible companies, how CSR communication is evaluated by consumers, perceptions of sincerity of corporate motives to invest in CSR, and the role of new media in CSR communication.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Theoretical approaches, concepts and perspectives in the field of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) communication;
• Consumer attitudes, motives and intentions regarding CSR.
• Systematically analyse and critically reflect on theoretical and practical issues in CSR communication;
• Apply theoretical knowledge to and construct arguments about CSR-related communication strategies and issues.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86959,2019,Consumption and Identity,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. LE Braden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In modern society, identity is increasingly shaped and defined by what we buy, brands we wear, products we use, and consumer loyalties we claim. Perhaps as a consequence, in the past several decades consumer studies have grown in importance for sociological research. Accordingly, this course examines the connection between consumption and identity.  We begin by exploring contemporary theories of consumption, including ideas on rationalization and taste distinctions.  We then turn to consumption’s role in mediating the modern tension between establishing individual identity and community membership. We next address the possible dangers of using commodities of the culture industry to help shape our societies and ourselves. To what degree does the culture industry determine consumption practices and understandings? To address this question, we first examine the other side of consumption, supply, and how cultural producers and gatekeepers determine what products to offer. Once consumers attain these products, are they active or passive—i.e., how do they use, change, or reject commercial goods? Finally, we end the course by examining consumption’s role in social mobilization, including protest, to effect change.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students will be able to identify the major issues within consumption studies and address those issues through a foundation of sociological theory and empirical research. Students will also be able to link concepts considered in class and the literature to the broader social context and their own social realities and consumption practices.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86945,2019,Contemporary Approaches in Cultural Sociology,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. J Michael', 'dr. JCF Schaap', 'dr. MJ Berghman', 'dr. N Oosterman']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology has been witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas such as politics, economy, the state, etc. This course addresses major themes and theories in cultural sociology by discerning three ideal typical approaches:

column2: • culture as cognitive structure approach, which studies the way in which cultural codes, schemas, narratives and texts constrain and enable the possible range and arrangement of meanings;
• culture in action approach, which focuses on the practical ways in which culture is reflexively used and set to work to solve everyday problems;
• production of culture approach, which focuses on how the content of culture (in the more restricted sense) is affected by its production, distribution and consumption.

column1: We will study exemplary works from all three contemporary approaches in cultural sociology, and, furthermore, focus on work that integrates key ideas from these different approaches into the study of making meaning in various cultural genres such as music, literature, fashion and sports. Finally, we will zoom in on how gender, race/ethnicity and nationality affect meaning-making, and how each of the three abovementioned approaches has studied such questions differently.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course students will develop and expand their knowledge of the sociological perspective on the arts and culture in the broad sense. They will be able to distinguish three contemporary theoretical approaches in cultural sociology (culture as cognitive structure, culture in action and production of culture) and identify these approaches in recent sociological research.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87241,2019,Contemporary Approaches to Digital Cultures,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. P Arora'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Contemporary approaches to digital cultures: platforms, politics, performances and people

How do we identify the fake from the real? What strategies enable us to reveal and yet protect our subjects who seek anonymity online? Can researchers be activists and their research serve as instruments for social change? How do we ensure fair representation through big data analytics? These are some of the questions that need addressing as we seek to study digital cultures.  This course identifies key research issues and novel methodological solutions in the study of contemporary digital cultures. In particular, we investigate challenges faced in the arena of data authenticity, representation and communication to lay and other publics.

The course is organised around four dimensions – platforms, politics, performances and people. Platforms are the new contexts for digital cultures. They are deeply corporatized, walled gardens that often allow a small circle of researchers to access their vast data. They are designed to be unstable, as they need to constantly innovate and re-design to stay competitive. Here, students learn to apply methods of place-making and data hacking to circumvent issues of access and locatedness. To speak thoughtfully about the politics of engagement, students learn to critically identify and capture the perspective from varied actors such as (non)users, programmers, politicians, corporations and activists. To extract voices from below, students learn how to deploy action research using social media campaigns. Performances are about digital expressions, memes and trends. Here, students learn to use digital methods to assess claims of globality and diversity through big data. Lastly, in the module on People, students learn to apply auto-ethnography to digital contexts such as gaming, city navigation and other applications. Overall, this course provides both qualitative and quantitative methodological insights into the examining of contemporary digital cultures.

Note: This course is part of the graduate programme of the national Research School for Media Studies (RMeS). The course is specifically designed for research master students. The maximum number of participants is 25. Research master students who are part of RMeS take priority over other research master students.

column1: Ever since the advent of the 20th century, political philosophers have felt the need to conceptually restructure and philosophically legitimise the notion of a ‘liberal representative democracy’. This process is still going on, as can be seen in the writings of many contemporary political thinkers. In this course we focus on several key debates – and bones of contention – on liberal democracies in contemporary political theory and political philosophy. Central concepts include: justice, legitimacy, deliberative democracy, antagonism, ideology and inclusion. These concepts will be discussed in reference to thinkers as diverse as Carl Schmitt, Jürgen Habermas, John Rawls and Chantal Mouffe.

column1: The lecturer of this course is Dr Jason Kiley (Spears School of Business, Oklahoma State University).

column2: • Prerequisites. To get started, participants will learn the basic skills for using modern statistical ecosystems (i.e. Python, with some examples in R and Stata), particularly those for data handling and using the many external packages that make sophisticated techniques very accessible. These topics include basic variable types, working with dates, importing and exporting data, and using external packages.

• Getting and handling data. Participants will work through examples reading in, preparing, and saving structured data (e.g., from typical archival datasets). In addition, they will work through a step–by–step example using web scraping to recover semi–structured data and generate structured data.

• Hands–on techniques. Using sample data, participants will transform text into quantitative data (i.e. feature engineering) and run some common forms of text analysis. Because feature engineering is a common foundation of many kinds of techniques, we will look at how these methods work, and their relative strengths and weaknesses. The text analyses include human–coded variables, dictionary methods, pre–trained machine learning models, and machine learning models for categorization and topic modeling.

• Familiarization. For a number of advanced techniques, I want participants to know that they exist, know what problems they can solve, have a brief example to walk through, and know where to look for more information outside of the course. These topics include automated data collection, APIs, SQL, and advanced machine learning.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course is designed to help participants learn modern text analysis techniques, with relevant content ranging from planning a study to publication. The topics will include a streamlined set of data science prerequisites, gathering and working with data, understanding how text becomes data, hands–on work with common techniques, and familiarization with some advanced techniques. The skill requirements assume essentially no prior training, though reasonable spreadsheet skills and some familiarity with one of the commonly–used commercial statistical systems is helpful.

After completing the course, participants should have a sound understanding of fundamental skills underlying text analysis and machine learning workflows, knowledge of particular sets of skills and their return on investment for researchers, hands–on experience with a number of common techniques, and a road map for selecting and learning further skills to carry out their research.</body>

column1: Practitioners not only need to have an in-depth knowledge of contract law but are also often involved in drafting commercial contracts. The course Contract Drafting deals with techniques of international contract drafting from the perspective of comparative contract law. It builds on the activities of the International Contract Working Group chaired by Professor De Ly, which has been analysing contract clauses for the past thirty years leading to many publications. The course will cover boiler plate and tailor made clauses from the contract formation point to the termination of the contract including letters of intent, merger clauses, force majeure and hardship clauses, exemption and penalty clauses, termination and post termination clauses, assignment clauses and dispute settlement clauses. Clauses used in practice, both pathological and model clauses, will be used as illustrations. The course is taught on the basis of the compulsory reading materials, case law materials and practical cases.

column1: Familiarize students with drafting of various contract clauses from an international and comparative perspective against a background of law and business

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The role of the financial controller is changing in ways that mirror those of the broader finance function. Rather than serving as a rear-view mirror that only provides information about historical performance, the financial controller increasingly participate in the analysis and formulation of solutions to higher value-added, strategic issues. Reliance on forward-looking techniques tools allows the finance function to anticipate the future needs of the company to drive appropriate action, improve the current operating results and eventually maximize the bottom line.

The dynamic and integrative role of the controller function in business corporations is the focus of this course. Classes cover the principles underlying planning and control decisions in functional and divisional organizations, as well the design and consequences of responsibility accounting and performance measurement systems under various market conditions. The course also extends to financial controller’s roles in budgeting, strategic planning, pricing, risk management, corporate finance and investment related decision making.

The course is structured in lectures and tutorials. During the lecture part, the respective topics of each session are introduced and discussed. The emphasis in the tutorials is given to the preparation for CMA (Certified Management Accountant) Exam questions. Overall, by linking together financial management techniques and analytical business skills, the course aims at preparing students to manage the entire spectrum of responsibilities expected by financial professionals</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students are able to:

column2: • Demonstrate proficiency in understanding and interpreting each financial statement (balance sheet, income statement, cash flows statement), including the appropriate measurement and reporting standards underlying various financial transactions;
• Understand the role and apply the relevant techniques required for strategic planning, budgeting and forecasting;
• Recommend key performance measures (cost drivers and revenue drivers), responsibility centers and a periodic internal reporting methodology (e.g. Balanced Scorecard) given a business scenario;
• Identify and evaluate relevant decisions regarding long-term financial management, raising capital, corporate restructuring and international corporate finance;
• Recommend a course of action using cost estimation, marginal analysis and pricing methodologies under specific market conditions;
• Explain the role of corporate governance and evaluate risk assessment tools for operational and financial risks;
• Calculate the relevant cash flows of a capital investment project using discounted cash flow (NPV, IRR) and risk analysis;

• Demonstrate an understanding of issues organizations face in applying their values and ethical standards internationally, by proposing resolutions for ethical dilemmas such as fraudulent financial reporting, data manipulation and corporate social responsibility.

column1: This course aims to develop a basic understanding of economic behaviour. We will do so by examining the intuitions and the real world underpinning of the ‘maths and the models’ of economics. The focus is on teaching economic tools and concepts by addressing relevant questions, such as the causes and consequences of the financial crisis or economic inequality. Topics that will be discussed include individual decision making (‘how do people divide their time between leisure and working?’), firm decision-making (‘how do firms decide how much to produce?’), market mechanisms (‘how is decided what price we pay for our products?’), the financial world (‘how is money created?’), and how an economy can be described and measured, at an aggregate level.

The course is empirically motivated and illustrated. Based on facts from history, experiments and data, students will learn how economic insights and models can be used to understand the real world. The course will introduce you to key concepts in economic theory and economic reasoning on the basis of the curriculum developed by the core economics project.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After following this course, you will have an understanding of:

column2: • what the science of economics is about;
• the characteristics of the different recent economic epochs and their effect on the economy and the science of economics;
• choices people make given the opportunities available;
• the working and the limits of markets
• the elements of the aggregate economy and how government policies can affect these elements;
• the role banks play in the economy.

column1: This course provides an overview of the approaches, perspectives, and dimensions of corporate communication in an environment where branding and reputation are paramount. Students will learn about the functions, practices, challenges and opportunities of corporate communication in an international and social-mediated context.. Students will understand and critique the various roles that communication plays in the internal and external relations of organizations through a mix of case studies, course readings, and perspectives from the field.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 75. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89118,2019,Corporate Entrepreneurship,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. L Glaser', 'JS Breet']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In today’s dynamic and continuously changing business environment, entrepreneurship is an essential and indispensable element in the success of many organizations. Corporate entrepreneurship (or intrapreneurship) refers to activities involved in creating and exploiting new resource combinations in the context of existing corporations. Although many business books purport to teach top management how to create a culture that nurtures visionaries like Sergey Brin (Google) and Mark Zuckerberg (Facebook), the ability to think and act entrepreneurially and engage in ongoing processes of creativity often fails because established organizations present hostile environments for entrepreneurial ideas. This core course focuses primarily on organizational and managerial efforts aimed at the identification, development and exploitation of entrepreneurial ideas, the management of new product or process developments, and on effective new venture management in the context of large corporations. Topics include ways how organizations can stimulate corporate entrepreneurship, intra-organizational networks, entrepreneurial action, work contexts, exploration and exploitation.

The grading of the course will be based on two components. First, theoretical knowledge and practical knowledge based on case presentations during the course will be tested in an exam (50%). Second, you will operate in a team of students to analyze an entrepreneurial challenge in a corporate organization. As a team you develop an advisory report on how the organization can become entrepreneurial (50% of final grade).</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The main objective of the core course is to develop an awareness and understanding of the range, scope, and complexity of the issues related to the creation of an organizational environment that is supportive of entrepreneurial endeavors as well as to gain insight concerning the effective implementation of technological and organizational new business development in a corporate setting.

column1: This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. The themes we deal with in this course are particularly relevant for business decision-making in areas as whether or not to invest in a project, how to finance an investment, and how to deal with uncertainty.

Corporate finance can be seen as supportive to other fields such as strategy or marketing; often in these fields the business decisions are formulated (e.g., in what markets or products should we invest), whereas in corporate finance we evaluate these choices and analyse how to fund them best.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following this course, you should be able to:

column2: • Calculate the value of a company that is financed with equity and debt based on an analysis of the relevant cash flows.
• Analyse the impact of real options and dividend policy on the value of companies.
• Apply complex financial instruments such as futures, options, (convertible) bonds and warrants.
• Apply pricing models of complex financial instruments such as futures, options, (convertible) bonds and warrants.
• Apply key international finance models such as Purchasing Power Parity, international Fisher effect and covered and uncovered interest parity.
• In addition to these main topics, we deal with some specific topics.

column1: Finance appears to be at the nexus of recent political developments, not least due to its effect on the recent financial crisis. Corporate finance is much more than a collection of equations, matrices and models. Corporate finance is a set of first principles that govern how we run businesses. This is an introductory finance course that addresses the key decisions and issues faced by senior financial officers in corporations and the analytical frameworks and approaches that are helpful in addressing these issues. This course is an extensive introduction to the basic tools, techniques and theories that are necessary to understand the financial decision-making in the modern corporation. At the end of this course you will be able to apply Corporate Finance to unstructured real-life problems, get the bigger picture before you press the button, and be able to make numerical exercises as well as understanding the theories/models behind them.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After successfully completing the course you will be able to:

column2: • explain the implications of the model of Hirshleifer and the separation theorem of Fisher;
• apply the net present value method and other investment selection criteria;
• determine the value of financial assets such as shares and bonds;
• combine individual financial assets into a portfolio of financial assets;
• explain the difference between profits and cash flows;
• explain the portfolio theory and the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM);
• apply the CAPM to set a discount rate;
• explain the consequences of an efficient market for the investors in financial assets;
• explain the consequences of an efficient market for the investors in real assets;
• determine the net present value of a merger.

column1: This course discusses the corporate governance challenges of various kinds of private enterprise organization, as well as the measures and practices that can be used to meet these challenges. After introducing a general framework, we will look at the corporate governance challenges of publicly listed firms, family firms, (professional) partnerships, State owned enterprises, and non-profit organizations, such as philanthropies, for example. Although we focus mainly on the role and interests of owners in these firms, we will also discuss how corporate governance affects the interests of other stakeholders, such as employees, customers, creditors or society at large.

Corporate governance is about the ownership, decision-making and accountability practices through which modern enterprise organizations develop and deploy their resources in order to create value and secure a sustainable future while taking into account the business context at large. Within publicly listed firms, for example, executives make the bulk of everyday business decisions, while highly dispersed and therefore mostly uninvolved shareholders and other stakeholders face their economic consequences.

A striking fact about modern economic organization, however, is that there are not only publicly listed firms, but many different forms of enterprise organization, such as: (professional) partnerships, state-owned enterprises, cooperatives, family firms, and non-profit organizations such as philanthropies. Each of these organizational forms faces its own distinctive corporate governance challenges and will need to develop equally specific practices to meet these challenges.

In this course, we will survey and discuss various forms of enterprise organization in order to unveil the specific corporate governance challenges that they face. As modern capitalism is predicated on the private ownership of the means of production, we focus (but not exclusively) on the role of owners of these organizations but we will also take into account the role of societal stakeholders.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand what corporate governance is and how it matters in business
• Understand the role of ownership in firms and how it matters in corporate governance more specifically
• Think strategically about different ways to meet the specific corporate governance challenges that come with   different types of ownership of the firm
• Think strategically about different ways in which firms can shape and manage their relationship with their stakeholders
• Think strategically about different ways in which firms can develop and maintain their institutional license to operate

• Ultimately to think strategically about how to align the ownership and governance practices of a firm with its core activities, critical resources and resource dependencies, its current and future business model, and its societal license to operate

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87864,2019,Corporate Governance and Corporate Litigation,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,['mr. O Oost', 'mr. T Spronk', 'mr.drs. KH Boonzaaijer']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Het vak Corporate Governance en Corporate Litigation richt zich op de interne structuur van N.V.’s en B.V.’s, op de aansprakelijkheidspositie van functionarissen van N.V.’s en B.V.’s en op juridische procedures rondom vennootschappen. Tot de vragen en aspecten die aan de orde komen tijdens dit vak behoren de volgende.

column2: • Wat is corporate governance? Wat is corporate litigation?
• Is er een verschil tussen corporate governance en corporate litigation in besloten vennootschappelijke verhoudingen en open verhoudingen (beursvennootschappen)?
• Wat is het gevolg van toepasselijkheid van de structuurregeling op de interne verhoudingen?
• Wat is de invloed van concernvorming op de interne verhoudingen?
• Welke (juridische) regels beheersen de interne verhoudingen in vennootschappen?
• Wat zijn de taken en bevoegdheden van het bestuur? Wat is het belang van bestuursautonomie? Hoe wordt bestuursautonomie beschermd? Wanneer is sprake van onbehoorlijk bestuur; wanneer van wanbeleid?
• Wat zijn de verschillen en overeenkomsten tussen een dualistisch bestuursmodel (two tier board) en een monistisch bestuursmodel (one tier board)?
• Hoe functioneert de raad van commissarissen? Wat is het belang van onafhankelijkheid van commissarissen?
• Hoe functioneert de algemene vergadering? Zijn er verschillen tussen een vennootschap met een verspreid aandelenbezit of met een beperkt aantal (groot)aandeelhouders?
• Welke rechten en plichten hebben aandeelhouders? Hoe is de bescherming van minderheidsaandeelhouders geregeld? Hoe kunnen zij hun positie in een juridische procedure beschermen?
• Hoe kunnen vennootschappen zich beschermen tegen activistische aandeelhouders?
• Op welke wijze komen de hiervoor vermelde vragen aan de orde in juridische procedures op het terrein van het ondernemingsrecht?
• Wat zijn de vennootschapsrechtelijke en procesrechtelijke aspecten die verband houden met geschillen binnen/rond ondernemingen?

• Waar en hoe zijn de enquêteprocedure, de geschillenregelingprocedure, de uitkoopprocedure, relevante aansprakelijkheidsprocedures en de procedure voor aantasting van besluiten van de vennootschap geregeld?
• Het vak besteedt daar waar nuttig/mogelijk aandacht aan rechtsvergelijkende aspecten.

column1: Economic efficiency may be undermined by misallocation of financial resources. This course discusses corporate law and financial regulation from the perspective of the correction of financial markets failure. The course focuses on the various legal, contractual and extra-legal mechanisms available to protect (minority) shareholders and other stakeholders from the self-serving behavior of managers and of controlling shareholders. Moreover, the course addresses the problem of financial distress and its consequences for the financing of private and public enterprises, as well as for financial stability.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

column1: Corporate Innovation and Venture Capital: Corporate entrepreneurship refers to the spawning of or pioneering of new businesses within established firms building on their strengths -- an increasingly important process in the organization of corporate research and management of innovation -- and distinct from the study of entrepreneurship (or the founding of new firms).

This course will explore changes in managing innovation in large established companies and emerging models of corporate entrepreneurship. The course will study formal theories of intrapraneurship that have emerged in the last decade and explore the phenomenon through case studies of particular firms, case studies of particular inventions, and also industry studies of how corporate entrepreneurship (and its failure) determine industry dynamics. We will also cover empirical studies of the tradeoff between entrepreneurship and intrapraneurship.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To describe and explain several theories of corporate entrepreneurship.
• To develop a framework for studying alternative forms of corporate entrepreneurship.
• To examine critically the challenges for large established firms in organizing and managing corporate entrepreneurshi pprograms research in an established firm.
• To propose ways for public policy to facilitate corproate entrepreneurship programs.
• To analyze and calculate the conditions under which entrepreneurs prefer corporate entrepreneurship relative to pure entrepreneurship.

column1: This course addresses a wide variety of political and environmental aspects which, when considered overall, help us to understand why some organizations thrive and others struggle.

Besides suppliers, customers, and other market stakeholders, governments and other non-market stakeholders play an essential role and influence the strategy of multinational corporations (MNCs). Governments can play different roles in the interaction with companies. They can both limit or enable companies in starting and doing successful business. In how far this can be the case, will be the main topic of this course.

In this course, we will learn how MNCs interact with non-market actors, such as governments, by pursuing an integrated approach to strategic management. In an integrated approach, MNCs combine elements from non-market and traditional market strategy. In particular, we will investigate the following questions:
•           Why do companies use non-market strategies?
•           Beyond political actors: What are other important non-market stakeholders?
•           Do, and if so, how do companies gain an advantage by shaping their non-market environment?

After the course, students will have gained a thorough understanding of companies’ non-market contexts. They will have discussed how companies are affected, and how companies can themselves affect, their non-market context.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Knowledge and Understanding: Students on completion of the course will possess …

column2: • Knowledge and understanding of the connections between companies and non-market actors.
• Awareness for the implications of these connections for companies’ strategies.

• Knowledge about the interaction of companies’ resources and capabilities, the non-market context, and the role of companies beyond their original understanding as market actors, i.e. as political and social actors.
• Knowledge of strategic planning techniques that companies use in analyzing the non-market context.
• An understanding of the application of these techniques in a global context.
• Familiarity with examples of successful and less successful strategies.
• Extensive knowledge of cases and major types of strategic decisions in a companies’ non-market context.

column1: Cognitive & Subject Specific Skills: Students on completion of the course will possess:

column2: • Knowledge of the theoretical background, and practical experience in terms of MNC non-market strategies.
• The ability to conduct a strategic analysis in a global stetting, and considering factors beyond the market.
• Understanding of similarities and differences between non-market contexts will improve (not least through working on real-life case studies).
• The ability to take a holistic approach, considering market and non-market factors, to the application of analytical techniques and other strategic tools.
• The know-how to obtain and analyze information which will aid decision making that goes beyond traditional market-focused logics.

column1: Key Skills: Students on completion of the course will possess:

column2: • The ability to use theoretical knowledge for understanding real-world cases.
• The ability to research material related to companies and the non-market context.
• The ability to structure ideas and presentations as members of a team.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The concept of corporate reputation management plays a central role in contemporary business practices. Reputation is viewed as a valuable intangible asset that provides a firm with sustainable competitive advantages. It captures the effects that brands and images have on stakeholders’ evaluations of companies, and contributes to differences in organizational performances. Therefore, building, maintaining and protecting corporate reputation is regarded of great importance by more and more organizations. This research workshop provides an overview of the role of corporate reputation management, focusing on international contexts and new trends in strategic reputation management. Key topics include:

column2: • The conceptualization of corporate reputation in various disciplines;
• The formation and determinants of a favorable reputation;
• The effects of corporate reputation on different stakeholder groups, as well as on social and financial performance of an organization;
• The transformation from reputation research to communication strategy.

column1: The participants will analyze several case studies addressing these topics in class, and design a small scale empirical study. After this course, they are able to assess the value, obstacles and consequences of a corporate reputation strategy, and develop an appropriate research design to empirically examine the effects of a corporate reputation strategy.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 18. Students of the MA programme in Media & Business take priority over other students.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: State-of the art theory on the subject of the workshop.
Common research designs and methods to examine the subject concerned.
Design and execute a small scale empirical study.
Report on their findings in oral and written form.
Evaluate their own work and others' research work.
Critically assess the potential and implications of corporate reputation strategies.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90984,2019,Corporate Restructuring,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. X Welch Guerra, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Corporate Restructuring can broadly be understood as the slicing, dicing and recombining of businesses within and across organizational boundaries. It comes in various forms including spin-offs, sell-offs, equity carve-outs, mergers and acquisitions, or asset swaps, which are carried out in isolation, or as part of a broader restructuring program.

Corporate restructuring activities can represent attempts to rescue a firm from the verge of bankruptcy, responses to unexpected macroeconomic occurrences, or opportunity-driven projects initiated by activist investors, analysts or corporate-level decision makers. Planning and implementing corporate restructuring moves are associated with a high level of uncertainty and complexity. Not only do they frequently fail to reach their intended objectives, they also have far-reaching implications for various stakeholders.

In this course we explore and analyze corporate restructuring from different angles: We review recent research findings and adopt different theoretical lenses to gain a comprehensive understanding of the drivers, characteristics, and implications of corporate restructuring activities from the perspective of various market participants.
Analyzing specific restructuring cases, we shed light on the managerial challenges of planning and implementing restructuring activities.

The teaching methods used in this course consist of lectures, cases, group discussions, and team assignments. Students are expected to come to each session well-prepared by having read the required readings for the session. Attendance is mandatory.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• To gain a theoretical understanding of the drivers and implications of different types of corporate restructuring and an overview of the most relevant research findings on the topic.
• To understand the managerial challenges associated with the initiation and implementation of restructuring activities.
• To develop skills to analyze and evaluate all factors and actors relevant to corporate restructuring situations.
• To gain a nuanced view on corporate restructuring as a societal phenomenon, driven by different fads, pressures and ideologies, with far-reaching implications for many stakeholders.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90055,2019,Corporate Social Investment as a force for positive social change,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. L Roza'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The statistics are very clear and pressing: if we want to reach the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), we still have a funding gap of a $ 2.5 trillion annually.  We therefore need to find further investments in the SDGs and ways to scale the impact as merely financial resources will not suffice. An increasingly relevant player in this field are Corporate Social Investors; e.g. corporate foundations, corporate social impact funds and corporate social accelerators.

Why? Because these CSIs operate in between the business and the ultimate beneficiary and are in the unique situation to leverage corporate resources such as financial means, products, services, technology and the corporate network for the public good. As companies realize that by only pursuing commercial strategies, our wicked problems will not be resolved, an increasing number of companies are implementing non-commercial strategies to contribute to society.

Indeed, CSIs are formalized in a separate legal structure to safeguard that they put social impact at the core of their activities rather than the financial return. As such, CSIs are aimed at “transforming patterns of thought, behaviour, social relationships, institutions, and social structure to generate beneficial outcomes for individuals, communities, organisations, society, and/or the environment beyond the benefits for the instigators of such transformation” (Stephan et al., 2016, p. 1252; italics added).

The aim of this course is to introduce students with Corporate Social Investments where social impact is at the core of the activities, rather than the financial return. We will discuss why are companies pursuing this strategy and set up these CSIs? What is the role of these CSIs in society? What are CSI strategies? What can CSIs do what the company cannot? And, how are these CSIs being managed efficiently and effectively?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After attending the theoretical classes, the practical guestlectures, the debate and after completing the two assignments that this class will offer, the student will be able to:
•    understand why and how businesses choose for non-commercial strategies to create positive social change.
•    explain what the difference is between finance first (or only) and impact first (or only) strategies are and when to pursue one above the other.
•    argue why corporate social investors are needed when companies implement their sustainability agenda (and/or adopt SDGs).
•    apply various theories (mostly organizational behavior theories) around corporate social investment on contemporary managerial issues of corporate social investors.
•    defend an impact-first or impact only strategy that companies may seek in their sustainability portfolio. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This seminar takes an in-depth look at the growing importance (and acceptance) of corporate social responsibility (CSR) as a key reputational asset for organizations of all types. At its crux, CSR is a conversation about the role(s) of business in society and signals a shift in management focus from shareholders to stakeholders. It is estimated that CSR contributes over 40 per cent to corporate reputation, and cognizant of the reputational impact of being socially (ir)responsible, leading organizations are making concerted efforts to do good and be good. Increasingly, firms are embedding CSR in their business strategy and corporate purpose, communicating CSR engagements, and encouraging employee engagement with CSR.
Although CSR now enjoys the status of being a ‘global’ phenomenon, it is, by no means, universal or unitary. Nor are its outcomes always positive.

The course will review the contemporary state of international CSR research from different theoretical lenses; examine intersections with corporate reputation and leadership; highlight the communication imperative for CSR; and reflect on the impact of new media developments on CSR reputation management.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 25. Students of the MA programme in Media & Business take priority over other students.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• The evolution, models, debates, and theories in international CSR scholarship
• The multi-dimensional role of communication in CSR research and practice
• The implications of CSR for reputation and leadership
• Assess the cultural and contextual considerations in CSR strategy and practice
• Analyze the opportunities and challenges in communicating CSR

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87575,2019,Corporate Venturing,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. VJA van de Vrande'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course combines key insights from the areas of strategic management and international business to shed light on the topic of international business strategy.

International business strategy means effectively and efficiently matching a multinational firm’s internal strengths (relative to competitors) with the opportunities and challenges found in institutionally and geographically dispersed environments that cross international borders. Such matching is a requirement for creating value and satisfying stakeholders’ goals, both domestically and internationally, and hence for survival and good performance.

Since globalization has increased both the opportunities and challenges found in the international business environment, forming and executing successful international business strategies has become increasingly complex for firms. Developing and building on a unifying framework of the practitioner-oriented and academic literature on international business strategies, the course familiarizes students with the core concepts and dynamics associated with such strategies, thereby increasing students’ understanding of successful international strategy formation and implementation.
Specific topics that will be covered include:
• The conceptual foundations of international business strategy;
• The nature of home-country location advantages and the problem with host-country location advantages;
• Combining firm-specific advantages and location advantages in a multinational network;
• The dynamics associated with entry modes such as strategic alliances and mergers & acquisitions;
• The influence of local, regional, and worldwide institutions on international strategies;
• New ways of looking at the role of distance in the formation and implementation of international strategies;
• The central role of cross-border knowledge transfer in international strategy implementation;
• The surge of emerging markets and emerging market multinationals, and the rising importance of the base of the pyramid.

The main teaching methods used throughout the course are lectures, instructor-led discussions, and team assignments. Students are expected to come prepared to each class by having studied the required readings and being able to explain and defend their team’s answers to the assignment questions. Accordingly, the classes will to a large extent be interactive.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: The course has the following objectives:
• familiarising students with the key theoretical ideas about international strategy;
• training students in critically evaluating these ideas;
• training students in applying these ideas to business practice through case studies of multinational firms;
• increasing students’ ability to formulate and express their views on the theory and practicalities of international strategy.
• increasing students’ ability to understand, develop, and implement successful international strategies in multinational firms – the overall end goal.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87512,2019,Corporate Venturing: Swimming with Sharks,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['J Duijsters, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: All over the world, firms are being disrupted by fast-moving, innovative startups such as Uber, AirBnB, Spotify and Snapchat. Startups are known for their innovative business models, exciting and promising ideas, and organizational agility. In contrast, large firms have an abundance of resources, scale advantages, power and experience (Weiblen & Chesbrough, 2015). Rather than simply competing, both large firms and startups have started to see the advantages of joining forces, allowing new innovations to emerge.

Through corporate venturing, the corporation may invest in a startup within or outside of the organizational domain (Sharma & Chrisman, 1999). However, despite their promising outlook, corporate venturing activities are often not successful for both the investor and the startup. Because of the potentially high risks and high rewards involved, corporate venturing has been compared to ‘swimming with sharks’. In this course at the intersection of strategy and entrepreneurship, we will therefore focus on both the benefits and challenges of managing a corporate venturing portfolio.

This course aims to bridge the gap between academic literature and real-world situations. Therefore, guest lectures by corporate venturing managers from leading Dutch companies will complement the theoretical part of the course. In order to generate an atmosphere in which students learn through both individual study and class interaction, teaching methods will be varied and include a combination of lectures, class discussions and guest lectures.
The course does not contain an exam. Instead, the grading will consist of an individual assignment (60%) and group project (40%).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: •    To understand how firms can manage corporate venturing.
•    To understand the effect of corporate venturing and corporate venture capital on value creation. How can firms use corporate venturing to spur their own businesses?
•    To understand the tensions and opportunities within a corporate venturing portfolio.
•    To learn how to mitigate some of the risks of corporate venturing.
•    To understand the role of corporate venturing in combination with alliances, mergers and acquisitions, and other external corporate development modes.
•    To apply this knowledge to a real-life situation.

column1: Dit vak is een diepgaande introductie tot de basismiddelen, technieken en theorieën die nodig zijn om te begrijpen hoe binnen de onderneming financiële beslissingen worden genomen. Tijdens dit vak worden onderwerpen behandeld die vooral belangrijk zijn voor beslissingsdoeleinden voor bedrijven. Enkele voorbeelden zijn of er al dan niet in een bepaald project geïnvesteerd moet worden, hoe een investering gefinancierd dient te worden en hoe om te gaan met risico/onzekerheid.

Corporate Finance is een discipline die andere disciplines zoals strategie en marketing ondersteunt. In deze overige disciplines worden vaak vraagstukken gesteld zoals; in welke markten en producten dienen we te investeren? Corporate Finance ondersteunt dit door diverse keuzes te evalueren en te analyseren hoe deze keuzes het beste gefinancierd kunnen worden.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na het volgen van dit vak, moet u in staat zijn tot:

column2: • Het analyseren van financiële beslissingen die ondernemingen maken.
• Het berekenen van de waarde van ondernemingen die met eigen en/of vreemd vermogen zijn gefinancierd aan de hand van relevante kasstromen.
• Het analyseren van de invloed van opties en dividendbeleid op de waarde van de onderneming.
• Het toepassen van complexe financiële instrumenten zoals futures, opties, (converteerbare) obligaties en warrants.
• Het toepassen van belangrijke financiële modellen zoals de koopkrachtpariteit, het internationale Fisher effect en (on)gedekte interest pariteit.
