https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89033,2019,Corporate finance,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MRC Bersem, MSc', 'prof.dr. D Metzger']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course in Corporate Finance deals with two broad and interrelated themes: how to value businesses and corporate investment opportunities; and how to finance corporate investment and activities.

Topics covered include: (1) Financing and financial policy; (2) Valuation; and (3) Advanced topics. The first topic covers the trade-of theory of capital structure, tax benefits, signaling models, as well as key features of the issuance process for various kinds of debt and equity. The second topic organizes standard cash flow-based valuation techniques such as WACC and APV, including assigning an appropriate cost of capital based on a firm's capital structure. We complement these with multiples-based valuation. Other topics are startup financing, initial public offerings, and mergers & acquisitions.
A set of key concepts and theories will be developed and employed throughout.
No formal entry requirements, but a sound undergraduate knowledge of corporate finance is strongly recommended.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After having followed this course, students should be able to:

column2: •     Value a firm, project or investment proposal, including assigning a cost of capital
•     Describe and understand the various types of financial instruments used to finance firms, from an economic, financial and practical point of view
•     Suggest a suitable capital structure for a firm
•     Critically evaluate the effects of agency and information problems on the firms’ financial policies and capital structure
•     Describe typical transaction structures for key types of financial deals, and suggest variations as appropriate.
•     Understand the role of stakeholders in corporate decision-making vis-à-vis financial considerations
•     Read, discuss and report academic journal articles in corporatefinance.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89125,2019,Corporate strategy and growth,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'dr. RAJL van Wijk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Companies are ever more relying on mergers & acquisitions (M&As) and alliances as different modes of corporate development to promote new learning, capability development and value creation. In a world where pressures for globalization, technological developments and time-compression incur a blurring of traditional organizational boundaries, the sets of managerial actions that enable relatively discontinuous changes in corporate growth and scope are a critical element of firm strategy and competitiveness. The past two decades have experienced a dramatic increase in mergers, acquisitions and alliances, both domestically and internationally, but there is also empirical evidence showing that a significant proportion is not giving the expected results.

The objective of this course is to help participants develop a conceptual and practical understanding of the role of acquisitions and alliances in the general context of corporate development. After successfully completing the course, students will have to their availability a toolkit that helps them deal with the nuts and bolts of alliances and acquisitions from a strategic angle. This includes tools to make a choice between acquisitions and alliances based on their pros and cons, as well as to assess their implications and integration into firms’ corporate strategies. Practically, this also involves tools assessing the specific ways in which resources of companies can be integrated to achieve corporate growth, value creation and competitive advantage, while highlighting the pitfalls. The course also pays attention to the managerial challenges alliances and acquisitions pose by addressing the levers of successfully integrating acquisitions, controlling alliances, selecting targets and partners, developing alliance/acquisition capabilities and managing portfolios of alliances and acquisitions, as well as the role of social capital in realizing these. The course develops state-of-the-art understanding of the risks and returns associated with acquisitions and alliances, and the managerial skills and capabilities needed to be successful.

Teaching methods are varied and include a combination of lectures, plenary discussions and group/individual case work. To be able to properly utilize the learning opportunity of this course, students should adequately prepare the material in advance of each workshop as it facilitates the process of group-work and class discussion. In order to create an engaging class atmosphere allowing divergent perspectives to be aired, which is important in courses of this nature, where there are seldom “right” or “wrong” answers, the course is highly interactive in nature and requires a student’s committed participation.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: To develop the ability to make a choice between alliances, mergers and acquisitions, or internal development
To build a firm grasp of how value is created through acquisitions and alliances.
To create expertise in analyzing how social capital is developed and used in corporate development
To develop an ability to choose acquisition target and alliance partner
To create the critical ability to manage integration processes in acquisitions and to design governance structures in alliances
To gain state-of-the-art understanding of how capabilities to acquire and ally are developed and organized so as to manage portfolios of alliances and acquisitions

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course combines key insights from the areas of Strategic Management and International Business to shed light on the topic of international business strategy. International business strategy means effectively and efficiently matching a multinational firm’s internal strengths (relative to competitors) with the opportunities and challenges found in institutionally and geographically dispersed environments that cross international borders. Such matching is a requirement for creating value and satisfying stakeholders’ goals, both domestically and internationally, and hence for survival and good performance.

Since globalization has increased both the opportunities and challenges found in the international business environment, forming and executing successful international business strategies has become increasingly complex for firms. Developing and building on a unifying framework of the practitioner-oriented literature on international business strategies, this course familiarizes students with the core concepts and dynamics associated with such strategies, thereby increasing students’ academic understanding of successful international strategy formation and implementation.

The main teaching methods used throughout the course are lectures, instructor-led discussions, and team assignments. Students are expected to come prepared to each class by having studied the required readings and being able to explain and defend their team’s answers to the assignment questions. Accordingly, the classes will to a large extent be interactive.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: To familiarize students with the key theoretical ideas about international business strategy;
To train students in critically evaluating these ideas;
To train students in applying these ideas to business practice through real-life case studies of multinational firms;
To increase students’ ability to formulate and express their views on the theory and practicalities of international business strategy.
To increase students’ ability to understand, develop, and implement successful international business strategies in multinational firms – the overall end goal.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87441,2019,Corporations and justice,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. BHE Wempe'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

There is fierce debate over the role of markets and the moral limits to the pursuit of profit by modern corporate enterprise. Is there a corporate responsibility beyond making money? Is the ‘free market’ fair? Are there goods which we should not try to provide via the market such as the adoption of children, human organs, or sexual services? What are these goods, and what is wrong with buying and selling them?

These are the questions addressed in this course which starts from a series of online lectures on political theories of justice, from Aristotle to John Rawls given by Harvard professor of government Michael Sandel. In our class meetings in Rotterdam we will refine this framework and apply it to major questions of markets and justice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course students are introduced to four major normative theories of justice. Students learn to appreciate arguments supporting these positions on the basis of a methodology of normative research. In the class discussions students will learn to apply normative frameworks to questions of justice in the market domain and the business world.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In recent years, the concept of creative cities has encapsulated the anticipation of the economic and social benefits of the creative industries and their embeddedness in cities. Cities have traditionally been sites of clustering of cultural activities and creative industries; their cosmopolitan and open character has been celebrated as stimulating innovation in the arts and culture. In this course, we   take a critical look at the complexities and challenges of cultural production and creativity in cities.

Students complete the course by carrying out their own research project. Possible topics include: creative clusters in the city; making and craftsmanship in the city; policies for creativity; inequality in the creative industries.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course’s aims are twofold: firstly, students become familiarized with and critically reflect upon the key concepts and theories on the nexus between creativity, cultural production and cities. Secondly, students apply their knowledge and research skills to conducting a small empirical study on the topic of creative cities, presented in oral and written form.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87029,2019,Creative Economy and Creative Organizations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['KF Karatas, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The economy is changing. Creativity is increasingly seen as a source of competitive advantage and creative assets (such as knowledge, intellectual property, networks, and technology) are increasingly seen as potential generators of economic growth. This course examines this shift in the economy through an organizational lens. Topics include: concepts of creativity; the relationship between creativity and innovation; theories on organizational creativity; distinguishing characteristics of organizations in the creative industries; creative entrepreneurship; how organizations balance the pursuit of creativity against other goals; how managers both foster and (inadvertently) kill creativity; and the nature of creative work, including labor conditions for creative workers.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of an economy based on ideas rather than physical goods and the role of organizations in this creative economy. After the course students will be able to explain how the creative or knowledge economy is different from a goods and services based economy, and how the role of organizations changes accordingly. Students will be able to explain how creative organizations are different from other organizations, and how creativity can be fostered within organizations. After the course students will be able to apply these insights in their analysis of creative organizations in a knowledge-based economy. .</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87064,2019,Creative Industries in the Global Economy,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['JR Fear', 'prof.dr. B Wubs']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Cultural and creative industries are increasingly recognized as important generators of revenues and jobs, as well as powerful drivers of cultural globalization, especially as the world moves into the digital age. One 2015 global survey estimated that they created $2.2 trillion in revenue and around 30 million jobs. Yet they are not new phenomenon. The high profile of multinational media companies is often described as dominance and cultural homogenization, yet it disguises the diversity and multipolar nature of the creative industries. Countries and cities have increasingly identified creative industries as an important means of economic development; cultural branding and have increasingly used historical ""heritage"" as a competitive advantage. We will critically examine the concept of creative industries and the ""creative class,"" how digitalization has made monetization more difficult and altered industry dynamics, and the relationship between cultural industries and development. The course examines why clusters and entrepreneurs emerge at specific points in time (such as Hollywood or Bollywood) and discusses how their competitiveness can be sustained. A special focus will be on how individual firms or clusters in specific places have emerged over time and altered their strategies to redesign themselves for a global digital age.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
·         Students are able to examine critically the concept, history and reality of creative industries.
·         Students understand the particularly dynamics of various creative industries over time, in particular how digitalization is changing these industries.
·         Students can assess and explain how public policy has targeted creative industries as drivers of growth, employment, and development.
·         Students can apply key concepts such as the ""gig economy,"" ""precariat,"" and ""creative class,"" in the analysis of firm-level strategies.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87214,2019,Creative Labour,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. YGD Wijngaarden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Creativity is one of the most desired aspects of modern work and creativity is seen as central to contemporary work practices. Specifically, jobs in the media and cultural industries are often considered to be the most creative of all. The recent interest in the 'creative industries', as well as the rising number of jobs in these sectors call for renewed attention to the nature of creative work in the media. Creativity requires other working conditions and skills than “regular” work and is often organized differently, with a large number of self-employed entrepreneurs and work that often tends to be project-based.

Creative industries’ policies tend to focus on the increase in the number of jobs, based on expanding the conditions for symbolic creativity. For (economic) policy, creativity is objectified as an ‘input’ in order to generate jobs and marketable products – ‘output’. In response, several analysts have pointed to serious problems concerning jobs and professions in these industries, such as uncertainty and 'precariousness'.

In this course we will critically assess the specificities of creative labour and the conditions under which it may thrive. We will identify possible drawbacks and benefits to creative employment and we will look at the nature of creative employment, drawing on contemporary work practices. Students will also gain knowledge and understanding of their future areas of employment.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Upon completion of this course, students will have knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives on creative labour in the media and cultural industries;
• Apply relevant theoretical insights in the analysis of creative labour in the media and cultural industries;
• Critically assess various texts (academic texts, industry reports, policy documents) addressing creative labour;
• Set up an academic argument on creative labour, both verbally and in writing.
• Reflect on and make informed choices regarding their future careers.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90116,2019,Creativity and Innovation in Contemporary Business,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['DE Kiss, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: There is an extensive literature on both creativity and innovation and their relation. The definition of creativity and innovation is overly discussed yet not conclusively. In addition, scholars and practitioners have an ongoing debate on creativity’s relation and influence within human (personal) and business development.

Creativity has its own meaning within education, psychology, business and management, marketing, communications, advertising, arts and entrepreneurship for instance. Depending on which context we take as a framework for creativity, the meaning, the practice and the outcome might differ. The same can be said about when defining what innovation might be. For the same reason, scholars argue for a ‘multidisciplinary definition of innovation’ (Baregheh et al., 2009).

To narrow down the comprehensive reach of creativity and innovation within the 21st century’s context, this seminar will focus on creative thinking (CT) & creative problem solving (CPS) theories, methods and applications in more specific. CT and CPS in a 21st century (business) context will benefit students by introducing, understanding and applying essential contemporary knowledge and skills. Besides CT & CPS being a central 21st century personal skill that is required within the work field, it is also a central practice of businesses in coming up with innovative ideas, improvements and thus solutions for product, service and communication/ human related (business) matters/ challenges.

CT & CPS, both can be related to the ‘creative person’, the creative process, the creative output (products & services) and the creative environment that either facilitates or blocks thus hinders these aspects/ processes. Several (scientific and work) fields can be directly related to these researches and practices. To name a few: Organizational-, business-, product development & communication, organizational and business sustainability, management and leadership-, creativity and innovation studies, communication sciences, (positive) psychology, entrepreneurship, marketing & sales, not to mention people’s career and lives’ in an ever-changing social, societal, economic, political, cultural context. In addition to communication, collaboration is also at the core of CT & CPS processes in a group setting.

Consequently, in this seminar, the focus will be a careful selection of creativity & innovation (CT & CPS) related theories, methods and the practice of those, applicable within several fields of work (and life in general). A solid theoretical backbone will serve for the practical implementation, geared towards a sustainable career development and business operation; product, people and process innovation.

Anahita Baregheh, Jennifer Rowley, Sally Sambrook, (2009) ""Towards a multidisciplinary definition of innovation"", Management Decision, Vol. 47 Issue: 8, pp.1323-1339, https://doi.org/10.1108/00251740910984578

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Essential theories and methods about creativity & innovation in relation to creative thinking (CT) and creative problem solving (CPS) within a globalized 21st century organizational, team and individual context

• Realizing the need for contextual awareness to apply creativity and realize innovation (that is ‘out of the box’), feasible and sustainable (for ex.: understanding the importance of the organizational, team and individual context and realizing the implications of historical, political, socio-economic, (multi / inter) cultural, industry or sector/ field related context)

• Identifying challenges and problems (within an organizational, team and individual setting) and how to differentiate between solvable difficulties to overcome, to transform, and difficulties / situations that need a complete new approach and a solution leaving the ‘old’ behind
• Knowledge of how to effectively produce and communicate (verbally and in writing) creative & innovative ideas, processes and outcomes (consultancy project)

• Understanding the need and benefits of a responsive, open, positive attitude and a curious mind-set, allowing out of the box (creative) ideas or (novel) solutions to emerge that fit the ethical framework of the situation / context
• Understanding the benefits of collaboration and own individual responsibility within a multicultural / intercultural context
• To be able to (re)define, elaborate, refine, analyse, and evaluate one’s own ideas to improve and maximize creative (individual and group) efforts within a multicultural setting

• How to gather (research) and implement methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
• To theorize (research, analyse, write and verbalize) creativity and innovation in a 21st century’s international / multicultural / intercultural business

• To contextualize theoretical knowledge within an empirical framework. Bringing theory into practice: To create novel solutions to existing and or foreseeable (personal, team and multicultural organizational) challenges

• To make judgments on why, where, when and how creativity and/or innovation could take place: To implement the presented methods through which creativity and innovation can be enhanced, fostered, realized and managed within the context of an organization, team, and on an individual level
• To practice critical and analytic skills, while listening, observing, writing, verbalizing the context of multidimensional possibilities within which creativity and innovation can take place

• Understanding the necessity of a high level of interaction, and when necessary (creatively) enhance collaboration to develop, implement, and communicate new ideas to others effectively within an international framework
• To develop a deeper level of self-awareness; to be a critical and creative listener, thinker, ‘actor’;
• To be aware of the need for an open mind-set that fosters every challenge as an opportunity (both within personal and career/ business context)
• To initiate (besides collaborating) creative ideas to find solutions, approaches and gradually realizing own responsibility in relation to the self and within the context of a group of individuals

column1: <body>In dit laatste vak van het eerste jaar wordt het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid centraal gesteld. Hoe wordt dit beleid gemaakt, welke veronderstellingen liggen aan het beleid ten grondslag, wat is de rol van de politiek en van criminaliteitscijfers daarbij?  Welk soort maatregelen wordt door de Gemeente getroffen en welke effecten (bedoelde en onbedoelde) hebben deze? Het is de bedoeling dat de student voor het beantwoorden van deze vragen gebruik maakt van de kennis die hij of zij heeft opgedaan bij de eerdere vakken. Daarnaast moet de student zich grondig verdiepen in het beleid. De student stelt zelf een onderzoeksvraag op en beantwoord deze met behulp van desk research. Het vak criminaliteit en samenleving leert de student als het ware om de eigen leefomgeving door een criminologische bril te bekijken</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na het succesvol afronden van dit blok kun je:

column2: • Betekenissen van definities van concepten als veiligheid in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid identificeren en evalueren;

• Veronderstellingen, doelstellingen en (beleids)theorieën herkennen in het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid en deze kritisch beoordelen op basis van wetenschappelijke juridische en empirische literatuur;
• Kwantitatieve en kwalitatieve databronnen in het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid herkennen en beoordelen;
• Een onderzoeksvraag opstellen gerelateerd aan het Rotterdamse veiligheidsbeleid die te beantwoorden is met bronnenonderzoek (desk research), dit onderzoek uitvoeren en hierover rapporteren;
• Een gestructureerde, samenhangende en kritische analyse schrijven over het Rotterdams veiligheidsbeleid.

column1: <body>In dit vak staan daders en hun criminele carrières centraal.  Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om verschillende soorten criminele carrières te beschrijven en te verklaren aan de hand van verschillende criminologische theoretische perspectieven. Daarbij worden de criminele carrières ook bekeken vanuit het perspectief van de daders zelf, en zullen de verschillende relaties tussen werk en criminaliteit worden bestudeerd. In de hoorcolleges wordt dieper ingegaan op de stof, en zullen meerdere gastdocenten verhalen over de loopbanen van criminelen. Ook zal er een college worden gegeven door iemand die vertelt over zijn eigen criminele carrière. Tijdens het practicum zullen de studenten de carrières van echte criminelen bestuderen, en verschillende concepten uit de literatuur daarop leren toepassen</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Na het volgen van dit blok kun je:

column2: • Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières beschrijven en verklaren.
• Centrale criminologische concepten die samenhangen met het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van criminele carrières benoemen en toepassen op verschillende criminele carrières.
• Het ontstaan, de ontwikkeling en de beëindiging van verschillende criminele carrières vergelijken op hun belangrijkste kenmerken, vragen en verklaringen.
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen uitleggen en duiden van verschillende theoretische en methodologische perspectieven op criminele carrières.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims to develop in students critical analysis, problem solving and research skills in the field of research on criminal justice policies, which will allow students both to be critical consumers of research, and to develop research in this field in practice. First, this course contributes to a better understanding of the key types of evaluation research, the methodological and practical issues involved and it discusses practical solutions for conducting evaluation research in practice. Secondly, students will learn the techniques of risk assessments and qualitative data-analysis and they will learn to critically reflect on those techniques. Thirdly, students will develop an understanding of the ethical dilemma’s involved in conducting criminological research for public policy making. Lastly, it contributes to a better understanding of the ways in which research findings can be transferred into policy making and to an understanding of the limits thereof.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87262,2019,Criminology: a broadening minor. The twilight zone between legal and illegal.,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. G van Eijk', 'prof.dr. LCJ Bisschop', 'RI Timmerman, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: At first sight, crime might seem like an easy concept to grasp, especially when this refers to murder, rape or robbery. However, there are many other phenomena such as corporate malfeasance or drug use that are on a thin line between the legal and the illegal. Some might be criminalized, whereas others might be harmful yet not part of criminal law or other regulations. Discussions about the meaning of crime as well as the social constructivist character of crime are key to any criminology programme. Criminology also sheds light on possible causes as well as consequences of crime for society. This implies that criminology deals with a diversity of possible causes, offenders as well as victims, and also keeps an open mind about the most suitable approach to deal with crime, ranging from criminal law to prevention policy. Criminology is an inherently multidisciplinary social science and bridges insights from sociology, (socio-) legal studies, anthropology, psychology and public management. This is reflected on theoretical, methodological as well as empirical level. Contemporary developments in criminology and in criminal justice and social policies will run as a thread through this minor. Given that much of the developments in contemporary crime are inherently global, we also pay attention to these elements of globalization in view of criminalization, aetiology and approaches to crime, while at the same time not losing track of local particularities of crime. Think for instance of topics such as drug trafficking, human smuggling and (irregular) migration, dumping of waste, cybercrime, terrorism, etc. This minor also takes a critical approach to the study of crime. We deem it essential for criminologists to approach crime phenomena and crime policies with a critical, multidisciplinary and comparative gaze.

This criminology minor is a broadening (1) minor. It is impossible to touch upon all the dynamics of criminology within this minor, but students will be introduced to the core concepts, theories and methods of criminology, to the basics of crime control and prevention and to contemporary developments in the field of crime and justice. Combined with sufficient methodological knowledge, this criminology minor prepares for a successful participation in the regular EUR master Criminology with its focus on crime and the city, globalization, multiculturalism and organizational crime.
1. I.e. it is not open to bachelor students in criminology.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>By the end of this minor, students will be able to:

column2: • Differentiate between different definitions of crime and assess their implications for policy making
• Name and explain the most important criminological research methods and assess their strengths and weaknesses
• Understand the importance of criminological research for criminal justice and social policy
• Compare different theoretical approaches to crime in terms of research questions, hypotheses and levels of analysis
• Discuss the strengths and weaknesses of criminological theories based on research findings
• Apply the key criminological theories to specific criminological phenomena and current issues
• Describe the objectives of different approaches to crime
• Discuss questions of effectiveness and justice of different approaches to crime
• Describe recent developments in the field of criminology

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course ‘Critical Studies of Management and Innovation’ offers an introduction to the master Health Care Management. It builds on previously discussed themes, such as organizational sociology and strategic management. In this course, students study processes of management and innovation in organizational settings; drawing from and critically assessing different – sometimes contradictory – theoretical perspectives.

What innovation and management are and how it should be done, is subject of scientific debate. Different authors describe, analyse and reflect on innovation and management from different (theoretical) perspectives. This course is all about: (I) learning to recognize such types of theoretical difference; and (II) about being able to critically reflect on their implications. Which theoretical perspectives do authors take? Which concepts do they use? What do they emphasize? And what are the consequences of their views for understanding organizational change processes? It is important for students to understand such differences, because it allows them to recognize, question and critically reflect on the –  sometimes implicit – theoretical perspectives and assumptions underlying health care policies and management.

Next to its theoretical foundation, the course also has an empirical dimension. The different cases that will be discussed and analyzed focus on change processes that are currently taking place in the healthcare setting: e.g. the changing role(s) of patients; the introduction of new technologies; the development of new professional roles; the introduction of new forms of organizational performance management; and external accounting for quality. Who should you involve in the development or introduction of a a new technology? How should you deal with the reactions to such changes on the workfloor? How radical should a change be? Should you introduce changes step-by-step (incrementally) or just at once (radically)? Precisely because these types of questions have no clear answers, it is vital to gain insight into the different approaches and arguments that are put forward in the literature.

The lectures will therefore be geared towards exploring empirical problems and towards introducing different theoretical perspectives in order to analyze such problems. In the workgroup meetings, students are expected to discuss these different theoretical perspectives in-depth and relate them to specific change process in the healthcare setting. In addition, students train their academic writing skills and practice how to compose a scientific argument through bi-weekly essays. In line with these objectives, the exam is conducted in the form of a final essay.

I van Oorschot', 'dr. JF van Houdt', 'dr. JP Kloeg', 'dr. MJ Kruithof', 'dr. R van den Akker', 'JI Wildschut', 'S Koevoets', 'T de Groot, MPhil', 'WM van Baalen, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course introduces students to critical theory and aims to equip students with the conceptual tools forged by some of the major scholars working in the critical tradition such as Horkheimer, Adorno and Marcuse (The Frankfurt School), Althusser, Foucault, Deleuze & Guattari (The Paris School) and Williams, Hall and Gilroy (The Birmingham School). Students learn to apply critical theory as a “martial art”: a means of self-defence against discursive and non-discursive structures of violence without having the right for unfair attacks (i.e., submission to the rules of responsible speech). The course provides students with the necessary historical and theoretical background needed to understand later developments in the fields of critical theory and cultural analysis (as offered by the various majors in the Humanities) and the skills to become “Critical World Citizens” in the present.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • have basic knowledge of the foundational schools and thinkers of critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the main concepts and theories used in critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the historical context of the main thinkers and theories used in critical theory;
• have a basic understanding of the various intersections of class, race, gender and nature that undergird the critical theories studied in this course.
• be able to apply critical theory to domains as varied as science, education, culture, media, and sports.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86923,2019,Critique: The Impact of Philosophy on Social Sciences and Humanities,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. M Huijer'],,Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What is critical thinking? What is its function in an era of ‘alternative facts’? This module explores some of the most important post-war continental social-philosophical theories and their consequences for disciplinary thinking in the humanities and social sciences. Guiding notion is that of critique, as developed by the Frankfurt School. We investigate the relation between society and the knowledge produced and methods used by social sciences and humanities (but also by medical and environmental sciences). We focus on critical theory (Habermas, Frankfurt School), poststructuralism (Foucault), feminist critique, postcolonial critique, tentacular thinking (Haraway) and critical realism (Latour).

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• being able to reflect critically on the various roles that scientific knowledge plays in society
• being able to analyse and evaluate the different kinds of critique, both historically and systematically
• understanding the methodology of philosophical critique with regard to social sciences and humanities, and assessing its relevance for society

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87466,2019,Cross-cultural Management,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. MJ Flory', 'JJ Werkhoven, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Cross-cultural competence is about professional ability to make sense of actions and complexities, which require comparison of values, norms and actions (verbal, material, symbolic, etcetera). Future managers must be able to perform a multidimensional analysis of an emergent mix of interactive, communicative and organizing processes – in order to make sense of them, in order to help others understand them, in order to perform efficiently and effectively.

Cross-cultural competence allows us to understand what individuals mean by words and acts. Dialogical turn in hyper-connected societies of mobile individuals requires a more coaching and servant leadership based type of managers. Students will exercise their methodological skills in deconstructing and changing complex adaptive systems by rhetoric, design, and contextual shifts. Students have to learn how to perform a quick cultural scan of organisations and compare the results across national, organisational, and professional fault lines. We shall also ask students to hone their skills in cross-cultural analysis by submitting a comprehensive team assignment, which will include a case study, an empirical research and formatted media communication releases.

This year, the course focuses specifically on the Latin-American cultures. These countries know a turbulent, often violent history, with democratic yet unstable governments and a developing economy. In many cases, the Latin-American countries are still unfolding their own identity. In order to understand these cultures, we cannot judge them by applying cultural models, which are developed based on our westers standards. Instead, we should do so by watching their movies, reading their books, seeing their art and, most importantly, by engaging in conversation. In a team the students will analyse a country on the historical, cultural and economic background, with the aim to a consultancy report for a Dutch company which would like to do business in Latin-America.
Plenary lectures will introduce students to the basic concepts of cross cultural competence and to the critical cases of culture-driven tensions, conflicts, synergies, and complexities.
During the interactive lectures students will learn how cultural differences are always present in our daily life, by making use of the method of experiential learning.
Team presentations will enable students to demonstrate their knowledge and insights on cross-cultural differences.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course, you should be able of the following:

column2: Judging cultural models and evaluate them in different contexts and to reflect on the impact of these models.
Performing cross-cultural diagnosis in a real-life practice, thus by comparing different countries developing cross-cultural competence.
Investigating a countries' culture by analysing its history and art.
Distinguishing own perceptions by experimenting with observations and to reflect on one’s own behaviour and attitude.
Understanding the differences in country cultures and what it is you need to know as a global manager.
Diagnosing and analyse cross-cultural processes for individual and collective sense making in organizations.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87506,2019,Cross-sector Partnerships for Sustainable Development,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AM Schouten', 'dr. M Faling']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Many practitioners and academics alike argue that complex societal challenges, including sustainable development, require collaborative processes between different sectors of society (state, market, and civil society). Cross-sector partnerships are therefore also an important part of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) agenda and even have their own goal: the 17th SDG is to ‘strengthen the means of implementation and revitalize the global partnership for sustainable development’. Despite all the positive rhetoric on cross-sector partnerships, critical voices point to their limited success in addressing the systemic causes underlying the severe sustainability challenges of our times. In this course, participants are therefore encouraged to critically analyze the concept of cross-sector partnerships, their role in sustainable development and their possible impact and frailties. As such, the course builds specifically on the core courses Sustainability Grand Challenges and Global Business Strategies, where collaboration for sustainability is introduced. This course, however, focuses on cross-sector partnerships not necessarily from a business perspective, but rather form a multi-actor perspective.

In the course, participants are stimulated to critically look at the drivers of cross-sector partnerships, explore different types of cross-sector partnerships and the process of navigating these, carefully assess the interlinkages between partnerships and sustainable development, and view partnerships as new forms of governance and explore issues of legitimacy and democracy. An important element of this course is the link between theoretical concepts and their practical relevance and case studies therefore play an important role. This course is developed and taught by staff of the Partnerships Resource Centre (PrC), a specialist research centre at Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University. The PrC connects scientifically sound research and practitioner experience of cross-sector partnerships to aid sustainable and inclusive development.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing this course, participants will be able to:

column2: Explain the concept of cross-sector partnerships for sustainable development;
Classify the different drivers and challenges of cross-sector partnerships;
Distinguish between different types of cross-sector partnerships;
Apply theoretical knowledge about partnerships for sustainable development to real-world situations;
Explain the interlinkages between partnerships and sustainable development;
Analyze cross-sector partnerships from different theoretical perspectives;
Critically reflect on the idea of partnerships for sustainable development.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85723,2019,Crosscultural Psychology -Fundamentals and Ethnic Differences,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MJ Gorgievski', 'prof.dr. MPh Born']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: With increasing globalization, we get in touch with different cultures more and more. In a city such as Rotterdam, where people from over a 100 countries live and work, knowledge and skills in cross-cultural contacts have become essential. This minor deals with various important themes across psychological disciplines, including emotions and psychopathology in different cultures, cultural differences in education and in attachment, working in intercultural teams, well-being of expatriates and immigrants, and problems in conducting cross-cultural research and assessment.

This minor is intended for all students who are interested in intercultural issues and in psychology. The minor aims to increase students’ awareness of cultural differences and contributes to the development of a broader academic attitude. Working during the course with students from diverse cultural backgrounds will deepen students’ knowledge through experiencing different cultural backgrounds and viewpoints themselves.

This minor is intended for all students who are interested in intercultural issues and in psychology. The minor aims to increase students’ awareness of cultural differences and contributes to the development of a broader academic attitude.

The minor will be open for international students. For this reason, all the material and activities will be in English. The language used in all tutorial groups will in principle be English. It will be possible to answer open ended questions on the exam in Dutch.

Students from all educational backgrounds are admissible for this minor. Students who do not have a background in psychology need to be aware they may need to put in extra effort in order to master the material and understand the underlying psychological principles. Students who do not have a background in problem-based learning (PBL) will need to be aware of the fact that the didactical model of PBL will be used in this course. Before the course, a short introduction will be provided on PBL for these students.

In this module we will study the main themes within cross-cultural psychology. Classic concepts in this domain will be discussed, as well as the factors that need to be considered when performing and interpreting cross-cultural research. Themes that are subsequently treated are: cultural differences and similarities in cognitions, emotions and autobiographical memory, how normal and abnormal behavior is perceived in different cultures, and cross-cultural issues related to society and work. Examples belonging to this last theme are experiences of expatriates, and preferred leadership styles across cultures.
Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures
Teaching materials: Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.

In Module 2, students learn about issues related to ethnic differences professionals may encounter when dealing with people from different cultural backgrounds in practice. Here one can think of topics such as: the role of ethnicity in diagnostics and treatment of psychopathology, immigrants’ study success, the influence of migration on mental health, discrimination at work, and the position of immigrants on the labour market.
Teaching method(s): Problem Based learning: Tutorial groups, self-study and lectures
Teaching materials:  Recent journal articles and book chapters, provided on the internet.

Modules 1 and 2 will be closed with a separate exam each. The exam consists of 50 statements (true/false) and 16 short-answer open-end questions. In addition, during Modules 1 and 2 you will work in couples to prepare a presentation. During the last tutorial meeting of module 2, you will present to the students in your tutorial group.
The final grade will be a weighted average of both Exam part 1 and Exam part 2, plus the grade for the presentation (weights 2 + 2 + 1).

In order to pass the course, the minimum weighted average of both Exam Part 1, Exam Part 2 must be a 5.5. Each exam separately (Part 1 and Part 2), needs to be graded with a 5.0 at minimum. That means students can to some extent compensate an insufficient grade for one part of the minor. In addition, the assessment of the final presentation needs to be a 5.5 or higher.
Students will be offered the possibility to review their answers for each part of the exam shortly after the grades have been announced.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Students gain insight into the following overarching themes: cross-cultural differences in child development, cognitions, emotions, personality, intelligence, psychopathology and the meaning of working.
• Students gain insight into methodological issues that play a role when conducting cross-cultural research.
• Students gain insight into ethnic differences and similarities in the domains of (mental) health care, education and the labour market.
• Students gain insight into the processes playing a role in stereotyping and discrimination.
• Students gain insight into effective behaviour in intercultural situations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The seminars deals with the problems of doing empirical research: how scholars have tested theories, what methods and data sources have been used, how scholars overcame the problems encountered in empirical research, what are the main limitations of their empirical works, and so on. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic and reading material. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature and to summarise it for discussion in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students therefore learn to appreciate standards of research and how to conduct their own research later on.

Topics covered in the course, among others: cultural policies; cultural heritage; cultural demand; artists' labour markets; culture, economy and cities; (temporary) clusters and intermediaries.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86991,2019,Cultural Economics: Theory,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. CW Handke', 'dr. E Dekker']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: For better or for worse, economics is a most influential theory of human behavior and a popular tool for rationalizing decisions. Economic perspectives and arguments are important in debates on public policy of almost any kind. Decision-makers in businesses draw heavily on aspects of economic theory. Economic reasoning is also increasingly employed in the cultural sector. In this course, we discuss the theoretical underpinnings of cultural economics, to help students in harnessing economics for their own purposes.

We do so by discussing ‘classic’ theoretical issues and debates that illuminate the foundations of economics. We begin with two fundamental aspects of economics, price theory and welfare economics, as well as their limitations. We continue with four main themes in cultural economics: (1) public goods, (2) intrinsic motivation, (3) uncertainty and taste formation, as well as (4) superstars. We round off the course with a discussion of economic perspectives on entrepreneurship.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>This course will help you to better understand the foundations of economics in general. You will develop an overview of the main themes in cultural economics. We encourage a critical, but constructive approach to the application of economics for decision-making in the cultural sector. Usually, the question is not whether economics is perfect but whether there is a superior alternative for a specific purpose, for instance to structure your thoughts, to interpret empirical evidence and to prepare your own empirical research or to convince others. All of this will serve you as a solid basis for subsequent courses, and help you define your specific areas of interest in further stages of the M.A. in Cultural Economics & Entrepreneurship.</body>

column1: The seminar builds on the Cultural Entrepreneurship: Theory course in Term 1. Students will select areas of special interest for weekly assignments, and will become familiar with and evaluate how cultural entrepreneurship scholars research the field.  The seminars will deal with the problems of doing empirical research: how scholars have tested theories, what methods and data sources have been used, how scholars overcame the problems encountered in empirical research, what are the main limitations of their empirical works, and so on. The study of entrepreneurship in practice is included as well: by means of case studies or ethnographic methods, students will get acquainted with an entrepreneur and gather data that inform their research.Topics covered in the course, among others: entrepreneurial intention, careers, performance, networks andinnovation,.

The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic and reading material. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature and to summarize it for discussion in class. A critical approach is encouraged. Students therefore learn to appreciate standards of research and how to conduct their own research later on, which they will present in class and a final paper.</body>

column1: The notion of “entrepreneurship” is commonly associated with the discovery and pursuit of new business opportunities through the creation of firms. The ultimate aim of entrepreneurial activity is seldom profit or personal wealth-creation, but rather realizing new ideas and being free from restraints. Similarly, artistic and creative work is often about the introduction of novelty, and artists and creative professionals seek to create the conditions and to overcome the barriers to be able to develop works of art and creative goods or services.

Different approaches to and theories on entrepreneurship coincide, that we will explore during this course. The series of lectures in term 1 will introduce students to the diverse facets of the entrepreneurship literature, yet, not without making the necessary connections to the practice of entrepreneurship within the cultural and creative industries. We do so by specialist readings, exercises, a guest lecture and a study trip to a site of interest in the area. The course introduces students to professional research in cultural entrepreneurship and teaches how to critically engage with this literature. Topics of the course include (but are not limited to):

column2: • Entrepreneurship: is it about traits or skills?
• Organized creativity: how to develop, foster and maintain creativity in organizations?
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The aim of this course is to offer an advanced training in cultural entrepreneurship by surveying the field of (cultural) entrepreneurship. It provides students with a solid background in the subject as a basis for subsequent courses and it enables them to select areas of special interest to pursue during the MA.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86956,2019,Cultural Heritage Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. SL Reijnders'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The scientific study of cultural heritage has developed significantly in recent decades. Not only has the interest in this subject grown explosively, also what is exactly meant by 'cultural heritage' has been changing rapidly.

Until recently, attention was focused mainly on forms of material culture of seemingly undisputed value, such as museum artifacts, monuments, and archaeological sites. However, the concept of cultural heritage has broadened considerably. It now also includes intangible forms of culture, such as rituals, customs, and traditions, which are usually associated with non-Western cultures and traditional folk culture. At the same time, within the heritage sector there is a noticeable growing interest in the role of (new) media in the creation and (re)presentation of a shared past.

The course Cultural Heritage Studies offers students an introduction to the above developments. Students take note of recent publications in these fields, do their own research - both individually and in groups - and present their findings during class meetings. For students in Arts and Culture Studies, this course provides an introduction to the heritage branch in the program and elucidates the canonization of arts and culture. Students in History and Media & Communication Studies with an interest in the handling of the present with the past will find this course a welcome addition to their usual curriculum.
NB the maximum number of participants in this course is 25.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of this course is to gain knowledge and an understanding of cultural heritage, in particular relating to contemporary developments within the field of heritage studies. This insight is obtained by a) critically examining, summarizing and presenting current, scientific literature; b) applying this literature to concrete examples.</body>

column1: In recent years, mainly with the advent of digital technology, new media platforms and transnational media networks have become central in the study of cultural identity and acculturation processes. New media is redefining the meaning of cultural identity and shaping the integration experiences of different ethnic migrant groups in European Western societies and elsewhere. The purpose of this course is to unravel the intricate relationships between new media, in, and cultural identity and acculturation through the process of definition, interpretation, and critical analysis. We examine the relationships between new technologies and cultural identity from the perspective of migration, focusing on community networks to explain the new dynamics of connection and bond formation among migrants, and the development of transnational socializing in online environments. Furthermore, we also focus on the analysis of the various ways in which (ethnic) migrant groups and institutions are currently using such new technologies and the implications of these practices for their adaptation experiences in their entirety
Note: This course is not accessible for students who have already completed the CM2038 course.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Theoretical perspectives on the study of cultural identity and its key concepts.
• The main theoretical and practical perspectives on the mediating role of new technologies in the relationship between cultural identity and acculturation processes.

column1: Students have the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Critically analyze new media as platforms for communication that are increasingly being utilized by different immigrant groups as part of their integration into the new cultural environment, but also taking into account that these communication processes may vary across and within ‘migrant groups’ in the context of public (work, politics, economics, social) and private domains (family, religion and ways of thinking).
• Apply different theoretical aspects on cultural identity to a more nuanced understanding of immigrant experiences in online environments.
• Analyze and reflect upon digital initiatives focusing on the adaptation experiences of migrants and refugees in relation to identity negotiations and media use.
• Report and present research findings in a clear, organized style.

We will study the impact of culture on communication processes in various domains such as time, space, verbal and non verbal communication. We will also analyze major research frameworks and methods as they are applied to the field of cultural differences in communication. Through discussion of intercultural issues and through analysis of numerous real-life cases with the help of visual materials (photographs, videos) and texts, we will improve our own cross-cultural understanding and our intercultural communication skills.
