They will also develop an open attitude to cultures that are, potentially, very different from their own.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86965,2019,Cultural Lifestyles and Participation,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. J Michael'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This research workshop focuses on the relation between theory and research in the domain of cultural participation taken in the broad sense. The questions to be addressed can be summarized as: who engages in which cultural activities and why? Students formulate questions about (specific forms or patterns of leisure or) cultural participation and its relation to people’s socioeconomic background characteristics and formulate hypotheses on the basis of the relevant literature.

Subsequently, they employ data made available by the lecturer to test their hypotheses on social differentiation in cultural participation (be it museum visits, concert or theatre attendance, TV watching, reading, going out, etc), Statistical techniques for causal analysis will be used in order to determine which characteristics of respondents are actually determining their cultural taste or behavior.

Students produce a research report (individually or in duos) that includes a concise literature review on the topic to be analyzed, and a presentation and discussion of the statistical analyses carried out.
It is recommended to take this course only after the Statistics course has been completed successfully.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In this course, students learn to answer questions about cultural participation by analyzing existing quantitative data. After this research workshop, they are able to translate substantial questions into adequate statistical analyses and produce a sound report of their work. They learn to critically reflect on the (im)possibilities of empirical research and to interpret their results in light of the original research questions.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86966,2019,Cultural Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. V Morea', 'L Marques']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course will provide students an understanding of management in the cultural sector. The starting point of view is that cultural organizations such as museums, venues, musical societies, theatre companies, and other creative enterprises possess particular characteristics from an organizational point-of- view that influence the way they operate. Cultural/arts management has developed as a full-fledged discipline. Cultural organizations increasingly need to develop management strategies to realize their objectives, paying attention to their potential visitors-audiences-users, and to the financial constraints that may hinder their activities. The cases selected by the students will be used to study and illustrate the impact that strategic management can have on the performance of cultural institutions. Students will have to apply the theoretical framework to cultural organizations in order to see how theory translates into reality.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This research workshop will familiarize students with the management of cultural organizations by case study research methods. They learn to connect theory to practice by conducting their own small research project about an existing cultural organization.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86988,2019,Cultural Management,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['L Marques', 'UZ Birsel - Birsel']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will cover the main components of the arts and cultural management, including business planning, marketing, fundraising, production, governance and the bifurcated leadership structures (so often found in arts organisations). Properly researched case studies from international practice will be used to make the peculiarities of the management of arts and cultural organisations clear.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Arts and cultural organisations are in important respects different from other organisations. The goal of this course is to introduce the student to the principles of cultural  management. Here the particular and peculiar questions of management of arts and cultural organisations will be explored.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86996,2019,Cultural Organisations,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. JA Do Carmo Junior', 'prof.dr. A Klamer']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The production of art and other creative products usually requires some organisation or another. The question is whether creative organisations have special characteristics. How different are they from commercial organizations? What is a good mission? What is a relevant vision? What are appropriate strategies?  How to evaluate? We will discuss various cases and students will apply in small groups concepts and insights to a particular case. At the end of the course they will present their findings.

In terms of theoretical perspective, the course follows the value based approach. The culture of creative organisations will one of the topics as well as the variety of organisational forms, the consequences of financial strategies for the organization and the culture of an organisation.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Why do people organize? Why don’t people do “it” alone? Why do people submit themselves to organisations? And why do creative people do so?

We want to understand how creative organisations  work, why  they  work so differently, what difference an ideal can make (as for non-profit or, better, social organisations), why  concepts  such as values, logics, cultural capital, creativity and cultural entrepreneurship are useful for thinking about creative organisations. The objectives are a) to learn about creative organisations, b) to prepare for future research on creative organizations, and c) to prepare for working with or for creative organizations.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86979,2019,Cultural Policy,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. LE Braden'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: This course takes a global perspective in exploring the theoretical social context of cultural policy with examples from European cultural strategy, though policy in the United States and other parts of the world are also examined. Classes are grounded in sociological theory and knowledge will be extended and enhanced through empirical research.  Emphasis is on the various dilemmas facing those who create, study, and work with cultural policy. Topics covered include how culture is defined, what is considered legitimate and consequently worthy of state support; art’s growing position in the marketplace; how globalization may affect local and national culture; the organizational needs of managers versus the creative needs of artists; how consumption practices influence policy and policy’s effect on cultural participation and education. We end the course considering how cultural policy has shifted to match changing cultural and social values.

The course is for advanced students interested in academic or applied careers in arts, culture, and public policy. In exploring various forms of culture and cultural research, the course cuts across disciplines, including economics, humanities, and social-psychology, though is grounded primarily in sociological theory and methodology. This course is a seminar and, consequently, the class work is a combination of lecture, discussion, class exercises and student presentation. Students will contribute to the content of the course through discussion and presentation of case studies that serve as exemplars. In this way, the class is research intensive, relying on student interests to direct the exploration of the course's main themes. The class is conducted entirely in English and students are required to discuss and report in every class.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Students will learn to distinguish the main policy concerns debated by academics and those involved in cultural policy creation and research. Students will be able to address these concerns through a foundation of cultural and organizational sociological theory and empirical research. Finally, students will be able to link concepts considered in class to the broader social context and current courses of action.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87229,2019,Cultural Sociology,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. J Peters', 'prof.dr. PPL Berkers']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing – yet fuzzily bounded – areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology is witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’ in a broad sense) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas, such as politics, economy, the state, etc. However, as ‘culture’ is difficult, if not impossible, to define, discussions often lack conceptual clarity, leading to truisms like ‘culture matters’.

This course addresses major theories and contemporary debates in cultural sociology. Besides discussing classical sociological traditions (Marx, Durkheim, Weber) and conceptions of culture, we will discern six ideal typical approaches in cultural sociology: (1) culture as an instrument of power (neo-Marxism and conflict sociology), (2) culture as (cognitive) structure (neo-Durkheimian sociology and structuralism), (3) culture as meaningful action (neo-Weberian sociology and rationalization), (4) culture as a product of social interaction (symbolic interactionism and ethnomethodology), (5) cultural as signification (semiotics) and (6) culture as embodied practice (practice and performance theory).

While most contemporary research usually draws on several of these approaches, we aim to provide a degree of intellectual clarity by disaggregating these traditions. Including both classical theories as well as related contemporary empirical studies, this course will stimulate systematic and critical sociological thinking, and provide a necessary compass to navigate current debates in cultural sociology. </body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Current theoretical insights, academic debates and approaches in the sociological thinking about culture
• Reproduce and contextualize contemporary theories, insights, and academic debates in cultural sociology
• Apply relevant cultural sociological theories and concepts to empirical reality

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87002,2019,Cultural Sociology of Tourism,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course is founded in a cultural sociological approach to the phenomenon of tourism, focusing on key concepts and theories which are relevant in the study of tourism as embedded in wider socio-cultural context in which they occur and acquire significance. First, the course will address both seminal theories as well as cutting-edge research on the historical development of tourism, paying particular attention to the underlying interests, activities and concerns which are attached to this phenomenon in its respective context. Moving from tourism and travel in pre-modernity, via the massification of tourism during modernity towards the contemporary nichification of tourism in postmodernity, the course will illuminate central issues related to the practice of tourism in relation to the particular ‘Zeitgeist’ in which it occurs. Second, the course will dive into the practices, motivations and experiences of the tourists themselves, scrutinizing the meanings that they attribute to their travels to and interactions with foreign locations and localities. Third, the destinations of tourists and locals will be of focus, particularly related to transformations of place, host-tourist relationships and issues related to sustainability, both in terms of preserving local culture, economy and the environment. Fourth, rising middle-classes in rapidly developing countries are increasingly having an impact on global tourism flows, resulting in a huge influx of tourists from a plethora of socio-cultural backgrounds, bringing in new opportunities, challenges and considerations. Last, the ever-increasing ubiquity of popular and digital media are brought in dialogue with contemporary and future tourism practices.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The main aim of this course is to teach students the basics and fundamental knowledge from the field of tourism from a cultural sociological perspective. Through working with a combination of seminal works in this field as well as more state of the art research, students learn to analyze tourism and related practices within the wider socio-cultural and political contexts in which they occur. In doing so, students will be able to reproduce and contextualize important insights, theories and concepts related to a cultural sociological of tourism. In addition, students will be able to critically and systematically analyse complex socio-cultural processes underlying the evolution of tourism in an age characterized by ongoing processes of globalization, mediation and digitization.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86960,2019,Cultural Studies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SR Driessen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: From art to advertising and from power to politics, cultural studies have inspired and influenced many contemporary debates in society. In this course, we will delve into the ever-expanding field of cultural studies. We will discuss its history and explore classical cultural studies concepts like representation, gender, and race. Also, we will investigate the contemporary value of cultural studies as a field of research and discover emerging concepts and ideas. In doing this, we will move across different media and genres like art, film, literature, music and photography. Part of the classes will be devoted to critically analysing objects selected by students. With the help of guest lectures we will experience how cultural theories are nowadays used in practice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims to familiarize students with the different theoretical traditions and perspectives in the broad field of cultural studies. Students learn to critically examine theories and concepts deriving from cultural studies, and are able to use them in the analysis of contemporary cultural objects. They will learn to present their analyses in a clear and convincing way, both orally and in writing.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86942,2019,Cultural and Creative Industries,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TA Calkins III'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course is oriented towards developing the understanding of the production and consumption of culture in contemporary societies. It will look at practical aspects of the organization and financing of cultural industries and discuss how these affect the type of art that is created and the cultural products that reach the audiences. Students will be introduced to the key sociological and the cultural economics concepts and theories that help to understand the functioning of cultural and creative industries. In order to highlight the relevance of discussed theoretical perspectives, the lectures will bring in empirical examples from the range of cultural industries taking diverse positions in the arts economy and consider both commercial and non-profit organizations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course aims at providing students with the basic understanding of the functioning of cultural and creative industries. The lectures introduce the sociological and cultural economics perspectives on the functioning of “high arts” (e.g. contemporary visual art and theatre) and “popular” industries (e.g. film and television) and provide conceptual frameworks to better understand recent developments in cultural industries across sectors and cross-nationally. It deals with applying the theoretical knowledge to real empirical cases by discussing the recent issues and developments in specific cultural organizations or creative fields more generally. The knowledge on the functioning of creative industries offers a useful frame of reference for the remainder of the bachelor program.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87203,2019,Culture Online,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. MNM Verboord'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: There is little dispute that the rise of digital technologies – file-sharing software, Internet, smart phones, etc. – has radically transformed cultural markets in the past decades concerning consumers’ purchasing modes, companies’ business models, impact of experts, and overall power relations. What the precise consequences of these transformations are, and will be in the long run, is less evident.

This research workshop focuses on the material and symbolic production of culture in online contexts. We will pay compare traditional and new business models in cultural production; transformations in how audiences find and consume cultural products; and changes in symbolic production of culture associated with new media (including the role of user-generated content).

Students conduct a small research on one of these themes. They formulate a research question, seek appropriate literature, and collect and analyze data to answer their research question. All research questions need to have an explanatory and/or comparative element.

Students can choose to (a) use survey data on how consumers access music, books, or audiovisual materials in Europe (made available by the lecturer), (b) conduct a content analysis of reviews or social media posts, or (c) collect online data on ratings, downloads, or other indicators of popularity.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: •             State-of the art theory on the topic of material and symbolic production of culture in online contexts.
•             Common research designs and methods to examine this topic.
•             Design and execute a small scale empirical study on the topic of culture online.
•             Report on their findings in oral and written form.
•             Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research.
•             Constructively work as part of a team

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87178,2019,Culture, New Media and International Business",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>In international business, it is crucial that the use of various media for internal and external corporate communication is aligned to its own cultural context. This course will analyze the cultural dimensions of international business communication, for instance, how various mobile channels are adopted and perceived in distinct cultural contexts, or how social media could be used to create cohesive groups with their own values and culture. An in-depth understanding of the interplay between culture and media can lead to effective practices to achieve communicative goals in cross-cultural contexts, which is vital for the success of multinational companies. Through case studies, this course will discuss cultural issues in cross-cultural marketing, branding, public relations, and organizational communication. Theories and practical implications supported by empirical case studies will also be introduced to students to build their knowledge base that can inform practice.</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Academic perspectives on the importance of culture in international business communication.
• Research on the perception and uses of media in different cultural contexts.
• The interplay between culture and media in an international business settings.
• How new media may shape and change social networks and culture.
• Effectively apply various media for international business with cultural sensitivity.
• Strategically use social media to form groups, shape cultures, and maintain social networks that can promote international business.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89078,2019,Current Issues in HRM,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. HMS Dietz'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Agenda’s of senior human resource executives of both local and multinational firms are crammed with countless issues. Parallel to this is a growing body of scholarly research on human resource related topics published and presented in journals and conferences around the world. What are the relevant lessons from within human resource research that these managers can learn from, and how can they benefit from this?

Triggered by this question, the present course identifies a number of essential ‘current issues in human resource management’ and takes these issues as a starting point for classroom discussion and learning. Building on concepts from the neighbouring sciences of Organisational Behaviour and Strategic Management, it discusses such topics as: (1) Performance Management, (2) Electronic & Web-Based HRM, (3) Performing necessary evils to employees, (4) The strategic position of most senior human resource officials in the firm, and (5) Emotional Intelligence.
The assessment elements that constitute the final grade are threefold:
(1) Lecture Assignments, (2) Team Report, and (3) Final Exam.

These three elements will respectively count for 10%, 30% and 60% in calculating the final grade. The lecture assignments will be short individual essays on cases (about 2 pages) and will be graded pass/fail. The team report will assess the ability to apply literature to a practical problem. The final exam will be a closed book exam on the content of this course, including the literature, lectures and guest lectures. The exam will consist of 18 MC questions about the literature (3 questions for each of the 6 topics. Each question will have 4 alternatives) and 3 open-ended questions related to the 6 business cases discussed in class (each open question will have an a, b, and c sub question). The MC and open questions parts of the exam will respectively count for 1/3 and 2/3 of the exam grade. The goal of the exam is to assess: (a) knowledge of the literature, and (b) ability to connect the literature to real life management issues.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Learning goals: The course has the following learning goals:

column2: • To develop insight in issues that are currently considered to be at the cutting-edge of human resource management research
• To develop the conceptual skills needed to diagnose business issues and develop human resource interventions geared to increase business performance
• Understand the dynamics of power and influence necessary ‘to make things happen’ for human resource professionals
• To provide an insight in antecedents and consequences of dynamics in the human resource functions inside firms.

column1: This HRM core course is constructive for those students who will be senior HR executives in charge of setting the corporate HR agenda. In addition, students who will be held accountable for business performance in its broadest sense are likely to benefit from the course.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87118,2019,Current Perspectives on Popular Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SMR Driessen'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: What can superhero movies like Black Panther teach us about today’s society? Or series like the Handmaid’s Tale or Black Mirror? What is the cultural value of memes? Should we study Donald Trump as a celebrity instead of as a politician? And what can pop culture teach us about (uncovering) “fake news”?

As a form of entertainment for the masses, popular culture has always played a key role in society. But, what if we looked at it beyond being ‘just entertainment’? Often popular culture illustrates, reflects on, and helps to better understand the world we live in through representing or questioning societal changes that take place. In this seminar we explore current and past perspectives on popular culture. We will focus on topics ranging from celebrity politics, meme culture (and the alt-right), fake news, race, and gender to transnational pop culture. We will discuss core questions like: Why and what ways do people engage with popular culture?
How has and will popular culture help us understand societal changes?
Every week, different theories and popular culture topics will be discussed and applied to specific forms of pop culture, like movies, series, games, and music.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on current and past perspectives on popular culture and its role in society.
• The relation between popular culture and societal changes.
• Critically assess and compare existing theories on popular culture and societal changes.
• Analyze and reflect upon popular cultural forms using concepts and theories covered in this course.
• Coherently present the discussed themes verbally (and visually) as well as in written assignments.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90464,2019,Current Topics in Marketing Research,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. B Van den Bergh', 'dr. CJP Lembregts', 'dr. JMT Roos', 'dr. M Szymanowski', 'dr. X Chen', 'prof.dr. G Liberali', 'prof.dr. S Puntoni', 'prof.dr. STLR Sweldens', 'prof.dr. YM van Everdingen', 'prof.dr.ir. A Smidts']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Topics that will be discussed are: Motivation in Consumer Behavior (van den Bergh); Introduction to Marketing Science (Roos); Consumer Neuroscience (Smidts); Learning Brand Associations (Sweldens); Consumer Processing of Numerical Information (Lembregts); Primer on Experimental Consumer Research (Puntoni); Machine Learning in Marketing (Liberali); Social Networks in Marketing (Chen); Adoption and Diffusion of Innovations (van Everdingen); Structural Demand Models (Szymanowski)</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The main goal of the course is to familiarize students with key areas of marketing research as well as with different methodological approaches that are influential in marketing. As a result, the course will cover a wide variety of topics and perspectives, spanning consumer behavior, marketing strategy, and quantitative marketing topics. The broad set of topics and methods reflects the diversity of marketing research. You are not expected to pursue research in all of these areas in the future. Rather, we would like the course to help you understand the field and form a clearer idea of what area might be most suitable for you.

The course also serves two additional goals: introducing students to RSM marketing faculty and introducing faculty to students. Our hope is that this course will offer a useful platform on which students can build to develop a successful line of research during their time at ERIM, by exposing them early on to the research carried out at the RSM marketing department and by facilitating interactions between students and faculty and thereby increasing the likelihood of collaborations.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90884,2019,Customer Centricity,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. A Lemmens'],,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The emergence of information and data technologies have led to a radical shift in the way marketing operations are run. The focus of companies has been shifted away from product-centric approaches and mass marketing campaigns to customer-centric campaigns tailored to the needs and wants of each customer. Customer-centric marketing campaigns target a well-chosen subset of customers, at a well-chosen time, and with a well-chosen incentive. Moreover, they also require a good monitoring of their impacts on firms’ profits. In other words, a customer-centric campaign requires companies to answer four key questions:

Customer-centric marketing can be applied to any domain of marketing and, so, is an approach that can be broadly adopted by multinationals. In this course, we will focus on the three key marketing tasks, which relate to the stages of a customer lifecycle: customer acquisition, customer development and customer retention.

The course will focus as much on the managerial questions and challenges, as well as on the use of methods to address these questions. This elective will be articulated around the customer lifecycle and rely on the core metric of Customer Lifetime Value (CLV).
The topics covered by the elective include, among others:

column3: • Historical perspective, strategic goals, business cases, concept of incremental impact
• Customer lifecycle, customer lifetime value, components, relation with firm value and stock market, variations across industries (e.g. contractual vs non-contractual)
• Social influence and referral programs, customer portfolio management
• Customer engagement, customer agency, cross-selling & up-selling, managing customer touchpoints, customer tier programs.
• Definition of churn across industries, churn management, proactive versus reactive campaigns, win-back strategies, loyalty programs
• Customers and privacy, governments and legislations, ethics, privacy policies, data security.
• Setting campaign goals, defining target, designing marketing experiments, uplift models, measuring the success of customer programs, visualization tools.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: By the end of this course, students will:

column2: • Understand and explain the importance and meaning of customer-centric marketing for today’s businesses;
• Have developed a good expertise of companies’ best practices in the domain of customer centricity;
• Have acquired a good understanding of the latest research in the area of customer centricity;
• Understand and explain the general intuition behind the methods companies have at their disposal to develop a customer-centric marketing strategy;
• Manipulate and do simple data analyses using the R programming language;
• Provide and justify concrete managerial recommendations to non-technical audiences through presentation and written report.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87488,2019,Customer Experience Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. CJP Lembregts'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

How can companies gain and sustain competitive advantage in an increasingly competitive environment? In recent years, companies have realized that a crucial source of competitive advantage lies in the provision of a compelling customer experience. Customer experience is comprised of all cognitive, emotional, physical, sensorial, and social elements that mark the customer’s interactions with companies or other market actors (De Keyser et al. 2015). Due to the rapid rise of digital and mobile devices, customers are increasingly valuing seamless experiences. In response, leading companies have decided to hire so-called “customer experience managers” to improve their customer experiences. This course discusses the general determinants of great customer experiences across all touch points (prior, during and after purchase) and introduces methods to improve customer experiences.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: Understand and explain the importance of customer experience management for business.
Recognize, understand and explain the determinants of great customer experiences.
Analyse companies’ customer experiences and identify strengths and weaknesses.
Understand and apply methods and techniques to improve customer experiences.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/87423,2019,Customer-centric Digital Commerce,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. D Tsekouras'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The costs of computing power and telecommunications have been dramatically reduced and, in this information intensive economy, products and services have been extensively digitized. Consumers are becoming more and more knowledgeable and demanding and contact firms in many different situations. These consumers require the formation of tailored value creation systems to better match their needs. As a result, business and marketing strategies have shifted from the traditional product-centric to a more customer-centric approach. The emerging challenge for firms is how to best support and activate consumers and also learn about their product needs. Increasingly firms and consumers work closely together in the value creation process across all stages of the value chain. In the information search stage, firms (e.g. Amazon, iTunes) attempt to maximize the accuracy of their recommendations by also incorporating consumer insights (product reviews). Firms such as Dell and Nike allow their customers to customize products to their own taste, whereas firms such as Threadless or Kickstarter rely on customers to generate ideas for new products. Platforms such as Airbnb or Etsy use customers’ spare resources (e.g. rooms, products) in order to create a community of sellers and buyers. Finally, firms like Wikipedia or Facebook heavily depend on consumer input to create value for other consumers. To be successful, these new business models often use non-conventional business models and digital commerce strategies to interact with consumers.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The first objective of the course is to provide students with a better understanding of how firms and consumers interact to create greater consumer value and how this process can best be organized. Different stages in the value creation process in which consumer-firm interactions take place are defined and analyzed (i.e. customer journey). Emerging marketing channels and IT-enabled systems that can be used for these different interactions receive special attention.

The second objective of the course is for students to learn how to analyze consumer channel usage decisions in each of the interaction stages. The course focuses on consumers’ or users’ information search, purchase decisions, product use, and product reviews.
Two key questions guide these analyses:

column2: • How can individual consumers best be supported in the value chain?
• How can consumers be activated so that they themselves become value co-creators?

column1: Finally, the course provides an overview of current examples of firms’ usage of information technology and marketing tactics across their digital commerce strategies.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/91803,2019,Customs Fundamentals I,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['ir. K Wassens'],,

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/91804,2019,Customs Fundamentals II,Nederlands,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['ir. K Wassens', 'J Thoms - van der Heul']",,"Inhoud

<body>This module concentrates on customs formalities, the customs suspension regime and miscellaneous topics. It starts with the customs formalities system, AEO and the suspension regimes such as warehousing and processing, all of which are at the core of the EU customs system. The module furthermore offers an introduction to excise duties and VAT on import and intra EU cross border transactions. Excise duties and VAT are closely linked to customs and play an important role in supply chains. The module ends with legislation concerning export controls and sanctions. In supply chains nowadays compliance with this legislation is gaining more and more importance.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <div>At the end of the module the student must be able to
·Evaluate and analyse the concept and rules of customs formalities, AEO and customs simplifications by using the concept and rules in a practical case;

column2: • Evaluate and analyse the concept of suspension regimes by using the concept in a practical case;
• Apply and analyse the rules of excise taxation by using these rules in a practical case;
• Apply and understand the rules of VAT on international transactions and the relationship between VAT and customs.
• Apply and understand the concepts of export controls and the sanction regime of the EU;

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: The course starts by introducing the basic types of data, data quality, preprocessing techniques, and measures of similarity and dissimilarity. Then it describes data classification techniques (e.g., decision trees, support vector machines, etc.) and classification evaluation measures (e.g., precision, recall, etc.). After that data clustering techniques (k-means, hierarchical clustering, etc.) and clustering evaluation measures (e.g., purity, entropy, etc.) are explained.

In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures the students will work in teams on assignments on the covered topics. The students will also make a report describing the proposed solutions.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/89881,2019,Data Visualisation,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['S Hammana', 'T de Groot, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In this course students discover why data visualisation is becoming increasingly important – both in the field of journalism and in the field of science. There are nowadays more and more unseen data that can or should be disclosed. Visualisation is the apparent answers to open up this vast amount of ‘big data’. Data visualisation is also needed to communicate effectively with an audience that is overloaded with information. Researchers who want to successfully disseminate their work should also think about how to construct compelling and effective visualisations. Basic knowledge of data visualisation principles will also help us to understand and apply data visualisation tools and techniques that have become freely available on the Internet, and to interact with data visualisation libraries and online communities. Data visualisation also enables us to incorporate the vast amount of open data, in particular since national governments and international organisations have opened their databases and made them accessible through interactive data visualisation tools.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The learning objectives of this course are twofold. On the one hand, we will teach you the basics of creating effective, creative and beautiful visualisations. On the other hand, we will teach you how to better understand the world of data and data visualisations and how to develop a critical attitude towards the politics of design and data visualisation.
At the end of this course students should be able to:

column2: • Understand, apply and reflect on the basic principles of good visuals (‘remove to improve’)
• Understand the politics of design and reflect critically on data visualisation in art, journalism and science

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90430,2019,Data analysis with Matlab/Advanced,Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen', 'P. Bremen']",,

Databases offer various models for storing, retrieving, and processing large amounts of data. In this course we focus on the most popular database model, namely the relational model. First relational databases are introduced, followed by formal languages for querying as relational algebra, tuple relational calculus, and domain relational calculus. Then, the entity-relationship diagram (ERD) is presented as a high-level abstraction of the modeled world. After that, the Structured Query Language (SQL), one of the most used query languages, is described. Last, the normalization theory employed for designing relational databases is given.

In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures, the students will work in teams on several assignments on the discussed topics. The students will also write a report describing the proposed solutions.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

<body>Knowledge and understanding of: the entity-relationship diagram (ERD), what is a relational database, how to query a relational database using the Structured Query Language (SQL), and how to design a relational database</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85498,2019,De Bestuurskundige Professional,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['prof.dr. H Geerlings', 'prof.dr. M van der Steen']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column3: De bedoeling van deze module is om de deelnemers ervan te doordringen, dat hun activiteiten in de publieke sector niet alleen waardevol, maar ook waardegeladen zijn. Het gaat om meer dan een instrumentele en dienstbare houding. In deze module worden kernvragen aan de orde gesteld als: Welke rollen vervullen bestuurskundige professionals in beleid en management? Welke voorwaarden, instrumenten en vaardigheden zijn noodzakelijk voor die verschillende rollen? Tegen welke normatieve en ethische vraagstukken lopen bestuurskundige professionals aan en hoe kunnen zij daarmee omgaan? Wat kan de toegevoegde waarde van bestuurskundige professionals zijn?

De module 'De Bestuurskundige Professional' gaat over wat bestuurskundigen in de praktijk meer nodig hebben dan 'alleen maar' wetenschappelijke kennis. Hoe overbruggen bestuurskundigen de kloof tussen theorie en praktijk? Hoe zorgen ze ervoor dat naar hun adviezen geluisterd wordt, dat hun onderzoeksresultaten serieus genomen worden? Hoe voorkomen zij dat ze de speelbal worden van belangen en conflicterende krachten in een organisatie? Hoe kunnen bestuurskundigen effectief zijn in onderzoek, advisering, beleidsontwikkeling, uitvoering of management, zonder zichzelf - hun integriteit - geweld aan te doen. Hoe kunnen zij voldoende recht doen aan, of rekening houden met bijzondere aspecten van het openbaar bestuur, zoals bijvoorbeeld de verhouding tussen ambtenaren en politiek verantwoordelijke bestuurders? Hoe moeten ze omgaan met normatieve en morele vragen, die werken in en met het openbaar bestuur onvermijdelijk oproept? Docenten en enkele gasten uit de praktijk van het openbaar bestuur zullen de thema's inleiden en de studenten stimuleren tot kritische reflectie en debat.
Ook gaan studenten in opdrachten en intervisiegroepen aan de slag met professionele vraagstukken die in hun eigen praktijk aan de orde zijn met een drieledig oogmerk:<ul>

column1: • a) op nieuwe manieren naar de eigen praktijk en het eigen functioneren kijken;
• b) de bruikbaarheid en toepassingsmogelijkheden van in de opleiding verworven kennis in beeld brengen, en c) verdere professionalisering te realiseren.

In deze module gaat het om de wijze waarop bestuurskundigen zich in de praktijk gedragen en welke overwegingen zij daarvoor hebben. Centraal doel van het college De Bestuurskundige Professional is de studenten te stimuleren en te helpen bij het nadenken over werken in en rond het openbaar bestuur en over de rollen die ze daarbij als bestuurskundigen (kunnen) spelen. Studenten worden geconfronteerd met de mogelijkheden om hun recent verworven bestuurskundige kennis in de praktijk te hanteren. Maar op welke wijze doen zij dat? Welk professioneel normenkader hanteren zij daarbij en waarom? Studenten worden ook gevoelig gemaakt voor de problemen en risico´s die zich kunnen voordoen bij het werken in de publieke sector. De module heeft een reflexief karakter.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86924,2019,De Bronnen van de Economie in de Middeleeuwse Theologie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. JW Hengstmengel', 'prof.dr. PJJ van Geest']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In deze module komen een aantal filosofische verhandelingen en theologische summae aan de orde, waarin de verhandelingen over geld, eigendom, arbeid, handel, marktwerking, rente en fraude zijn vervlochten. In chronologische volgorde worden sleutelpassages gelezen uit werken van Plato, Xenophon, Aristoteles, de evangelist Lucas, kerkvaders als Tertullianus, Cyprianus, Ambrosius, Johannes Chrysostomus Augustinus en theologen als  Johannes Duns Scotus, Bernardino van Siena, Robert Grosseteste, Thomas van Aquino en Gabriel Biel, waarin zij spreken over sociaal-economische vraagstukken als armoede, welvaart, geld, arbeid en eigendom.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Kennismaking met de filosofische en theologische traktaten van de premoderne tijd waarin thema’s als geld, eigendom, arbeid, handel, marktwerking, rente en fraude in verband worden gebracht met menselijke drijfveren, deugden en ondeugden.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86943,2019,De Culturele en Creatieve Industrieën,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. YGD Wijngaarden'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit vak maakt studenten bekend met een organisatie-theoretische kijk op de culturele sector. Relevante concepten uit de organisatietheorie zullen hierbij worden toegepast. Culturele organisaties (in de velden van kunst, media en erfgoed) worden gekarakteriseerd door eigenaardigheden en elementen die niet teruggevonden worden in andere beroepenvelden. In werkgroepen zullen, aan de hand van relevante artikelen, typische kwesties uit de wereld van culturele organisaties worden geanalyseerd.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit vak biedt studenten inzicht in organisaties en bedrijven in de culturele sector. Tijdens de hoorcolleges maken studenten kennis met het functioneren van zulke organisaties, terwijl de werkgroepen zich bezig zullen houden met eventuele problemen waar leidende culturele organisaties tegenaan kunnen lopen, en de oplossingen die hierbij kunnen horen. Deze kennis, over het functioneren van culturele organisaties, biedt een bruikbaar referentiekader voor de rest van het Bachelorprogramma.

IEJ Bonfrer', 'dr. J Weenink', 'dr. M de Mul', 'dr. RC van Kleef', 'dr.ir. SG Elkhuizen', 'drs. ACJ Drenthe', 'drs. SA van der Geest', 'HD Boet - Foley', 'JP Postma', 'K Kampstra, MBA', 'mr. CA Bol', 'mr. M Timmers', 'prof.dr. FT Schut', 'prof.dr. I Wallenburg', 'prof.dr. IN Fabbricotti', 'prof.dr. K Putters', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser', 'prof.dr. RA Bal']",,"Inhoud

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: De Nederlandse gezondheidszorg behoort tot één van de beste zorgsystemen ter wereld. In dit eerste onderwijsblok maak je kennis met de Nederlandse Gezondheidszorg, vanuit drie verschillende disciplines: de economische, de juridische en de bestuurlijke. Daarnaast ontwikkel je academische vaardigheden, werk je aan je persoonlijke vaardigheden en leer je om de inzichten vanuit de drie genoemde disciplines te integreren.

Waarom bemoeit de overheid zich zo intensief met de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg en op welke manier? Deze vraag beantwoorden we vanuit de economische wetenschap. We beginnen met een analyse van de oorzaken en gevolgen van stijgende zorguitgaven. Vervolgens bestuderen we belangrijke problemen in zorgmarkten die overheidsingrijpen nodig maken. Wat gebeurt er bijvoorbeeld als de overheid zich niet meer bemoeit met zorgverzekeringen? Ook bekijken we de huidige structuur en financiering van de Nederlandse gezondheidszorg en de ontwikkeling van het zorgstelsel sinds 1900. Tot slot vergelijken we het Nederlandse zorgstelsel met landen die een andere structuur en financiering van de gezondheidszorg hebben.

Zorg is een recht. En niet zomaar een recht, maar een mensenrecht dat in talloze internationale en Europese mensenrechtenverdragen is vastgelegd. In een rechtstaat als Nederland worden mensenrechten met wetgeving, bestuur en rechtspraak beschermd. Je maakt kennis met de verschillende soorten mensenrechten en met de manier waarop Nederland deze vertaalt in nationaal beleid. Hierbij zijn verschillende partijen belangrijk: wetgevers, bestuurders en rechters. Hoe verhouden deze zich tot elkaar en welke rollen vervullen zij met betrekking tot de (gezondheids)zorg? We eindigen met een eerste kennismaking met de belangrijkste nationale wetten op de terreinen van zorgverlening, zorgverzekering en zorginkoop.

Vanuit beleid en bestuur houden we ons in dit eerste blok bezig met de vragen: Wat is beleid? Wie zijn er betrokken bij het opstellen en uitvoeren van beleid? En hoe kunnen we dit alles op een goede manier onderzoeken en begrijpen? We gaan in op de historie van gezondheidszorgbeleid en bespreken verschillende wetenschapsperspectieven, zoals het rationele en het incrementele perspectief. Aan de hand van de beleidscyclus analyseren we hoe beleid tot stand komt en wanneer er sprake is van ‘goed’ beleid.

We hebben aandacht voor jouw vaardigheden als academicus-in-opleiding. Je krijgt een introductie in het zoeken, lezen en verwerken van wetenschappelijke bronnen, een inleiding in wetenschappelijk onderzoek, academisch schrijven en presenteren. Hierdoor maak je een goede start voor je academische vorming voor de rest van je opleiding.
Hieraan werk je gedurende het blok. Bekijk de pagina Persoonlijke en Professionele Ontwikkeling in canvas voor meer informatie.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• de gezondheid van een populatie omschrijven aan de hand van gezondheidsindicatoren;
• de belangrijkste gezondheidsproblemen in Nederland en de belangrijkste gezondheidsverschillen tussen hoge- en lage inkomenslanden beschrijven;
• op genuanceerde wijze betekenis geven aan de begrippen ziekte en gezondheid en het spanningsveld binnen en tussen beide begrippen beschrijven;
• verschillende theorieën gebruiken om het gedrag ten aanzien van ziekte en gezondheid van mensen te verklaren;
• verschillende sociologische theorieën gebruiken om te verklaren dat de betekenis die we toekennen aan ziekte en gezondheid onderhevig is aan tijd en cultuur;
• reflecteren op verschillende manieren om tot (wetenschappelijke) kennis over ziekte en gezondheid te komen;

• de juridische achtergrond van overheidsverplichtingen met betrekking tot (het bevorderen van) gezondheid beschrijven en kan jij de daarbij relevante wetten (Wet Publieke Gezondheid (WPG) en Wet op het bevolkingsonderzoek (WBO)) betrekken
• benoemen hoe de Wet op de Geneeskundige Behandelovereenkomst (WGBO) in de patiëntenzorg de invulling van de arts-patiëntrelatie normeert;
• de voor de praktijk meest relevante jurisprudentie ten aanzien van de WPG, WBO, WGBO en WMOM vinden en interpreteren;

• verschillen en overeenkomsten tussen kwantitatief en kwalitatief onderzoek beschrijven en ken jij de voor- en nadelen van de meest voorkomende dataverzamelingsmethoden binnen deze onderzoekstradities;
• de verschillende fasen van de kwalitatieve onderzoekscyclus toepassen op een concrete casus, de keuzes beargumenteren en hier kritisch op reflecteren.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85785,2019,De Professionele School,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. LAL de Meijer'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A professional school is directed by an excellent school leader who shows instructional and transformational leadership. This school leader focuses on student learning and instruction, is clear in his or her goals and involves teachers in the process of change. In the professional school, teachers are excellent and are continuously developing professionally. But most importantly, professional schools succeed in stimulating and supporting all their students to develop and perform to their full potential.

Supporting professional capacity building can be seen as one of the fundamentals of school improvement. Professional capacity encompasses the quality of staff (teachers as well as school leaders), the quality of their professional development activities as well as their capacity to cooperate with each other and other professionals and work towards common goals of teaching and learning. This cooperation can take place in so-called professional communities that can be characterized by for example a focus on student learning, shared values and goals, and a common feeling of responsibility for the schools’ success. The focus of this module will be on the characteristics of professional schools. The module covers the following four topics: Teacher quality, school leadership, the school as a learning organization (including the role of research), and urban school development.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Following completion of this module, students are expected to be able to do each of the following:

column2: • Describe the main theories and models on professional capacity in schools, in general as well as in urban settings;
• Evaluate the effectiveness of these theories and models on professional capacity?;
• Describe the main forms of continuous professional development, in general as well as in urban settings, and their underlying theories;
• Evaluate the effectiveness of the main forms of continuous professional development.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85584,2019,De Sociologische Blik:een scherpere kijk op de samenleving en jezelf,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. SRJM van Bohemen', 'prof.dr. W de Koster']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De opleiding Sociologie is gericht op de intellectuele en beroepsmatige interesses van studenten die belangstelling hebben voor wat er gebeurt in de samenleving én in de eigen interacties met anderen. Sociologie biedt niet alleen een grote rijkdom aan theoretische inzichten en onderzoeksresultaten; wie de sociologie bestudeert verwerft specifieke manieren van kijken naar de wisselwerking tussen mens en maatschappij.  Sociologische kennis en vaardigheden zijn nuttig bij tal van beroepen en dragen bij aan persoonlijke groei.

In deze minor verbreed je je blikveld en bestudeer je de hoofdvragen van de sociologie (sociale ongelijkheid, sociale cohesie, modernisering en identiteit) aan de hand van actuele vraagstukken rondom onder meer globalisering, criminaliteit, sociale ongelijkheid in het onderwijs en de arbeidsmarkt, gender, en groepsidentiteiten. Daarbij leer je de vier belangrijkste sociologische perspectieven te hanteren (functionalisme, conflictsociologie, symbolisch-interactionisme en de rationele keuze benadering).

De minor heeft ook een verdiepend karakter: je kunt een invloedrijk sociologisch werk bestuderen dat betrekking heeft op, of raakt aan, je eigen vakgebied, waaronder psychologie, pedagogiek, rechten, bedrijfskunde, geneeskunde, bouwkunde, geschiedenis, media- en cultuurwetenschappen en filosofie.

Studenten met een Bachelordiploma die deze minor met succes hebben afgerond verkrijgen daarmee toegang tot een Master-opleiding in de Sociologie (waaronder Grootstedelijke vraagstukken en beleid; Arbeid, Organisatie en Management; Governance of Migration & Diversity; Politics & Society), mits ze voldoende kennis van sociaalwetenschappelijke methoden kunnen aantonen.

De minor bestaat uit drie Modules: Module 1, Module 2 en Module 3. Het onderwijs voor Module 2 en 3 wordt ook gegeven aan reguliere sociologiestudenten en pre-Master studenten Sociologie. Voor Module 2 (blok 1) en Module 3 (blik 2) zijn er hoorcolleges en onderwijsgroepen waarbij studenten onder meer werken met Probleem Gestuurd Onderwijs (PGO). Voor Module 1 vinden er verspreid over blok 1 en 2 speciaal voor de minorstudenten kleinschalige werkgroepen plaats. Alle contacturen zijn overdag.
De minor bestaat uit drie modules.

column2: • Inhoud: Je ontwikkelt een sociologische kijk op je eigen vakgebied – bjiv. psychologie, pedagogiek, rechten, bedrijfskunde, geneeskunde, bouwkunde, geschiedenis, filosofie –  door het bestuderen van een voor jou relevant, invloedrijk sociologisch werk. Ook heb je de optie om twee meer populairwetenschappelijke sociologische boeken te bestuderen van Gladwell. Je geeft twee presentaties of een presentatie gevolgd door een essay. Tijdens werkgroepen krijg je gelegenheid om de stof met de docent en met andere minorstudenten te bespreken.

• Inhoud: Je maakt kennis met het gedachtegoed en begrippenapparaat van de Sociologie en leert de verschillende velden en actuele thema’s waarmee de Sociologie zich bezighoudt, te herkennen en benoemen. Daarnaast leer je de vier belangrijkste sociologische perspectieven (functionalisme, conflictsociologie, symbolisch-interactionisme en rationele keuzebenadering) beschrijven en gebruiken bij het analyseren van vraagstukken rond modernisering, cohesie, ongelijkheid en identiteit (de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie).
In de colleges worden de vier hoofdvragen en sociologische perspectieven besproken aan de hand van actuele thema’s en gebeurtenissen.
• Onderwijsmateriaal: In het studielandschap van de UB zijn verschillende leerboeken beschikbaar. Via de digitale leeromgeving worden artikelen en boekhoofdstukken aangeboden.

• Inhoud: Deze cursus beoogt studenten dieper kennis te laten maken met de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie: modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit. Studenten maken kennis met verschillende hedendaagse toonaangevende discussies binnen deze vier thema’s, en leren reflecteren op diverse prominente onderzoeksproblemen.

Aan de hand van deze verdieping in de centrale thema’s van de sociologie, wordt aandacht besteed aan de vertaalslag van sociologische theorie naar empirie. De student leert hoe puzzels binnen de thema’s modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit kunnen worden onderzocht met behulp van empirisch onderzoek. Naast het behandelen van voorbeelden van empirisch onderzoek binnen deze vier thema’s, leren studenten hoe ze zelf theoretische begrippen kunnen aanwenden voor de formulering van empirisch toetsbare vragen of verwachtingen.
• Onderwijsmateriaal: In het studielandschap van de UB zijn verschillende leerboeken beschikbaar. Via de digitale leeromgeving worden artikelen en boekhoofdstukken aangeboden.

column1: Een schriftelijk tentamen in week 5 (module 1) en week 10 (module 2) en twee individuele presentaties gespreid over blok 1 en 2 (module 3).

De cijfers voor Module 1, 2 en 3 bepalen voor respectievelijk 20%, 40% en 40% het eindcijfer. De Minor is behaald als het gewogen gemiddelde tenminste 5,5 bedraagt. De drie behaalde cijfers hebben het karakter van deelcijfers: er is onderlinge compensatie tussen de drie cijfers mogelijk.</body>

column1: <body>Als je de minor succesvol hebt afgerond kun je:

column2: • prominente sociologische theorieën toepassen rondom de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie: modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit.

• centrale begrippen binnen de vier hoofdvragen van de sociologie beschrijven en toepassen op hedendaagse maatschappelijke vraagstukken (waaronder: globalisering, criminaliteit, sociale ongelijkheid in het onderwijs en de arbeidsmarkt, gender, en groepsidentiteiten).
• Voorbeelden geven van empirisch onderzoek binnen de vier hoofdthema's
• empirisch toetsbare vragen en verwachtingen formuleren op basis van sociologische theorieën over modernisering, ongelijkheid, cohesie en identiteit.
• uitleggen hoe sociologen aankijken tegen een of meerdere verschijnselen of theorieën die in je eigen wetenschappelijke discipline centraal staan, of aan die discipline raken.

column1: In het vak komen drie kernthema’s aan bod. Deze kernthema’s zijn:
A. Het financieel toezichtrecht, de beursgang en het prospectus;
B. Marktmisbruik & publicatieverplichtingen van de beursvennootschap, haar aandeelhouders en andere aan de vennootschap gelieerde (rechts)personen;
C. De aansprakelijkheid van de beursvennootschap en haar bestuurders voor misleidende informatie.
Elk kernthema wordt in een aantal colleges uitgediept, waarbij zoveel mogelijk interactief college wordt gegeven en actuele ontwikkelingen worden besproken.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• De student is in staat de belangrijkste voor- en nadelen van een beursnotering uiteen te zetten en kan hierover in concrete casus een juridisch gefundeerd advies uitbrengen.

• De student is in staat te beargumenteren waarom in het kader van een beursgang een prospectus moet worden gepubliceerd en kan tevens beredeneren aan welke inhoudelijke vereisten dit prospectus dient te voldoen.

• De student heeft inzicht in het gehele proces rondom een beursgang en in de rol van alle daarbij betrokken partijen en tevens is de student in staat de belangrijkste (deel)fases in dit proces, zoals het due diligence-onderzoek en het bookbuilding-proces, te beschrijven en hierover te adviseren.
• De student kan vanuit financieel-economisch en rechtseconomisch perspectief beredeneren wat de functie is van (het publiceren van) informatie op de effectenmarkt.
• De student is bekend met en heeft inzicht in de belangrijkste informatieverplichtingen waarmee de beursvennootschap tijdens (de duur van) haar beursnotering wordt geconfronteerd.

• De student heeft inzicht in de belangrijkste wet- en regelgeving ten aanzien van het openbaar bod, in het bijzonder in de informatieverplichtingen waarmee bieder en doelvennootschap rondom het openbaar bod worden geconfronteerd.

• De student is in staat te beoordelen en te beargumenteren wanneer sprake is van wederrechtelijke handel met voorwetenschap en kan tevens beredeneren wat de doelstelling is van het verbod tot handel met voorwetenschap.

• De student is in staat te beoordelen en te beargumenteren wanneer bepaalde informatie als ”voorwetenschap” dient te worden aangemerkt en kan tevens beoordelen en beargumenteren wanneer sprake is van marktmanipulatie.

• De student heeft inzicht in het leerstuk van prospectusaansprakelijkheid en is tevens in staat in concrete casus te beoordelen en te beargumenteren of een (mededeling in het) prospectus al dan niet misleidend is.
• De student heeft inzicht in de aansprakelijkheid van de beursvennootschap en haar bestuurders wegens het niet publiceren van voorwetenschap en/of het overtreden van het marktmanipulatieverbod.

• De student is bekend met de wettelijke regeling van de jaarrekeningprocedure, tevens heeft de student inzicht in de aansprakelijkheid van de beursvennootschap en haar bestuurders wegens het publiceren van misleidende financiële verslaggeving en is daarnaast in staat in concrete casus te beoordelen en te beargumenteren of een gepubliceerde jaarrekening al dan niet misleidend is.
• In algemene zin heeft de student inzicht in de belangrijkste op de beursvennootschap van toepassing zijnde (Europese en nationale) effectenrechtelijke wet- en regelgeving.

• De student kan zelfstandig zowel Nederlands- als Engelstalige wetenschappelijke artikelen over onderwerpen die behoren tot het domein van de beursvennootschap bestuderen, analyseren, beoordelen en daarop kritisch reflecteren.

column1: Deze cursus richt zich op de stad als een politieke arena waarin verschillende politieke actoren opereren met verschillende, vaak strijdige belangen. Het vak is georganiseerd rond vier centrale thema's. Ten eerste wordt een inleiding gegeven in de belangrijkste theoretische benaderingen van stedelijk beleid. Daarbij gaan we in op de vraag naar de beleidsspeelruimte van steden: can cities act? Een belangrijk vraagstuk hierbij is hoe stedelijk sociaal beleid bij kan dragen aan het versterken van de sociale cohesie en het verminderen van sociale ongelijkheid. Ook besteden we aandacht aan de manieren waarop steden stedelijke ontwikkelingen monitoren en de resultaten van hun beleid evalueren. Ten tweede richt de cursus zich op het bestuur van steden in multi-level settings: de onderlinge relatie van lokale, nationale en supranationale beleidsniveaus, evenals vormen van zelforganisatie van burgers. Ten derde wordt geanalyseerd hoe stedelijke beleidsmakers en instellingen omgaan met Europa's migrantenpopulaties die steeds diverser en vlottender worden. Dit is het vraagstuk van ""de nieuwe verscheidenheid"". Ten slotte gaan we in deze cursus nader in op specifieke vormen van ""verzet"" door burgers, zoals de opkomst van stedelijke sociale bewegingen en het ontstaan van stedelijke rellen en stedelijk geweld in Europese steden als Parijs, Londen en Stockholm. Daarbij komt ook de vraag aan de orde waarom dergelijke rellen in andere Europese steden niet voorkomen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na succesvolle afronding van deze cursus zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • Inzicht te geven in de relevante theorievorming over politiek en bestuur van Europese steden.

• Theorieën en empirisch onderzoek over vraagstukken van stedelijke bestuur en beleid te relateren aan stedelijke vraagstukken van armoede, migratie en integratie, leefbaarheid en veiligheid, en onbehagen.
• Een analyse te maken van de aard van stedelijke ongelijkheid en van de verschillende manieren waarop stedelijk beleid en bestuur daarop van invloed is.
• Een analyse te maken van de aard van stedelijke sociale cohesie en sociale conflicten en van de verschillende manieren waarop stedelijk beleid en bestuur daarop van invloed is.
• Kritisch te reflecteren op de belangen van verschillende stedelijke actoren en hoe ze van invloed zijn op de inhoud en vormgeving van stedelijk beleid.
• Verklaringen te geven voor de kracht en zwaktes van zelforganisaties van bewoners.
• (Internationaal) vergelijkende analyses te maken van stedelijk beleid en bestuur in de omgang met sociale ongelijkheid, sociale cohesie en sociale conflicten.
• Heldere en gerichte papers te schrijven over de wekelijkse literatuur.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In deze cursus staan de ruimtelijke en demografische ontwikkelingen van steden centraal. Sinds begin deze eeuw woont meer dan de helft van de wereldbevolking in stedelijke omgevingen. Steden zijn daarmee de dominante samenlevingsvorm van onze tijd. Deze cursus richt zich met name op stedelijke ontwikkelingen in de westerse wereld. Steden kenden in de loop der jaren perioden van opkomst en groei, maar ook tijden van verval. Westerse steden kwamen tot ontwikkeling tijdens de 19de eeuwse industriële revolutie. Na de Tweede Wereldoorlog volgde een tijd van ontstedelijking en verval, die voortduurde tot in de jaren ’90 van de vorige eeuw. Sindsdien zien we een heropleving van steden, die in toenemende mate weer aantrekkelijk zijn voor (delen van) de middenklasse die voorheen eerder een suburbane leefstijl verkozen. Dit leidt tot processen van nieuwe verstedelijking en gentrificatie. Een ander facet van hedendaagse steden is de toenemende etnische en culturele diversiteit, die sommigen als verrijking van de stedelijke samenleving zien en anderen als oorzaak van problemen. De wederopleving van steden en de stedelijke leefwijze is niet alleen een succesverhaal. Hedendaagse steden worden in toenemende mate ook gekenmerkt door ongelijkheid, polarisatie en segregatie. En wat betekenen hedendaagse tendensen zoals toenemende diversiteit, individualisering en afnemende sociale cohesie voor hedendaagse stadswijken? Is de hedendaagse stadsbuurt nog een hechte en veilige sociale gemeenschap voor bewoners? En hoe beoordelen we dat?

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>Na succesvolle afronding van deze cursus kunnen studenten:

column2: • Theorieën en bevindingen van empirisch onderzoek over demografische en ruimtelijke ontwikkelingern van en in steden in heden en verleden bespreken.

• Actuele stedelijke ontwikkelingen zoals suburbanisatie, herurbanisatie, gentrificatie, etnische en sociale segregatie, alsmedfe de maatschappelijke gevolgen daarvan, kunnen analyseren in het licht van relevante stadssociologische theorieën en onderzoeksbevindingen.

• Actuele ontwikkelingen in hedendaagse stadsbuurten zoals (afnemende) sociale cohesie, buurtcontacten en (gepercipeerde) veiligheid kunnen analyseren in het licht van relevante stadssociologische theorieën en onderzoeksbevindingen.
• Onderzoek over buurt- of concentratie-effecten in stadsbuurten (incl. uitkomsten van multi-level regressietabellen) begrijpen.
• Stadssociologische en stadsgeografische inzichten toepassen op actuele stedelijke ontwikkelingen in Nederlandse of andere westerse steden.
• Kritisch reflecteren op en beknopte, gefocuste papers schrijven over theorieën in stadsstudies.
